articleBodyHTML:
Talia is here to show you how to have pancakes every day without spiking your blood sugar or expanding your waistline! And the taste is so good, you’ll want seconds!

Talia Pollock from Party in My Plants is taking pancakes to new heights of awesome. If someone told her she could have pancakes daily without jerking her blood sugar and waistline around, she would’ve been all about it. Adding Sunwarrior protein to the mix has made flipping (get it?) her attitude about this breakfast food possible. You can feel light and energized rather than needing a nap.

Talia eats this every day, and personally attributes her increase in happiness and decrease in weight to discovering this recipe. Just look at her energy and happiness levels for proof. Don’t let her personal hype or hyperness sway you though. Try it for yourself and see.
articleSummaryHTML: Talia is here to show you how to have pancakes every day without spiking your blood sugar or expanding your waistline! And the taste is so good, you’ll want seconds!
seoTitle: Perfect Protein Pancakes: Vegan Style! | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Talia is here to show you how to have pancakes every day without spiking your blood sugar or expanding your waistline! And the taste is so good.
ingredients:
s:627:"
  • ½ ripe banana
  • 1 tablespoon ground flax seed
  • 2 tablespoons warm water
  • ¼ cup + 2 tablespoons almond milk
  • 1 scoop Sunwarrior Classic Plus chocolate protein (or whichever flavor you like best)
  • ¼ teaspoon cinnamon
  • 1 teaspoon baking powder
  • ½ cup rolled oats
";
directions:
Dump a tablespoon of ground flax seed into a jar and add to it two tablespoons of warm water. Stir this together before letting it sit for a couple minutes to gel up. This is a flax egg. It acts as an egg in recipes, but, you know, without the egg.

Put your half a ripe banana mashed up on a plate. That nanner will serve as your sweetener. Put your mashed banana in a bowl with a quarter cup of almond milk plus two tablespoons of almond milk. Add one scoop of Sunwarrior protein. The flavor you use determines the final flavor of your pancakes. You can make them chocolate, vanilla, mocha, or even berry flavored. Classic or Classic Plus work best here, but the others will do in a pinch, too (they might need another tablespoon or two of almond milk to get the texture right). Add a quarter teaspoon cinnamon, one teaspoon baking powder, half a cup of rolled oats, and your flax egg. Mix it up real good. Add some stevia if you like to make it sweeter or a tablespoon of maple syrup. You can add other extracts too, like vanilla, strawberry, peach, lemon, and more.

Grease your griddle with coconut oil, and pour those pancakes on over medium to medium-low heat. Cook three to five minutes on one side. Flip. Turn down the heat and cook another three to five. You have to cook these longer on lower heat to get the deliciousness you want. Top them with your favorite fruit and nut butters and enjoy!

articleTitle: Cashew Orange Cheesecake with Strawberry Orange Coulis
articleBodyHTML:
We’re nuts about this cheesecake! Not only because it’s made with cashews instead of cream cheese but because all the health benefits make it easier to justify having a bigger slice!

My newest oh wow dessert!  A cashew cheesecake infused with orange and robed in strawberries! It’s rich, thick, and creamy, screaming of indulgence and just begging to be enjoyed.  I have long been a fan of cheesecake, yet with years of near zero dairy intake and the reality that dairy is a top food allergen, I abstain.  So, of course, I found a delicious alternative! There is no need to announce this is vegan (unless you’re sharing with people who have nut allergies). There’s no need to announce that it was easy to make, either. Your guests will only know that they are eating a truly fantastic dessert.

Did you know? Cashews are cholesterol-free, an excellent source of copper, and a good source of phosphorus, magnesium, manganese, and zinc.
articleSummaryHTML: We’re nuts about this cheesecake! Not only because it’s made with cashews instead of cream cheese but because all the health benefits make it easier to justify having a bigger slice!
seoTitle: Cashew Orange Cheesecake with Strawberry Orange Coulis
seoDescription: We’re nuts about this cheesecake! Check out Sunwarrior's cashew orange cheesecake with strawberry orange coulis. It's easy to make and delicious.
recipeName: Cashew Orange Cheesecake with Strawberry Orange Coulis
ingredients:
s:1117:"

Crust Ingredients

  • 1½ cups raw almond or pecan meal 
  • 1/3–1/2 cup Medjool dates, pitted
  • 2 tablespoons coconut oil, room temp
  • 1 teaspoon real vanilla extract or Cointreau
  • 1 teaspoon organic orange zest
  • 1 pinch sea salt

Filling Ingredients

  • 3 cups raw cashews, soaked 4 hours or overnight, rinsed, and drained
  • ¾ cup freshly squeezed orange juice
  • ½ cup raw agave or maple syrup
  • ½ cup coconut oil, warmed to liquid in a hot water bath
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla 
  • 1 heaping teaspoon organic orange zest
  • ½ teaspoon sea salt 
";
directions:
Cake

1. Blend the crust ingredients together in a food processor until it starts to stick together. Add extra dates only if needed.  Press the crust into the bottom of a 9 inch, parchment-lined, spring form pan, to about ¼ inch thickness.  Set aside while you make the filling. 

2. In a high-speed blender or food processor, blend together cashews, agave or maple syrup, and juice. Blast until creamy and smooth, scraping down the sides occasionally if necessary. Add remaining ingredients and continue to blend until mixture is well combined.  The consistency will be similar to a thick pudding.

3. Use a spatula to pour and scrape the filling over the crust, smooth evenly. Cover the cheesecake and place in the freezer on a flat surface for approximately four hours or until frozen throughout. 

4. When ready to serve, remove the cheesecake from the pan and let stand at room temp for 5–10 minutes then garnish as desired and slice into 10–12 slivers.  Return any leftovers to the freezer or fridge until you are ready to enjoy again.  This delish cake will keep up 2–4 weeks if well wrapped. 

Simple Strawberry and Orange Coulis

1. Wash and slice one pint organic strawberries.  Cook over medium heat in a saucepan with a splash of fresh orange juice, maple syrup or agave.  Once boiling, reduce heat to a simmer, and continue to cook until your berry mix is thickened to coat the back of a spoon.  Add an ounce of Cointreau if desired.

2.  Let cool, puree ½ of the mixture if desired then chill.  When you are ready to serve your cake, spread the thickened coulis evenly over the entire cake, garnish as desired and relish this delish dessert.

Top with fresh berries, strawberry orange coulis, or chia jam and additional orange zest.

Garnish with raw 80% chocolate shavings or coconut cream.

Teri's Tip

The cake is best made in a high-speed power blender like the affordable Harley Pasternak by Salton.  If making this in a food processor, be patient and blend for a few minutes at a time until the cream is smooth and silky.

articleBodyHTML:
This elegant plant-based dinner is sure to impress and satisfy even your non-vegan friends and family. Caitlyn’s stuffed acorn squash is a definite crowd pleaser.

One of my favorite things about Autumn is the walk from the car into the house. The sun has started setting earlier. In the near dark, leaves tumble across the sidewalks, and the wind that carries them gives me a chill. I know that in a matter of seconds I will step inside my home and be greeted by two eager boxers and the warmth of the oven. As the weather gradually cools down, gone are the breakfast smoothie bowls and refreshing summer salads, replaced by earthy flavor profiles that remind us of fall. Is it any wonder earth-grown nutrients make for the best autumn meals? I wanted to share a simple, yet elegant, plant-based dinner sure to impress and satisfy vegans and everyone else.
articleSummaryHTML: This elegant plant-based dinner is sure to impress and satisfy even your non-vegan friends and family. Caitlyn’s stuffed acorn squash is a definite crowd pleaser.
seoTitle: Caitlyn’s Stuffed Acorn Squash | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: This elegant plant-based dinner is sure to impress and satisfy even your non-vegan friends and family. Caitlyn’s stuffed acorn squash is a win-win!
ingredients:
s:893:"
  • 2 acorn squash
  • ½ cup sprouted rice blend, cooked
  • 1 tablespoon olive oil
  • 2 cups Portobello mushrooms, stems removed, roughly chopped
  • 1 carrot, roughly chopped
  • 1 celery stalk, diced
  • 1 shallot, finely chopped
  • 2 cloves garlic, minced
  • 6 sprigs fresh thyme, minced
  • 6 fresh sage leaves, minced
  • 1 cup collard greens, chopped
  • ¼ cup walnuts, toasted and chopped
  • Salt and pepper, to taste
  • 2 tablespoons bread crumbs, for topping
";
directions:
1. Preheat oven to 450.
  2. Cook rice according to package directions and set aside.
  3. Remove tops and pulp of the squash. Cut a small portion of the bottom off to provide a stable base. (Fun tip: Reserve the seeds and roast for a snack!)
  4. In a deep, heavy-bottomed pot, heat olive oil and add mushrooms. Cook for around 5 minutes, or until juices are released.
  5. Add shallot, carrot, and celery. Cook for additional 5 minutes, until shallot is transparent and carrot is tender.
  6. Add garlic, thyme, and sage. Cook for 30 seconds.
  7. Stir in chopped collard greens and cook for an additional 30 seconds, until green begin to wilt.
  8. Remove from heat and mix in cooked rice and toasted walnuts.
  9. Add salt and pepper to taste.
  10. Stuff the acorn squash with rice mixture and place inside a rimmed baking dish. Cover with foil.
  11. Bake for 40–45 minutes, until a fork can be easily inserted into the squash.
  12. Remove foil and top with bread crumbs.
  13. Coat lightly with coconut oil spray and put back in the oven, uncovered, for 5 minutes.
  14. Plate and enjoy!

articleBodyHTML:
With just 5 ingredients, you can raise your hands with reckless abandon. Stay dry and smell good with this 5 ingredient DIY deodorant!

Making your own all-natural, chemical-free deodorant is super easy and fun! You are eliminating chemicals in your lifestyle while still using something that keeps odors and sweat minimal. PLUS you’re keeping your immune system strong. You can also use different oils in this recipe to make different pleasing smells that have specific positive benefits for the body.

Raw coconut oil kills odor causing fungi, yeast, and bacteria. It’s also great because it will solidify the mixture when cold. Aluminum-free baking soda neutralizes odors. Arrowroot powder helps to absorb moisture. Sunwarrior Immune Shield is anti-bacterial, anti-Fungal, anti-viral, and immune boosting. Frankincense is an antiseptic and disinfectant. Frankincense oil is also immune boosting and is known to reduce anxiety and stress. Frankincense may help fight cancer, and deal with chemotherapy side effects.

Frankincense oil also helps with regulating estrogen production, hormone balancing, and reducing the effects of PMS. It is a nice, healing addition to your DIY deodorant that has practical disinfecting benefits but also cell health benefits.
articleSummaryHTML: With just 5 ingredients, you can raise your hands with reckless abandon. Stay dry and smell good with this 5 ingredient DIY deodorant!
seoTitle: 5 Ingredient Deodorant | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: With just 5 ingredients, you can raise your hands with reckless abandon. Stay dry and smell good with this 5 ingredient DIY deodorant!
ingredients:
s:550:"

5 Ingredient Deodorant

  • ¼ cup aluminum-free baking soda
  • ¼ cup arrowroot powder
  • 4 tablespoons raw, organic coconut oil (at room temperature so it is soft)
  • Optional: 8 drops of pure essential oil of choice
  • Optional: ½ teaspoon Sunwarrior Immune Shield
";
directions:
1. Mix baking soda and arrowroot together in a medium sized bowl.
  2. Mash in coconut oil with a fork until well mixed.
  3. Mix in essential oil and Immune Shield
  4. Optional: I also added ½ teaspoon of colloidal silver for extra anti-bacterial benefits.
  5. Store in small glass jar or old deodorant container for easy use. Since you only need a little bit, a small jar should last you for about 6 months! Store in a dry, cool place away from sunlight.

Tips:

  • Apply with fingers. You only need a very small amount. Make sure it is fully rubbed into your armpit to avoid any potential staining of shirts. I like to massage it into my armpit, knowing that I am helping to move my lymph for better health, take a deep breath, and say a positive affirmation.
  • If you don’t have arrowroot powder, you can also use organic corn starch from Bob’s Red Mill. Or you can make this recipe with baking soda only.
  • Some people notice irritation from baking soda. If so, then omit it from the recipe and use arrowroot powder in its place.
  • If you’re purchasing essential oils, avoid oils that say “fragrance oil” or “perfume oil” as these can be synthetic and can be more toxic than beneficial. Instead, look for oils that say “pure essential oil” or “100% essential oil” for the highest quality essential oil.

articleBodyHTML:
Make breakfast awesome with flavors that sing in this Peruvian quinoa porridge! Because waking up to awesome is just how you do things!

One of the great things about traveling is you get to experience different cuisines, and as a chef, I get to taste different flavors, herbs, and different food combinations. During one such trip to Peru, while hiking the amazing Andes, I was given porridge – with a taste and texture that still lingers when I think about it. It was something so simple, nourishing, and healthy that I had to recreate the recipe on my own.

This recipe is packed with fiber, complex carbohydrates, fats, protein and essential vitamins. It’s a great breakfast!
articleSummaryHTML: Make breakfast awesome with flavors that sing in this Peruvian quinoa porridge! Because waking up to awesome is just how you do things!
seoTitle: Peruvian Quinoa Porridge
seoDescription: Make breakfast awesome with flavors that sing in this Peruvian quinoa porridge! Because waking up to awesome is just how you do things!
ingredients:
s:556:"
  • 2 cups rice milk (or Brazil nut milk)
  • 1 cup quinoa
  • 1 cup amaranth
  • 1 teaspoon cloves
  • 1 teaspoon cinnamon
  • 2 tablespoons coconut sugar (or honey)
  • 1 scoop Sunwarrior Classic Plus vanilla protein
  • 1 teaspoon sea salt
";
directions:
1. Heat the nut milk with cloves and cinnamon. Slowly add coconut sugar to it. After boiling for about 15 minutes, strain out the ingredients, and allow the nut milk to cool
  2. Cook the quinoa and amaranth separately in a pan
  3. Once the grains are done, transfer as much as needed to the milk to reach desired consistency
  4. Using a ladle, you can stir the mixture
  5. Add the Sunwarrior Classic Plus vanilla protein at this point

You can serve this warm or store it in the refrigerator and serve it cold.

Variations

You can change the consistency of the porridge by adding more grains or even chia seeds to it.

Or serve it as a light porridge by adding more nut milk to it.

Enjoy!

articleBodyHTML:
Add a little spice to your pecans and keep life amazingly nutty (in the best way possible!).

Pecans are a crazy awesome source of energy and are an incredible source of fiber and manganese and copper as well as the omega 3 fatty acids—the healthy fats that are super good for you. The fiber aids digestion and promotes heart health. A little nut can do so much for you! {9kucur9p
articleSummaryHTML: Add a little spice to your pecans and keep life amazingly nutty (in the best way possible!).
seoTitle: Spicy Pecans | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Add a little spice to your pecans and keep life amazingly nutty (in the best way possible!).
ingredients:
s:560:"
  • 1 teaspoon sea salt
  • ½ teaspoon ground cumin
  • ½ teaspoon cayenne pepper
  • ¾ teaspoon ground cinnamon
  • 1 teaspoon dried and ground orange peel
  • 1 pound pecan halves
  • 4 tablespoons unsalted butter
  • 1/3 cup coconut sugar, packed
  • 2 tablespoons water
";
directions:
Mix the salt, cumin, cayenne, cinnamon, and orange peel in a small bowl, set aside.

Line a sheet pan with parchment.

Place the pecans in a heavy skillet over medium heat. Toast for about 5 minutes stirring frequently until they start to brown and smell toasted. Add in the butter and stir until melted. Add the spice mix and stir to coat evenly. Once coated, add the sugar and the water, stirring until the mix thickens and the nuts are coated.

Transfer to the sheet pan and spread out with a spoon and allow to cool completely before transferring to a container. These can be stored up to 3 weeks. That is if they last that long!

articleBodyHTML:
Inspired by Mexican street food, get your vegetarian on for this creamy, flavor filled street taco!

These little tortillas pack a little punch and are great on the go! If you’re a cheese lover, this one’s for you! You can spice it up with more heat or less heat - cheese it up with more or less - or potato it up with your taste preference - it’s all up to you! Great to cut up into several pieces for an appetizer, in half for the kids, or grab one just for yourself.
articleSummaryHTML: Inspired by Mexican street food, get your vegetarian on for this creamy, flavor filled street taco!
seoTitle: Sweet Potato Street Tacos
seoDescription: Inspired by Mexican street food, get your vegetarian on for this creamy, flavor filled street taco!
ingredients:
s:721:"
  • 2 med potatoes (I used 1 Japanese sweet potato and 1 baking potato, but feel free to use whatever potato you like)
  • 1 ½ cups of chihuahua Mexican cheese (or shredded vegan cheese)
  • ½ cup pepper jack cheese (or shredded vegan cheese)
  • 1 poblano pepper
  • 2 tablespoons salsa + extra for dipping (preference)
  • Pinch of sea salt and pepper
  • 5 small white corn tortillas
  • Dash of nut milk (if you desire)
  • Cooking spray
";
directions:
Bring water to a boil, peel (if you like) and cut potatoes into small pieces and cook in the boiling water and cook until tender.

While the potatoes are cooking roast your poblano pepper. This is a crucial step that you don’t want to miss! It adds so much more depth to the flavor of this dish. I put mine in the toaster oven at 400 degrees and turned as each side cooked and charred. This process is usually complete by the time the potatoes are done cooking. Remove from cooking source and let cool slightly, peel off skin, and cut into thin slices.

Drain tender potatoes and place into a medium-sized mixing bowl. Mash potatoes and slightly let cool. When slightly cooled, add cheeses, salt, and pepper, sliced up poblano pepper, salsa. You may add a dash of milk if you want, but you want the mixture to be firm. The cheese and salsa are usually enough. Set aside, do not mix together yet.

Heat a large skillet on the stove over med heat, lay tortilla flat and slightly warm up. Just enough that they bend easily (usually a minute or so).

With clean hands mix up potato mixture, that’s right, with your hands! Mix until really mashed together!

Add enough mixture into each tortilla shell to make your taco! Fold over and in the newly sprayed pan, add the taco to the pan and let it cook until slightly golden on each side. The cheese will melt, and you will be left with a yummy, crunch of goodness!

articleBodyHTML:
It’s dinnertime. Again. What are you going to have? Don’t know? We got you covered with this yum bowl because whatever dinner is, it ought to be YUM!

What do you get when you throw a heaping helping of rice in a fancy bowl, and add all your favorite fixins? You get a yum bowl! That’s right, a yum bowl. And how can you wrong eating anything called a yum bowl?
articleSummaryHTML: It’s dinnertime. Again. What are you going to have? Don’t know? We got you covered with this yum bowl because whatever dinner is, it ought to be YUM!
seoTitle: Rice Yum Bowl
seoDescription: It’s dinnertime. Again. What are you going to have? Don’t know? We got you covered with this yum bowl because whatever dinner is, it ought to be YUM!
ingredients:
s:577:"
  • ½ cup rice
  • 1 cup water
  • 1 tablespoon oil
  • ¾ cup white onion
  • 1 cup shredded carrots
  • 1 can black beans
  • ½ head broccoli
  • 2 teaspoons curry powder
  • ¼ cup vegan sour cream
  • 1 cup hummus
  • Avocado
";
directions:
Begin by cooking up a big ole bowl (or half a cup) of your favorite rice – brown, white, short grain, long grain, we don’t judge. You probably know how to cook rice, but in case you don’t, we’ve included the instructions in the video. While the rice is cooking to your liking, add a bit of oil to a sauté pan, and set pan on medium heat. To your pan, add white onion, shredded carrots, and sauté for about five minutes. Just get those onions looking nice and clear. Now throw in black beans and whatever else you can think of to make this bowl a colorful dish of nutrition. We added broccoli to get a little green in there, but use whatever you’d like. Keep on a low heat just long enough to get the beans and veggies nice and hot. In a separate small bowl, add a cup of your favorite hummus. And yes, there are tons of amazing options out there. Tomato basil, jalapeno, roasted red pepper, plain, whatever; the list goes on and on! Yes, hummus is that good. It pretty much deserves its own aisle in the grocery store.

To your hummus, add curry powder and sour cream. We used a fancy vegan sour cream, but work with what you got. Give that concoction a good stir then plop it on top of your rice.

Add your bean and veggie mixture then top it off with avocado. If you’d like to stare at this bowl of perfection, go right ahead. It’s a beauty to lay your eyes upon, but we assure you, it’s even more beautiful going down your gullet.

articleBodyHTML:
Here is something to feel grateful for this Thanksgiving season: amazing apple pie protein muffins!

Talia Pollock, vegan chef and the zany host of Party in My Plants, can pretty much guarantee that she has the power to transform you into a morning person with this recipe. If you’re already a morning person, that just means she’s already converted you preemptively. She’s that good. Her morning person apple pie protein muffins really put a pep in your pillow. Try saying that five times fast. Knowing you have one waiting for you after you hit snooze a couple times is enough to make even a morning hater happier with the sunrise. It’s time to get excited to be alive!

These are rich in plant protein. They’re dairy, gluten, and refined-sugar free. This makes them filling and easy to digest, a great combo. They taste like apple pie, which makes them worth waking up for. They’re also easy to make – always a bonus.
articleSummaryHTML: Here is something to feel grateful for this Thanksgiving season: amazing apple pie protein muffins!
seoTitle: Apple Pie Protein Muffins | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Here is something to feel grateful for this Thanksgiving season: amazing apple pie protein muffins!
ingredients:
s:947:"
  • 1 scoop Sunwarrior Warrior Blend vanilla
  • ½ cup oat flour
  • ½ cup chia seeds
  • 1 ½ teaspoons baking powder
  • ¼ teaspoon sea salt
  • ¼ cup raisins
  • ¼ cup walnuts
  • 2 teaspoons of cinnamon
  • ½ teaspoon allspice
  • ¼ teaspoon nutmeg
  • ¼ teaspoon ginger
  • 1/3 cup maple syrup
  • 1/3 cup+ 2 teaspoons almond milk
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla
  • Coconut oil
";
directions:
Start with vanilla Sunwarrior protein. Add oat flour, chia seeds, baking powder, sea salt, raisins, walnuts, cinnamon, allspice, nutmeg, and ginger. Phew! Mix all those together.

In a separate bowl, you’ll add wet ingredients. Pour in maple syrup, almond milk, and vanilla. Mix that and then mix it into the dry ingredients. Easy peasy apple muffin squeezy (but don’t squeeze them until they are done)! Stir in a chunked up apple. Pop the dough into muffin tins you’ve greased with coconut oil.

Place them in a 300 degree Fahrenheit preheated oven for 30 minutes. Enjoy the apple pie smell and eat it only once they’re cool enough to eat. Try them in your toaster too! Welcome to mornings!

articleBodyHTML:
Halloween is over. But it’s gifted you with leftover pumpkin! Not sure what to do with all that pumpkin puree awesomeness? How about adding it to you morning hot cereal!

Honestly, is there anything better than pumpkin? As soon as the first leaves turn color, people become pumpkin obsessed. And for good reason. Not only is pumpkin comforting and decadent, this seasonal superfood is actually a really healthy add-in.

Pumpkin is a great source of carotenoids, including beta-carotene. As with other orange-colored fruits and vegetables, pumpkin is rich in these antioxidants, which the body converts into Vitamin A. These nutrients help the body maintain healthy skin, keen vision, and a well-tuned heart. Carotenoids are also studied for their ability to prevent cancer.

The fibrous insides of a pumpkin make it stand to reason that pumpkin is also an excellent source of fiber. Foods high in fiber help us feel fuller for longer. Fiber also aids in weight loss, making recipes with added pumpkin (like this one) a healthy choice.

Pumpkin is loaded with potassium. For those who enjoy an active lifestyle, potassium helps the body recover after a workout. Potassium does this by balancing the body’s electrolytes and keeps muscles functioning properly. But even for those who don’t enjoy a healthy active lifestyle, everyone needs potassium. It’s essential for heart function, and adding potassium into the diet is associated with a reduced risk of stroke.

Creating your own pumpkin puree is ideal. But, canned pumpkin is a really great choice, too. Just make sure that you do not use a canned pumpkin pie mix, as this contains added preservatives and sugars.

This hot cereal breakfast gives you all the macro-nutrients you need. It has protein, courtesy of the Sunwarrior Warrior Blend protein. It contains carbohydrates, found in the steel cut oats. And it has healthy fats in the coconut oil.

It’s important to get an adequate amount of protein and carbohydrates, especially in the morning. To prevent fatigue, boost energy, and fuel our systems, our bodies need those macro-nutrients to get going in the morning.

Making this recipe ahead of time gives you one less thing to do on a busy morning. Such a great grab-and-go breakfast option!

The aroma of the spices makes this hot cereal extra comforting and particularly fall appropriate. The velvety texture feels like a custard or pie filling, but it is totally healthy.

So go ahead and jump on the pumpkin band-wagon!
articleSummaryHTML: Halloween is over. But it’s gifted you with leftover pumpkin! Not sure what to do with all that pumpkin puree awesomeness? How about adding it to you morning hot cereal!
seoTitle: Pumpkin Pie Protein Hot Cereal | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Halloween is over. But it’s gifted you with leftover pumpkin! Not sure what to do with all that pumpkin puree? Make this pumpkin pie protein hot cereal.
ingredients:
s:971:"
  • ¼ cup gluten free steel cut oats (you could easily use another grain like buckwheat groats)
  • 1 ½ cup water
  • 1 teaspoon coconut oil
  • Dash salt
  • ¼ cup canned pumpkin puree
  • 1 tablespoon maple syrup
  • ¼ teaspoon cinnamon
  • Dash of the following: ginger, allspice, cloves, nutmeg
  • ¼ teaspoon vanilla extract
  • 1 scoop Sunwarrior Warrior Blend vanilla protein
  • ½ cup unsweetened almond milk
  • Optional Toppings:
  • Chopped pecans
";
directions:
1. Bring water to a boil
  2. Add in steel cut oats, coconut oil and salt. *If using another grain, cook as instructed
  3. Reduce to simmer, uncovered for approximately 20 minutes
  4. In the last couple minutes of simmering, add in rest of ingredients
  5. Remove from heat and stir to fully incorporate everything together
  6. Serve immediately. Refrigerates for up to one week

articleBodyHTML:
If breakfast is the most important meal of the day, then it should be the best, the most awesome . . . it should be blue cornmeal pancakes!

The best mornings consist of a nice cup of brewed tea or coffee and a super star breakfast. Muffins, cereals, and yogurt are awesome choices, but pancakes are even better. Corn meal pancakes are absolutely delicious and gluten free. Pancakes should be fluffy, light, and flavorful. These pancakes are all of the above. These blue pancakes are a delightful spin on the usual classic with more flavors and texture that will leave you wanting seconds!

Cornbread is one of the best comfort foods, but it doesn’t need to be unhealthy. These corn pancakes are a great twist on the classic flavors of cornbread. Cornmeal is corn that has been ground up to create a flour-like consistency. Cornmeal contains a large amount of unsaturated fats and fiber. I used blue cornmeal in this recipe. Corn has gotten a bad reputation over the years. Most of the corn used in North America is highly refined, processed, and is genetically modified. Unlike its yellow counterpart, blue corn meal is easier to find in a non GMO version, especially if you’re looking in your local health food store.

One of the best reasons to use blue corn meal is its anti-cancer properties. Just like blackberries and blueberries, blue corn meal contains a high amount of antioxidants. Blue corn also has a slower rate of starch digestion which leads to a lower spike in your glycemic index. This means that you will stay full longer and won’t gain excess pounds due to high spikes in your sugar levels (such as happens with yellow corn).

Pancakes don’t need to be limited to breakfast. They are awesome as lunch or even dinner! Pair these up with fresh syrup such as maple, honey, or brown rice syrup. Add nuts or seeds and fruit. Be creative with your pancakes and craft a masterpiece with your favorite flavors and toppings.
articleSummaryHTML: If breakfast is the most important meal of the day, then it should be the best, the most awesome . . . it should be blue cornmeal pancakes!
seoTitle: Blue Cornmeal Pancakes
seoDescription: If breakfast is the most important meal of the day, then it should be the best, the most awesome . . . it should be blue cornmeal pancakes!
ingredients:
s:479:"
  • 1 cup blue corn meal
  • ½ cup gluten free flour (or spelt flour if not gluten free)
  • 2 teaspoons baking powder
  • 2 tablespoons unsweetened apple sauce
  • 1 teaspoon Himalayan salt
  • 1 cup vanilla unsweetened almond milk
  • 2 tablespoons coconut oil
";
directions:
Combine all dry ingredients together

Add all wet ingredients to dry ingredients (apple sauce, almond milk and coconut oil). Let this sit for 10 minutes to thicken

Preheat a pan with 1 tablespoon of coconut oil on medium heat. Scoop out dollops of batter onto pan and cook for 3 minutes each side. When you see bubbles appearing on one side, flip them over and cook for another 2 minutes

Serve with fruit, syrup, or nuts

articleTitle: Gluten Free, Vegan Pumpkin Protein No-Bake Cheesecake
articleBodyHTML:
It’s the holidays! Celebrate with a healthy choice, the kind you don’t have to tell anyone about. This no-bake cheesecake is so good, no one will guess it’s hiding a cornucopia of health benefits!

Pumpkin Cheesecake is a staple in most households around the holidays. You will save some valuable time and room in your oven on a busy day of cooking and baking with this no-bake alternative. One bowl, a food processor, and some refrigerator and freezer space is all you need to make this healthy dessert.

To avoid putting on unwanted weight during the holidays, it is important to make smart choices whenever possible. With this Pumpkin Protein No Bake Cheesecake, you are not sacrificing taste or texture whatsoever. But, you are enjoying some added protein, healthy fats, and vegetables. Plus, this recipe is naturally sweetened.

The graham cracker crust is a combination of almonds and old fashioned rolled oats. It crumbles just like a traditional graham cracker crust, without all the processed yucky stuff. This crust can easily be made ahead and kept in the fridge for a few days until you are ready to make the filling. {9kucur9p}

The filling is everything you would expect in a cheesecake: pillowy-soft texture, and the creaminess comes straight from the pumpkin’s mouth (you know, if it was a jack o lantern first). The Sunwarrior protein helps hold the filling together, which gives you a nice firm slice after chilling in the fridge.

You could even serve the filling all by itself in individual dessert cups. It’s that good! This would also be a great gift to bring over as a guest to any holiday party. Or, serve it at your own table and be the all-star hostess! Pumpkin cheesecake is festive, and this recipe comes just in time for the season!

Makes 2 six inch pies, or 1 eight inch pan
articleSummaryHTML: It’s the holidays! Celebrate with a healthy choice, the kind you don’t have to tell anyone about. This no-bake cheesecake is so good, no one will guess it’s hiding a cornucopia of health benefits!
seoTitle: Gluten Free Vegan Pumpkin Protein No-Bake Cheesecake
seoDescription: It’s the holidays! Celebrate with a healthy choice, the kind you don’t have to tell anyone about. This no-bake vegan pumpkin protein cheesecake is so good.
recipeName: Gluten Free, Vegan Pumpkin Protein No-Bake Cheesecake
ingredients:
s:1569:"
  • Crust
  • ½ cup old fashioned rolled oats (gluten free)
  • ½ cup raw almonds
  • 1 tablespoon coconut sugar
  • 2 ½ tablespoons coconut oil, liquefied
  • ¼ teaspoon cinnamon
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
  • 1 teaspoon maple syrup (or liquid sweetener of choice)
  • Cream Cheese
  • 1 ½ cup cashews (soaked for at least 4 hours)
  • 3 tablespoons lemon juice
  • 2 tablespoons almond milk, unsweetened
  • 6 tablespoons maple syrup
  • 2 teaspoons vanilla extract
  • Pumpkin Filling
  • 2 tablespoons maple syrup (or liquid sweetener of choice)
  • 2 tablespoons coconut oil, liquified
  • 1 cup pumpkin puree *see note below
  • 2 scoops Sunwarrior Warrior Blend Vanilla protein
  • 2 teaspoons cinnamon
  • Dash of the following spices (allspice, cloves, ground ginger, nutmeg)
";
directions:
1. Place all crust ingredients into a food processor and blend until a fine meal is created. When pressed, the crust should hold together
  2. Lightly oil pie pan(s) with coconut oil
  3. Divide the crust between the two pie pans. Press dough firmly around the pie pan. The crust should be approximately 1/4” thick
  4. Wipe the food processor clean, and place all cream cheese ingredients into the food processor, or high-speed blender
  5. Blend on high until a smooth, creamy consistency is achieved
  6. Add all pumpkin ingredients to the cream cheese. Blend until a smooth, creamy texture is achieved
  7. Divide batter between two pie pans, pour over crust
  8. Smooth over the top with a spoon
  9. Refrigerate for two hours, then pop in the freezer for two hours
  10. Serve and enjoy!
  11. *Note: I have made this with roasted butternut squash with very similar results. Feel free to use roasted squash if you do not have pumpkin puree on hand.

articleBodyHTML:
Ever had a BLT sandwich vegan style? (Which, of course, means IN style!) Then have we got some tasty happiness waiting for you!

This recipe was inspired from one of my favorite vegan bakeries in Toronto. I decided to experiment and see if I could replicate the taste and flavor myself using a few simple ingredients that I found in the health food store. The “B” or “bacon” flavor in this recipe comes from the smoked coconut chips. The bakery smokes their own coconut chips, and since I have no smoker, I found these wonderful BBQ coconut chips in the health food store that I think compare to the real thing. This recipe is very simple since all the ingredients, minus the vegan mayonnaise, requires zero preparation time. Well maybe besides washing and slicing the vegetables (“L – Lettuce” & “T – Tomato”).

I bought a small loaf of the bakeries gluten-free bread which they make in-house and is truly delicious. However any gluten-free sliced bread will do.  The vegan mayonnaise is not the true version that the bakery makes so I had to improvise, seeing that I don’t know the recipe for their secret mayo sauce.  Equally as tasty is my version below. If you don’t have time to make a batch, you can purchase one from the health food store and use that instead.

This recipe will pleasantly surprise any “real” BLT lover.  Give it a try and see for yourself.
articleSummaryHTML: Ever had a BLT sandwich vegan style (which of course mean IN style!)? Then have we got some tasty happiness waiting for you!
seoTitle: BLT Sandwich Vegan Style
seoDescription: Ever had a BLT sandwich vegan style (which of course mean IN style!)? Then have we got some tasty happiness waiting for you!
ingredients:
s:973:"

Sandwich

  • 2 slices of gluten-free bread
  • 1 tomato
  • 1 romaine lettuce leaf
  • 1 cup BBQ coconut chips
  • Vegan mayonnaise (see recipe below)

Vegan Mayonnaise

  • ½ cup unsweetened coconut milk
  • 1 cup sunflower oil
  • ½ teaspoon dry mustard powder
  • ½ teaspoon apple cider vinegar or coconut vinegar
  • ½ teaspoon raw agave nectar or coconut nectar
  • 1 teaspoon sea salt
  • 2 teaspoon freshly squeezed lemon juice
  • 1–2 garlic cloves minced.
";
directions:
1. Combine all the ingredients for the vegan mayonnaise into a blender and blend until thick and smooth. Set this aside until you need it.
  2. Cut the tomato into slices, set aside.
  3. Shred lettuce into large pieces (large enough to fit on top of the sliced bread).
  4. Spread vegan mayonnaise on both slices of gluten-free bread; add the BBQ coconut chips on one of the slices of bread, top with lettuce and tomato. Finish off by adding the second slice of bread on top.
  5. Garnish with a pickle on the side.

If you’re looking for a festive way to bring protein into your holiday we’ve got you covered with this protein pumpkin pie!

articleBodyHTML:
If you haven’t tried cauliflower as a potato alternative, it’s time. This holiday season, consider a nutritious twist to the time-tested potato dish: Cauliflower Mash.

Really. If you make this Cauliflower mash and top it off with Mushroom Gravy, you’ll have yourself a new tradition!

Cauliflower contains about 28 calories and 5 carbohydrates per serving compared to over 100 calories and 20 carbs in potatoes. Plus, you get to sneak another serving of veggies into your meal. What could be more beneficial?

Macadamia nuts can be on the expensive side, but trust me—the creamy nuttiness of macadamias bring this dish from good to WOW and are so worth the splurge. If your wallet is hurting too much from all that holiday gift shopping, feel free to sub in cashews or pine nuts for up to one third of the nuts in the recipe. You’ll want to be sure to taste and adjust the finished dish to bring out your favorite mashed potato flavor. Prepare by having a little extra garlic, salt and pepper on hand in case you need to do your own tweaking.

Be advised that these “potatoes” do not keep well. They are fabulous when made fresh, but are not nearly as tasty as leftovers. Just like Grandma always insisted, you’ll have to finish them off before you leave the table!
articleSummaryHTML: If you haven’t tried cauliflower as a potato alternative, it’s time. This holiday season, consider a nutritious twist to the time-tested potato dish: Cauliflower Mash.
seoTitle: Cauliflower Mash and Mushroom Gravy | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: If you haven’t tried cauliflower as a potato alternative, it’s time. This holiday season, try Sunwarrior's favorite cauliflower mash and mushroom gravy.
ingredients:
s:1494:"

Cauliflower Mash

  • 3 cups cauliflower, cut into small pieces
  • 1 cup macadamia nuts, soaked
  • ¼ cup lemon juice
  • ¼ cup water
  • 1 ½ teaspoons kelp flakes or granules
  • ¼ tablespoon unrefined salt
  • 1 ½ teaspoons garlic, minced

Mushroom Gravy

Yield: 2 1/2 cups

  • ½ cup coconut water
  • ½ cup purified water
  • 1 ½ cups mushrooms (Portobello, porcini or white)
  • ¼ cup tahini
  • 4 cloves garlic, peeled
  • 2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice
  • 1 tablespoon soy sauce
  • 1 tablespoon   light miso
  • 1/3 cup celery, chopped
  • ½ carrot, chopped
  • 2 tablespoons yellow onion, chopped
  • ¼ red bell pepper
  • ¾ teaspoon poultry seasoning
  • ¼ teaspoon sea salt
";
directions:
Cauliflower Mash

Put macadamia nuts into a food processor with the S blade. Pulse briefly to slightly break up the nuts. Add the rest of the ingredients and process until the mixture looks and fluffs like mashed potatoes.

Mushroom Gravy

Blend gravy ingredients until creamy and smooth, adding water as needed.

Serve with Cauliflower Mash.

articleBodyHTML:
Pumpkin—the only food worthy of magical carriage material is here for you enchanting your bread into something to be thankful for this Thanksgiving!

Pumpkin spice lattes, pumpkin candles, pumpkin rolls, pumpkin pie, pumpkin carving, pumpkin ravioli… It may be a bit past October, but that doesn’t mean pumpkin season is over! I am one of those obnoxious pumpkin fanatics. For me, I would be happy with pumpkin flavor being put into every-day use, like vanilla or strawberry or banana. Not only does pumpkin taste great, but it is so good for your body! It has very high amount of our necessary vitamins and minerals, including vitamin A which is essential for eyesight! It is a low calorie source of beneficial fiber, high antioxidants content (like beta-carotene) to help prevent cancer and to slow aging, and has high potassium, and vitamin C to boost your immune system before winter cold/flu season comes around! {9kucur9p}
articleSummaryHTML: Pumpkin—the only food worthy of magical carriage material is here for you enchanting your bread into something to be thankful for this Thanksgiving!
seoTitle: Pumpkin Spice Protein Bread | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Pumpkin—the only food worthy of magical carriage material is here for you enchanting your bread into something to be thankful for this Thanksgiving!
ingredients:
s:908:"
  • 3 cups gluten-free flour
  • 7 tablespoons honey or maple syrup (*This is for the typical dense beer-bread taste. For sweeter palates, add a bit more)
  • 12 oz. pumpkin ale, or non-alcoholic ginger beer
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
  • ½ teaspoon nutmeg
  • ½ tablespoon pumpkin pie spice
  • ½ tablespoon cinnamon
  • ½ tablespoon baking powder
  • 5 scoops of Sunwarrior Classic Plus vanilla (or Natural) protein
  • ½ teaspoon salt
  • 1 ½ cups pumpkin puree
";
directions:
Cover inside of 9x5” bread pan with aluminum foil or parchment paper (or grease with butter or oil) and preheat oven to 375 degrees.

Sift all dry ingredients (salt, protein powder, flour, cinnamon, baking powder, pumpkin pie spice, nutmeg) together in one bowl. In another bowl mix honey, vanilla, pumpkin puree and then add to dry ingredients. Combine well. Then add ale very slowly, mixing as you pour!  If this mixture is too lumpy, you can use electric hand-beaters until it is smooth J

Bake for 60 minutes. Insert a toothpick in the middle and if it comes out clean, it’s ready! If not, add aluminum foil to cover top of bread pan and cook for another 30 minutes or until toothpick comes out clean!

**Baking tip- whenever you are baking breads (or even casseroles) and the top is getting too hard but the middle isn’t cooked enough- adding aluminum foil to cover it keeps the heat in to cook more thoroughly instead of making the top and edges too hard!  Also remember with the added pumpkin, the bread is going to be a bit moister than regular bread!

articleBodyHTML:
Soaking! It makes breakfast a smooth transition to your day. And these overnight oats are just what breakfast has been asking for.

One of my favorite things about eating raw vegan food is its texture. It’s soft, easily digested, tastes great, and absolutely nutritious. Having your breakfast ready even before you are up is a gift. Hence, the art of soaking.

Having your grains, nuts, and seeds soaked overnight is not just convenience, but helps to remove the chemicals and harsh starchy layer around it and changes the chemical composition by giving it more of a protein content than a starchy carbohydrate load. Here are some recipes to get you excited for breakfast and will make you love soaking even more!
articleSummaryHTML: Soaking! It makes breakfast a smooth transition to your day. And these overnight oats are just what breakfast has been asking for.
seoTitle: Overnight Oats
seoDescription: Soaking! It makes breakfast a smooth transition to your day. And these overnight oats are just what breakfast has been asking for.
ingredients:
s:1743:"

Peanut Butter Oats

½ cup rolled oats

1 cup nut milk

1 tablespoon coconut sugar

1 tablespoon peanut butter

1 scoop Sunwarrior Classic Plus protein

Berry Coconut Oats

½ cup oats

1 cup coconut milk

¾ cup blueberries

1 tablespoon coconut butter

1 teaspoon maple syrup

1 scoop Sunwarrior Classic Plus protein

Cinnamon Chai Oats

½ cup oats

1 cup coconut milk

1 teaspoon cinnamon powder

1 teaspoon cardamom powder

½ teaspoon ginger powder

1 teaspoon maple syrup

1 scoop Sunwarrior Classic Plus protein

Mint Milkshake Oats

½ cup rolled oats

¾ cup coconut milk ice cream (vanilla)

2–3 fresh mint leaves

1 banana

1 scoop Sunwarrior Classic Plus protein

";
directions:
In a jar, mix all ingredients and let it sit in the fridge overnight.

Add some fruits as a topping, the next day and give it a quick stir if needed.

Feel free to get adventurous and try different flavors of Sunwarrior protein!

Eat right. Stay active. Live happy!

articleBodyHTML:
Fall is here, and so is the fresh tastes and aromas of all the yumminess fall offers. Apple Cinnamon Overnight Oats will put the awesome back into breakfast!

Healthinista, Marzia Prince, is back in the kitchen, whipping up something that those taste buds will go wild for – Apple Cinnamon Overnight Oats.

Overnight oats have come to be a staple in many fridges, so why not jump on board, and make some? Overnight oats are fast and healthy and can be made to order. They just require a little pre-morning preparation.
articleSummaryHTML: Fall is here, and so is the fresh tastes and aromas of all the yumminess fall offers. Apple Cinnamon Overnight Oats will put the awesome back into breakfast!
seoTitle: Apple Cinnamon Overnight Oats | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Fall is here, & so is the fresh tastes and aromas of all the yumminess fall offers. Apple Cinnamon Overnight Oats will put the awesome back into breakfast!
ingredients:
s:397:"
  • ½ cup oats
  • 1 scoop Sunwarrior illumin8
  • 1 chopped apple
  • ¼ cup raisins
  • Dash cinnamon
  • 1 cup almond milk
";
directions: Start by grabbing a jar and adding half of all the ingredients in this order: oats, Sunwarrior illumin8 meal replacement powder, chopped apple, raisins, and a dash of cinnamon, then repeat the whole process with the other half. Add almond milk, screw on the lid, and give it a good shake. Now let this little autumn masterpiece sit overnight in your fridge. Wake up refreshed or groggy (we don’t judge), open your fridge, pull out your overnight oats, give it a good stir, and eat! All your favorite fall flavors (unless pumpkin is your favorite fall flavor) come together to make these overnight oats a sweet morning hit.

articleBodyHTML:
Let’s be honest, pumpkin is the reason we love fall, okay that and crunchy leaves, but really. Pumpkin. These pumpkin muffins are everything we love about the season!

We certainly enjoy those baked goods, but sometimes they are not the healthiest. A lot of baked goods require excess oil or butter to make them moist, which isn’t always great for your heart. Pumpkin adds a lot of moisture and keeps baked goods from drying out. This recipe only uses healthy fats.

Another great thing about pumpkin is you can substitute it with basically any kind of squash. Some of our favorites are acorn and butternut squash. A lot of kids struggle with squash because of the texture, but if you have some lying around, you don’t want to waste it. So what do you do with it? Cook it in oven 350 degrees until tender at. Scoop out the squash and blend in blender or food processor until smooth. Add a tablespoon at a time if the squash is really thick. Then substitute for any recipe that calls for pumpkin. The kids will never know!

Pumpkins have a great deal of vitamin c that helps your vision. Like other squashes, pumpkin has the antioxidant beta-carotene which can help prevent cancer.

These pumpkin muffins are delicious. We enjoy them in the morning or for an anytime snack, and this recipe won’t make you feel guilty after you enjoy one.
articleSummaryHTML: Let’s be honest, pumpkin is the reason we love fall, okay that and crunchy leaves, but really. Pumpkin. These pumpkin muffins are everything we love about the season!
seoTitle: Pumpkin Muffins | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Let’s be honest, pumpkin is the reason we love fall, okay that and crunchy leaves. Sunwarrior's pumpkin muffins are everything we love about the season!
ingredients:
s:744:"
  • 1/3 cup melted coconut oil
  • ½ cup maple syrup or honey
  • 2 eggs or flax eggs
  • 1 cup pumpkin puree
  • ¼ cup milk of choice
  • 1 teaspoon baking soda
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
  • ½ teaspoon salt
  • 1 ½ teaspoon cinnamon or pumpkin pie spice
  • 1 ¾ cup whole wheat flour or gluten free all-purpose blend
  • 1/3 cup old fashioned oats (more for sprinkling, if desired)
";
directions:
Preheat oven to 325 degrees. Line muffin tins with paper liners then spray with coconut oil or spray muffin tins with coconut oil.

In a large bowl, mix flour, oats, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon (or pumpkin spice) with a whisk. In another bowl, combine coconut oil and syrup (or honey) with a whisk. Then add eggs (or flax eggs) and mix again until combined well. Mix in pumpkin, milk, and vanilla.

Pour batter into muffin tins ¾ full. Sprinkle extra oats on top if desired. Bake for 20 to 25 mins or until a toothpick inserted in center comes out clean. If using muffin liners, remove from pan and let cool on rack. If no muffin liners, let cool in muffin tins until mostly cool.

articleBodyHTML:
Pumpkin Spice and Everything Nice! Branch out your fruit leather flavors with pumpkin pie spice-y happiness!

Have you noticed? The pumpkin spice craze is still going strong—and major consumer-driven companies won’t let you forget! In addition to the seasonal lattes, there’s ice cream, donuts, cereal, beer, and even tortilla chips! Many of these concoctions don’t have a lick of pumpkin in them—so why do they taste so much like pumpkin? It’s the spice!

Like other spice blends (think curry, Chinese 5-spice and Herbes de Provence) pumpkin spice is an American blend commonly used in (you guessed it) pumpkin pie and is generally a mix of powdered cinnamon, cloves, nutmeg, ginger and, in some cases, allspice. Like many other blends, pumpkin spice may also be used in general cooking according to your preference.

Make your own pumpkin spice by starting with these measurements, and adjust to your personal taste and preference.
articleSummaryHTML: Pumpkin Spice and Everything Nice! Branch out your fruit leather flavors with pumpkin pie spice-y happiness!
seoTitle: Pumpkin Pie Leather
seoDescription: Pumpkin Spice and Everything Nice! Branch out your fruit leather flavors with pumpkin pie spice-y happiness!
ingredients:
s:595:"

Pumpkin Pie Spice

  • ½ teaspoon cinnamon
  • ¼ teaspoon ginger
  • 1/8 teaspoon nutmeg
  • Pinch clove

Pumpkin Pie Leather

  • 2 cups (16-ounce can) pumpkin puree (not pumpkin pie filling)
  • 1 cup full fat coconut milk
  • 3 apples, cored
  • ¼ cup honey (or agave syrup for our vegan friends)
  • ¼ cup shredded coconut, unsweetened
  • 1 teaspoon pumpkin pie spice (see above)
  • 2 tablespoons raisins
";
directions:
Puree all ingredients except raisins in a blender until smooth. Pulse raisins into mixture after tasting and adjusting as needed for desired flavor. Spread mixture evenly on a nonstick dehydrator sheet.

Dry eight hours at 105 degrees Fahrenheit. Remove nonstick sheets and flip the leather. Return leather to dehydrator until dry, approximately four more hours.

Pumpkin Pie Leather will keep for approximately one month wrapped in plastic and stored at room temperature.

articleTitle: Protein Packed Pumpkin Chocolate Chip Cookies
articleBodyHTML:
Making cookies like a boss! That’s what you can use as your social media update when you pimp out your pumpkin chocolate chip cookies with amazing protein!

seoDescription: Making cookies like a boss! That’s what you can use as your social media update when you pimp out your pumpkin chocolate chip cookies with amazing protein!

Heat the oven to 350°F. Spray the baking sheets with coconut oil or use a nonstick pan. Roll the dough into small balls (roughly the size of a tablespoon). Place each ball on the pan. Bake for 10–12 minutes, cool and enjoy!

seoTitle: Pumpkin Oatmeal | Sunwarrior Recipe

ingredients:
s:861:"

articleBodyHTML:
Hop into healthy holiday snacking with sweet roasted pumpkin seeds!

These roasted pumpkin seeds make the perfect snack around the holidays, even though they can be a staple year-round if you’re smart. Try a savory recipe for your summer road trip snack or something for your trail mix. But today we’re going with some of the sweet seasonings.

For those wanting to know the health benefits behind this recipe, pumpkin seeds are rich in protein, magnesium, zinc, and omega 3s to keep hearts healthy. They’ve also been linked to digestive health, anti-inflammatory effects, and restful sleep. This is one case where being kind to your body tastes amazing, too!
articleSummaryHTML: Hop into healthy holiday snacking with sweet roasted pumpkin seeds!
seoTitle: Roasted Pumpkin Seeds | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Hop into healthy holiday snacking with sweet roasted pumpkin seeds!
ingredients:
s:251:"
  • 1 ½ cup pumpkin seeds
  • 6 tablespoons maple syrup
  • ¼ teaspoon salt
  • ½ teaspoon pumpkin spice
";
directions:
Start with a cookie sheet. Spread out one and a half cups shelled pumpkin seeds. You can shell them yourself or buy them that way. Bake them for 45 minutes at 250 degrees Fahrenheit. Add them to a bowl so you can drizzle in six tablespoons of maple syrup. Sprinkle in one-fourth tablespoon salt and one-half tablespoon pumpkin spice. Stir the mixture before putting it back on the cookie sheet and into the oven for another 20 minutes. The seasonings will caramelize and crisp up perfectly. Enjoy the sweet, spicy, nutty deliciousness while you go about your holiday decorating!

articleBodyHTML:
Make the holidays awesome  with this pumpkin bread crumble that passes for bread, but tastes like dessert!

Want a delicious, crumbly, perfect-for-the-holidays pumpkin bread crumble? Then you have come to the right place. It’s easy to make and tastes like something between pumpkin bread and pumpkin chocolate chip cookies.
articleSummaryHTML: Make the holidays awesome  with this pumpkin bread crumble that passes for bread, but tastes like dessert!
seoTitle: Pumpkin Bread Crumble
seoDescription: Make the holidays awesome  with this pumpkin bread crumble that passes for bread, but tastes like dessert!
ingredients:
s:668:"
  • 2 ½ cup flour
  • 2 teaspoons baking powder
  • One teaspoon salt
  • Two teaspoons baking soda
  • 1 ½ vanilla Sunwarrior Classic Plus
  • 1 ½ cup chocolate chips
  • 1 ½ cup coconut oil
  • Water (as needed)
  • 15 ounces pumpkin puree
  • 4 tablespoons applesauce
";
directions: Start with your dry ingredients. Mix together two and a half cups flours, two teaspoons baking powder, one teaspoon salt, two teaspoons baking soda, and one and a half scoops of vanilla Classic Plus from Sunwarrior. Your wet ingredients include one and a half cups coconut oil, water (as needed), fifteen ounces of pumpkin puree, and four tablespoons applesauce. Add those to your mixed dry ingredients and stir them together. Fold in one and a half cup chocolate chips. Put your dough in a bread pan and bake it for 40 minutes at 400 degrees Fahrenheit. Let it cool, remove your crumble from the pan, and enjoy the taste of the season.

articleBodyHTML:
Eating your vegetables has never been so sweet! Bite into satisfaction by indulging in this zucchini blueberry cake.

These delicious cake bites are super easy to make. You can grab a piece on the go, enjoy one (or two) at breakfast, or jazz it up with some homemade blueberry compote and serve warm as a dessert. The zucchini and blueberry keep these bites nice and moist, but feel free to enjoy whatever berries you have on hand. You won’t be disappointed! Enjoy this treat!
articleSummaryHTML: Eating your vegetables has never been so sweet! Bite into satisfaction by indulging in this zucchini blueberry cake.
seoTitle: Zucchini Blueberry Cake | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Eating your vegetables has never been so sweet! Bite into satisfaction by indulging in this zucchini blueberry cake.
ingredients:
s:802:"
  • 2 cups flour
  • ½ cup coconut sugar
  • 2 ½ teaspoon baking powder
  • ¾ cup almond milk
  • 2 tablespoon agave
  • ¼ cup oil
  • 3 tablespoon lemon juice
  • 2 tablespoon unsweetened apple sauce
  • 1 tablespoon lemon zest
  • ½ teaspoon salt
  • 1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
  • 1 teaspoon allspice
  • 1 cup blueberries
  • 1 small zucchini, shredded
";
directions:
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees (convection bake 325 degrees)
  2. Lightly spray medium glass baking dish with oil.
  3. In a large bowl gently whisk the almond milk, lemon juice, agave, and zest.
  4. Add oil, vanilla, applesauce into the milk mixture and whisk until all incorporated.
  5. In a sifter add all remaining dry ingredients and sift into large bowl containing wet ingredients.
  6. Stir together to make a nice heavy batter.
  7. Sprinkle a teaspoon of flour to lightly coat the blueberries and shredded zucchini. Stir gently into batter until incorporated.
  8. Gently pour into baking dish and bake for approximately 20-25 minutes or done.
  9. Nothing beats a versatile recipe that will become a favorite any day of the year!

articleBodyHTML:
Use your noggin—skip the eggs! Celebrate your festivities with eggless eggnog for a sweet, smooth beverage that lets health and happiness hang out together!

The creamy holiday drink known as eggnog can be rather polarizing: people tend to love the taste or hate it. Around here, we love it—especially when the classic ingredients are swapped out for healthier ones.

Traditionally, eggnog is made with milk, sugar, and real eggs—some recipes do indeed specify raw—but we’re changing it up to make a vegan version. If you love the creamy richness of eggnog, but don’t care to use animal product ingredients, we’ve got your homemade solution below. The base mixture is a luscious combination of young coconut meat, almonds, pine nuts and chia seeds to create that thickness that’s characteristic of true eggnog. Next, the inclusion of both Medjool dates and maple syrup add a layered, rich sweetness—so you won’t miss the table sugar. Finish off the drink with a little cinnamon, and of course nutmeg, for authentic flavor. (Wanna know the secret to great eggnog? Only use nutmeg that you grate yourself right before you use it!) {9kucur9p}

Eggless Nog takes no more than a few minutes to whip up, and this recipe makes four servings. If you prefer yours warm, heat it gently on the stove before serving. For extra heat, splash with your choice of rum, brandy, or bourbon. Just use your noggin and don’t drive!
articleSummaryHTML: Use your noggin—skip the eggs! Celebrate your festivities with eggless eggnog for a sweet, smooth beverage that lets health and happiness hang out together!
seoTitle: How to Make Vegan Eggless Nog | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Use your noggin—skip the eggs! Celebrate your festivities with vegan eggless eggnog for a sweet, smooth beverage that is delicious any time of the year.
ingredients:
s:664:"
  • 1 young coconut: meat and water
  • ½ cup raw almonds
  • ¼ cup pine nuts
  • 3 Medjool dates, pitted
  • 3 tablespoons  maple syrup
  • 1 ½ teaspoons cinnamon
  • ¼–½ teaspoon nutmeg, freshly ground
  • ½ teaspoon vanilla extract
  • 3 cups water (use coconut water or purified water)
  • 1 tablespoon chia seeds
";
directions:
Blend all ingredients in a high-speed blender and strain liquid through nut milk bag or cheesecloth. Serve chilled, and garnish with a sprinkle of cinnamon.

articleBodyHTML:
Looking for a way to jazz up some olives on your holiday table? This recipe will delight with a combination of tart and sweet flavors and bring on that holiday cheer!

The infusion of ingredients slightly encompass the warmth of the olives and bring a little holiday cheer. A modern twist on the ordinary olive is a great addition to any appetizer table.
articleSummaryHTML: Looking for a way to jazz up some olives on your holiday table? This recipe will delight with a combination of tart and sweet flavors and bring on that holiday cheer!
seoTitle: Warm Holiday Olives | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Looking for a way to jazz up some olives on your holiday table? Sunwarrior's warm holiday olives will delight with a combination of tart and sweet flavors.
ingredients:
s:680:"
  • ¾ cup of a combination of olives
  • 1 tablespoon olive oil
  • ¼ cup sun-dried tomato, diced
  • ¼ cup marinated roasted red pepper, diced
  • ¼ cup fresh cranberries
  • 2 tablespoons fresh squeezed orange juice
  • 1 teaspoon orange zest
  • 1 teaspoon lemon zest
  • 1 teaspoon thyme (or more per taste preference) fresh or dried
  • 1 teaspoon honey
";
directions:
In a small saucepan, heat olive oil on medium temperature. Add sun-dried tomato and red pepper. When heated, add thyme and olives. Once heated, add orange juice and zest. Stir and add honey. Feel free to add in some slices of orange, too, if you want to kick up the citrus.  Combine together. Serve warm.

articleBodyHTML:
Lunchboxes are calling. Office snacks need attention. Don’t let yourself or your little ones go hungry or reach for less healthy options. How about a PB&J in a bite-sized snack?

But really. Bite-sized PB&J! How does that sound? Pretty fantastic, huh? Talia Pollock, the energetic and charismatic host of Party in My Plants, is here to supply your nostalgic snacking needs! These easily pop into a lunchbox, briefcase, or purse to bring to school, work, or both if you are one of those overachiever types or a teacher. This recipe is for anyone who loves this childhood favorite.
articleSummaryHTML: Lunchboxes are calling. Office snacks need attention. Don’t let yourself or your little ones go hungry or reach for less healthy options. How about a PB&J in a bite-sized snack?
seoTitle: PB&J Protein Balls | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Lunchboxes are calling. Office snacks need attention. Don’t let yourself or your little ones go hungry try these PB & J protein balls from Sunwarrior.
ingredients:
s:440:"
  • 1 cup pitted dates
  • 1/3 cup peanut butter(or your favorite nut butter)
  • ½ cup rolled oats
  • 1 scoop Sunwarrior’s vanilla Classic Plus protein
  • 1–2 tablespoons water (if needed)
";
directions: Dump one cup of pitted dates into your food processor. Add a third cup of peanut butter (or your favorite nut butter here), half a cup of rolled oats, and one gorgeous scoop of Sunwarrior’s vanilla Classic Plus protein powder. Process away! If it stays too crumby, add in a tablespoon or two of water to moisten it all up. You want it rollable. Reach in with clean hands, avoiding the blades of course, and roll up your snack balls. Make them the size that works for you, small and bite-sized, or larger and more filling. Stick them in the fridge to await their journey to a lunch near you. Enjoy!

articleBodyHTML:
Apple pie doesn’t just have to revolve around the holidays. But since the holidays are here . . . we have an apple pie smoothie for you!

You can make an apple pie smoothie any time of the year, any season, any day, and any hour you like. If you’re someone who loves apple pie, there’s no reason not to extend your enjoyment beyond special occasions. Talia Pollock, the energetic and zany host of Party in My Plants is talking about transforming one of your favorite desserts into a much easier to manage smoothie, so you can grab a jar and go, rather than bake, slice, or unbutton anything in the process. {9kucur9p}
articleSummaryHTML: Apple pie doesn’t just have to revolve around the holidays. But since the holidays are here . . . we have an apple pie smoothie for you!
seoTitle: Apple Pie Protein Smoothie | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Apple pie doesn’t just have to revolve around the holidays. But since the holidays are here . . . we have an apple pie smoothie for you!
ingredients:
s:498:"
  • 1 chopped apple (cored)
  • Handful spinach
  • 1 scoop Sunwarrior’s vanilla Classic Plus protein
  • 1/3 cup rolled oats
  • 1 teaspoon cinnamon
  • 1/8 teaspoon nutmeg
  • ¼ teaspoon cloves
  • ¼ teaspoon ginger
  • 1 tablespoon nut butter
  • ¾ cup almond milk
  • Ice (if you want it really cold)
";
directions:
This smoothie is the healthiest and smartest way to enjoy the essence of apple pie in the form of a green protein smoothie. Start with a blender. Toss in one chopped apple. Don’t forget to remove the core. Add a handful of spinach, a scoop of vanilla Sunwarrior protein (your choice of Classic, Warrior Blend, Classic Plus, or even illumin8), a third cup of rolled oats, one teaspoon of cinnamon, one-eighth teaspoon of nutmeg, one-fourth teaspoon of cloves, one-fourth teaspoon of ginger, one tablespoon of nut butter (your fave), and three-quarters cup of almond milk. Add ice if you really want your apple pie smoothie chilled. Blend away. Pour in a jar and enjoy!

articleBodyHTML:
These cookies are nutritious enough to have for breakfast or to be finished off after a delightful meal. Pumpkin spice is the flavor profile of holiday weather.

Believe it or not, these pumpkin oatmeal cookies are vegan, gluten-free, and absolutely delicious. Using a combination of gluten free oats and gluten free oat flour (which can be made by placing your oats in a food processor and blending until it turns into flour), these cookies come together in a delicious masterpiece of joy. Oats are one of the healthiest foods on this planet. Oats can be a perfect way to kick start the day or to made into cookies and bars. Oat flour is a great way to create healthy treats. Oat flour has a delicious nutty flavor but boasts an array of nutritional value that traditional flour lacks. Oat flour tends to be lighter and sweeter than refined white flour. Since we are using gluten free oats, this flour is gluten free which is easier for our digestive systems. Oats have a high fiber content which can help remove cholesterol from our digestive system that would have been in our bloodstream. Oats are a great way to stabilize blood sugar levels, therefore, people suffering from diabetes can benefit greatly.

Replacing oat flour in recipes is simple. For every 1 cup of wheat flour substitute it for 1 ½ cups of oat flour. Oat flour tends to make baked goods moister so adding more will level out the moisture in recipes. Oat flour is a great thickener for foods as well.

You can make a large batch of these cookies and store them in the fridge. They will keep up to four days.
articleSummaryHTML: These cookies are nutritious enough to have for breakfast or to be finished off after a delightful meal. Pumpkin spice is the flavor profile of holiday weather.
seoTitle: Pumpkin Spice Oatmeal Cherry Cookies | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: These cookies are nutritious enough to have for breakfast or to be finished off after a delightful meal. Pumpkin spice is the flavor profile of holidays.
ingredients:
s:664:"
  • 1 cup gluten free rolled oats
  • 1 cup gluten free oat flour**
  • ½ cup coconut sugar
  • 1 teaspoon baking soda
  • 2 tablespoons pumpkin spice mix
  • ½ teaspoon Himalayan salt
  • 1/3 cup maple syrup
  • 3 tablespoons nondairy milk
  • 3 tablespoons coconut oil
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
  • 2/3 cup dried cherries
";
directions:
1.) Preheat oven to 350 degrees

2.) Combine all ingredients dry ingredients together. Add wet ingredients and stir well. Stir in dried cherries

3.) Scoop out dough on to a parchment paper lined baking tray. Bake for 15–17 minutes. Let cool

articleBodyHTML:
Chocolate. It is its own magic. And chocolate pudding is the smoothest magic out there! And since even adults need magic in their lives, we bring you dairy free chocolate pudding!

Chocolate pudding is one of those super-nostalgic foods that we don’t typically eat often as adults. Now’s your chance to change that with a dairy-free version that will bring back pleasant memories of your childhood while not making you feel guilty about the indulgence. Some of the ingredients may surprise you, but don’t be afraid to give it a whirl.{9kucur9p}
articleSummaryHTML: Chocolate. It is its own magic. And chocolate pudding is the smoothest magic out there! And since even adults need magic in their lives, we bring you dairy free chocolate pudding!
seoTitle: Dairy Free Chocolate Pudding | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Chocolate. It is its own magic. And chocolate pudding is the smoothest magic out there! Try this amazing Sunwarrior dairy free chocolate pudding.
ingredients:
s:495:"
  • 2 avocados
  • ½ cup maple syrup
  • 1 scoop Sunwarrior Classic Plus chocolate
  • ½ teaspoon salt
  • ½ cup cacao powder
  • ½ teaspoon vanilla
  • ¼ cup coconut cream
";
directions:
Start with two avocados, pits and peels removed and discarded. Toss the avocados into a blender. Add one-half cup maple syrup (you could also use coconut nectar), one scoop Sunwarrior chocolate Classic Plus protein, one-half tablespoon sea salt, one-half cup cacao powder, one half tablespoon vanilla, and one-fourth cup coconut cream. Blend these all together. Pour your delicious childhood memories into a bowl. Garnish with shredded coconut, almond slivers, cherries, strawberries, bananas, quinoa puffs, and whatever else speaks to you at the moment. So many things pair well with chocolate that you may have a hard time deciding. Good luck and you’re welcome!

articleBodyHTML:
Warm up from the inside out with soup! Cozy up to this roasted red pepper soup, and let it warm you from your toes on up!

The weather outside may be dreary, but that doesn't mean your food has to be as well. Colder months can also mean lively, bright, hearty, and healthy food options. The best way to incorporate all of these key nutrients into your diet is soup. You can add an array of vegetables, herbs and spices to liven it up. Eating soup is a quick and hot meal that can be prepared in no time. When you make your own soup, you can gauge the amount of salt and fat you are adding to it. Store bought soups tend to be high in sodium which can leave us feeling lethargic and bloated.

The base of this soup is the humble red pepper. This mighty vegetable is used in salads and many dishes, but in a soup it comes alive! These peppers are roasted in the oven, and once they are done, cooking this recipe comes together in no time. Adding tahini will give this soup a nutty and earthy flavor. The best part about this recipe is that it can be used as a pasta sauce the following day. This makes a quick and simple dinner that will impress your family and guests.

Red peppers are nutritionally rich in so many nutrients and vitamins. Red peppers are very high in vitamin C that can help keep your immune system healthy and boost antioxidants in the body. During winter months, red peppers are an amazing way to heat our internal core. These crisp and vibrant vegetables activate thermogenesis in the body which can increase metabolism.

This recipe calls for Harissa which is a wonderful spice. If you cannot find it in the grocery store, just double the quantity of smoked paprika, or add cumin for extra flavor.
articleSummaryHTML: Warm up from the inside out with soup! Cozy up to this roasted red pepper soup, and let it warm you from your toes on up!
seoTitle: Roasted Red Pepper Soup
seoDescription: Warm up from the inside out with soup! Cozy up to this roasted red pepper soup, and let it warm you from your toes on up!
ingredients:
s:566:"
  • 1 small onion, diced
  • 2 gloves garlic, minced
  • 1 tablespoon olive oil
  • 5 roasted red peppers
  • 2 cups vegetable broth
  • 1/3 cup tahini
  • ½ tablespoon harissa
  • ¼ teaspoon smoked paprika
  • 1 teaspoon Himalayan salt
  • 1 teaspoon pepper
";
directions:
1.) Preheat oven to 400 degrees. Slice red peppers in half and place on a parchment-paper-lined baking tray. Drizzle with olive oil and bake for 20 minutes.

2.) In the meantime, preheat a pan with 1 tablespoon of olive oil and add onion. Cook until translucent (4–5 minutes) Add garlic. Add roasted red peppers, Harissa, salt, and pepper. Add vegetable broth and cook for 5 minutes.

3.) Place mixture into your high speed blender or food processor. Add tahini and blend until smooth. Carefully remove soup from your food processor and place soup into a pot. Heat for another 5 minutes and serve.

4.) Top with greens, nuts, seeds, or grains

Do-it-yourself nut butter! You can give it for holiday gifts or keep it all to yourself! Either way, nuttin’ is better than cinnamon superfood nut butter that you made yourself!

Nut butters are pretty fantastic to start with, making almost anything better, like bread, smoothies, celery, and even that well-washed finger, but Talia Pollock of Party in My Plants is taking nut butters to new heights. She’s whipping up nut butters with extra plant-based protein, extra flavor, and extra superpowers from superfoods. This Cinnamon Superfood Nut Butter is nuttin’ but superb! {9kucur9p}
articleSummaryHTML: Do it yourself nut butter! You can give it for holiday gifts or keep it all to yourself! Either way, nuttin’ is better than cinnamon superfood nut butter that you made yourself!
seoTitle: Cinnamon Superfood Nut Butter Recipe | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Do it yourself cinnamon superfood nut butter recipe from Sunwarrior Health Hub. Either way, nuttin’ is better than DIY cinnamon superfood nut butter.
ingredients:
s:596:"
  • 3 cups nuts
  • 2 tablespoons coconut sugar
  • 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon
  • ½ teaspoon sea salt
  • 2 tablespoons Sunwarrior’s Classic Plus vanilla protein (or vanilla bean illumin8 for extra flavor and superfoods)
  • 1 teaspoon maca powder
";
directions:
Start by placing three cups of nuts on a baking sheet. Go nuts with your favorite or combinations of favorites. Pop them into a preheated oven at 400 degrees Fahrenheit for roughly ten minutes until they are light brown and smell amazing. Add them while still warm and toasty to your food processor, along with two tablespoons of coconut sugar, one teaspoon of ground cinnamon, half a teaspoon of sea salt, two tablespoons of Sunwarrior’s Classic Plus vanilla protein (you can use vanilla bean illumin8 for extra flavor and superfoods too), and one teaspoon of maca powder. Maca is great for the adrenals, energy, recovery, and more! Look it up!

Process your nuts. You’ll need to be patient because this will take about twelve minutes. You may need to stop it a couple times to scrape down the sides, but keep going. It will go from crumbly to doughy to smooth and buttery. Yep, that’s real nut butter that you just made in your own house with ingredients you know and understand. Put it in a jar and store your nut butter in the fridge. Yum!

articleBodyHTML:
Eggnog, with a shake-up and re-imagination, can be amazing, creamy, and vegan. This nutnog is the best thing to happen to Christmas since the guy in red discovered chimneys!

A favorite classic treat over the holidays is a smooth, sweet, rich, and creamy glass of eggnog. Traditionally, made with milk or cream, sugar, whipped eggs and rum or bourbon is far from healthy. This healthier version has the same blend of spices as real eggnog. The young coconut replaces the eggs in the traditional recipe which helps to give it that thick and creamy constituency. Of course, turmeric is added to kick in that eggnog color.

This holiday nutnog is as sweet and rich tasting as real eggnog, without the added artery clogging components contained in most. It is so smooth and decadent you’ll fool yourself into thinking that is the real deal. Give the recipe below a try and prepare to impress your guests!
articleSummaryHTML: Eggnog, with a shake-up and re-imagination, can be amazing, creamy, and vegan. This nutnog is the best thing to happen to Christmas since the guy in red discovered chimneys!
seoTitle: Holiday Nutnog Recipe | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Eggnog, with a shake-up and re-imagination, can be amazing, creamy, and vegan. Try Sunwarrior's vegan holiday nutnog recipe. It is truly delicious.
ingredients:
s:861:"
  • 1–2 cups coconut milk
  • 1 teaspoon of cinnamon or 1 stick of cinnamon
  • ¼ teaspoon turmeric
  • ½ teaspoon clove powder or two whole cloves
  • ¼ teaspoon of cardamom powder or 2 crushed cardamom pods
  • 1 vanilla pod or vanilla extract
  • 1 cups raw cashews
  • 1 cup young coconut meat
  • 3 tablespoons maple syrup
  • 1 teaspoon chia seeds
  • 1 to 2 drops of DoTERRA On Guard essential oil blend
  • Dash of Himalayan salt
  • Dash of nutmeg
";
directions:
1. Soak cashews in filtered water for 30 minutes; drain.
  2. Place the coconut milk into a pot. Add the cinnamon, turmeric, clove, cardamom and vanilla bean, as well as the pod, into the milk. To maximize the vanilla bean, you want to cut the pod in half, lengthwise. Scrape out all of the oily seeds from the inside to use in the recipe. You will have flecks of vanilla throughout, which will infuse the milk with vanilla. Once cut, throw the whole pod and the oily seeds you scraped out earlier, into the coconut milk. The most efficient way to get the flavor from the vanilla is to add it to something warm, which helps to disperse the seeds and the oils. Mix the ingredients using a whisk.  Infuse the milk for 3 to 4 minutes of simmering.
  3. In a blender add the raw cashews, young coconut meat, maple syrup, chia seeds, salt, DoTERRA On Guard and the infused coconut milk (if you have added the spices whole make sure to strain the milk first). Blend for 30 to 60 seconds. Depending on the thickness you want, you can add a little bit of water if you find it too thick.
  4. Pour into a glass and sprinkle with some nutmeg.

Happy Holidays – Eat, Drink & be Merry!

What do you get when you cross peppermint with chocolate? Christmas! Nothing says festive more than these peppermint truffles!

The candy cane is a holiday classic and what better way to enjoy it than in kid or adult friendly truffles packed with superfoods. Heck, this recipe creation can create a power bar for athletes of all calibers.
