  • ¾ cup blueberries, blackberries, or raspberries
";
directions:
Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Rinse the two sweet potatoes, poke some holes in the potato, and cook for 1 hour until cooked and soft.

While the sweet potato is cooking, mix the honey with  Sunwarrior illumin8 vanilla. Once the sweet potato has cooked, peel back the skin and mash up the sweet potato into a fine mixture. Once you do that, then add the Sunwarrior illumin8 vanilla with the honey to the sweet potato mixture.  Whip it up until it is nice and smooth. Then top with the berries, add as many berries as you want. The more the better. You can either eat it right away or refrigerate and warm up for breakfast in the morning.

Enjoy!

articleBodyHTML:
For the love of cookies! Because we all love cookies! Especially the cookies that come packed with the health of protein and superfoods and come guilt-free for the win!

Who doesn’t love a home-baked treat that is both additively delicious as well as jam packed with nutrient power? Yes, even cookies can be nutritious. It’s all in what you use for ingredients. Ever so chocolate-y (made with great quality raw cacao powder), studded with crunch, and rich in so many good things: protein, fiber, quality carbs, and healthy fats makes this treat a home-run!
articleSummaryHTML: For the love of cookies! Because we all love cookies! Especially the cookies that come packed with the health of protein and superfoods and come guilt-free for the win!
seoTitle: Protein Power Cacao Crunch Cookies | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: For the love of cookies! Especially the cookies that come packed with the health of protein and superfoods and come guilt-free for the win!
ingredients:
s:1216:"
  • 1 cup organic oatmeal or quinoa flakes (gluten-free if needed)
  • ½ cup cacao powder, sifted
  • 1/3 cup Sunwarrior Warrior Blend protein, chocolate, vanilla, or mocha
  • ½ cup organic shredded coconut
  • 2 large really ripe bananas, mashed approximately 2 cups
  • ½ cup organic coconut or apple butter
  • 4 heaping tablespoons Sunbutter, creamy or crunchy, add a little more if needed
  • 2 tablespoons extra virgin coconut oil
  • 1 heaping tablespoon ground flax stirred into 3 tablespoons coconut water
  • 1/3 cup organic currants and ¼ cup cacao nibs
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla extract or vanilla powder and a pinch sea salt
";
directions:
1. Pre-heat the oven to 350F and cover a baking sheet with parchment paper.
  2. Combine all ingredients in a bowl, mixing well to create a sticky dough that holds together well. Adjust ingredient amounts if needed.
  3. Using a two-inch ice cream scoop drop dough onto your prepared sheet leaving 2 inches between each cookie, flatten into patties and bake approx. 20 minutes.
  4. Let cool completely on a rack then store in a covered container or freeze up to 1 month.

Teri’s Tips:

  1. If you intend to use these as a pre-workout fuel source, consider adding the espresso powder or matcha powder for added energy
  2. If your bananas aren’t really ripe, then consider adding a few tablespoon date, prune or more apple or coconut butter to taste. Some like it sweet! J
  3. Makes approximately 10–12 large ice cream scoop sized cookies

articleTitle: 9 Sneaky Ways to More Avocado! Plus Vegan Chocolate Avocado Pudding!
articleBodyHTML:
Getting avocado in your diet is easy! The avocado is so versatile, you can even hide it in pudding. Here are nine ways to sneak avocado in your diet, plus a recipe!

If avocado was a person, he would be “the man.” You know: the boss, the chief, the coolest dude of them all. Why? Because he gets along with anyone, and everyone just loves him. He doesn’t steal the show by being the life of the party, but he’s the kind of guy you always want around because he just makes every situation better.

But avocado actually isn’t a guy; it’s a fruit (a fruit?! Yeah, avocado's technically a fruit!). And because avocado is so awesome, I love to add it to just about everything!

Here's WHY:

  • Avos are filling! Their fat provides long-burning fuel which will keep you satiated longer which helps prevent you from binging on unhealthy stuff later.
  • Avocados are a good source of B3 which can help stabilize your blood sugar and keep you from craving and caving for sugary stuff.
  • Avocados contain a loooot of fiber which helps lubricate the digestive tract and keep you more “regular,” wink, wink.
  • Avocados have some of that tryptophan (you know, that stuff that makes you tired after eating the Thanksgiving turkey), which can encourage us to relax more by supporting the release of serotonin!
  • Avocados nourish and moisturize skin and help us maintain youthful and glowing spa-day-everyday skin. They also provide a solid source of silicon which can assist in anti-aging efforts.

Are you sold?! Yeah, hard not to be. Now, here are nine fantastic ways to sneak “the man” into all sorts of daily dishes.

  1. Spread avocado on toast in place of butter! (Add a sprinkle of salt or a drizzle of hot sauce.)
  2. Use avocado in sandwiches and wraps to healthfully replace the texture of mayo or cheese.
  3. Blend avocado into sauces, pestos or dressings to thicken them up without needed oils.
  4. Dice avocado and add it to salads for substance!
  5. Blend avocado into smoothies to up their creamy texture. (Great if you're avoiding sugar and don't want banana to be the texture-maker.)
  6. Roll avocado into sushi. (Or order an avocado veggie roll if you're out.)
  7. Mix avocado into dips to make them smoother and more filling.
  8. MAKE GUAC! (Ok, this is hardly "sneaking" avocado in, but I couldn't write about enjoying avocado without guacamole! This is my go-to guac recipe: http://www.partyinmyplants.com/perfect-guacamole/)
  9. Sneak avocado into homemade chocolate pudding! Seriously. You'll never know. Here's my recipe for creamy, dreamy chocolate avocado pudding:
articleSummaryHTML: Getting avocado in your diet is easy! The avocado is so versatile, you can even hide it in pudding. Here are nine ways to sneak avocado in your diet, plus a recipe!
seoTitle: 9 Ways to More Avocado! Plus Vegan Chocolate Avocado Pudding
seoDescription: Getting avocado in your diet is easy! The avocado is so versatile, you can even hide it in pudding. Here are nine ways to sneak avocado in your diet.
ingredients:
s:268:"
  • 1 ripe avocado, green flesh scooped out
  • ¼ cup cacao or cocoa powder
  • ¼ cup maple syrup
  • ¼ cup almond milk
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
  • ¼ teaspoon sea salt
";
directions:
1. Throw all the ingredients into a food processor or blender and process this bad boy until smooth. Scrape down the sides periodically to make sure every little bit of goodness gets included.
  2. Portion into two serving bowls and let ‘em chill out in the fridge for at least twenty minutes.
  3. Serve! And then drop your jaw in awe at how good this weird sounding dessert is!

articleTitle: Arame Citrus Salad with Pomegranate Dressing
articleBodyHTML:
This simple, elegant, salad is bursting with flavor and happiness. And flavor is what makes up this arame citrus salad with pomegranate dressing!

When it comes to salads, it’s about choosing seasonal ingredients that can upgrade your basic salad into something unique. I am always an advocate of adding color, texture and bold flavors to any salad. This particular salad recipe not only has a contrast of all the above but you are also getting your daily dose of nutrients. The oranges provide vitamin C, the arame provides iodine and other trace minerals, avocado gives the salad a boost of healthy fats, and the pomegranate juice is loaded with antioxidants. I’d say this is a salad worth making any time of year!

Arame is a sea vegetable that is loaded with calcium and other minerals such as magnesium, iron, and iodine. It is subtle, soft, and stringy and makes a wonderful condiment for soups, salads, stir-fry’s, sandwiches, or wraps.
articleSummaryHTML: This simple, elegant, salad is bursting with flavor and happiness. And flavor is what makes up this arame citrus salad with pomegranate dressing!
seoTitle: Arame Citrus Salad with Pomegranate Dressing | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: This simple, elegant, salad is bursting with flavor and happiness. And the flavor is what makes up this arame citrus salad with pomegranate dressing.
recipeName: Arame Citrus Salad with Pomegranate Dressing
ingredients:
s:821:"
  • ½ cup arame, soaked
  • ½ cup fresh orange juice
  • ¼ cup pure pomegranate juice
  • ¼ teaspoon salt
  • 4 teaspoons olive oil
  • 1 tablespoon honey
  • 1 tablespoon Dijon mustard
  • 2 teaspoons apple cider vinegar
  • 2 bunches baby arugula or mixed greens
  • 3 oranges, segmented without membranes
  • 1 avocado, cut into small cubes
  • ¼ cup pumpkin seeds
  • ¼ cup chopped parsley or mint
";
directions:
1. Rinse arame and soak in a bowl with water for about 20 minutes. Drain and gently squeeze out any remaining water. Discard soaking water.

2. Toss together olive oil, orange juice, pomegranate juice and Dijon mustard, honey, and apple cider vinegar.

3. Transfer arame into a bowl with arugula and orange slices.

4. Top with pumpkin seeds. Eat right away. Dressing will keep for 2 weeks in fridge.

articleBodyHTML:
Can’t do nuts? No Problem You can still have THIS raw Carrot Cake! The flavor is sweet, smooth happiness in your mouth.

Raw desserts and cakes typically use a base of nuts and dates. The nuts provide bulk and body; the dates serve as a sweet binder. But not everyone can partake in tree nuts, so my No-Nut Carrot Cake was born. In this moist and raw recipe, I ditch the nuts altogether in favor of oats and coconut.

While the oats and coconut bulk up the cake, the dates—joined by a handful of dried apricots—act as a binder. Additional moisture and sweetness are provided by maple syrup and applesauce. To the traditional cinnamon and nutmeg, I add just a touch of cardamom for warmth.

The best part of this no-nut carrot cake? It’s also no-bake! After you’ve mixed the ingredients as instructed, all you need is a refrigerator to firm it up.
articleSummaryHTML: Can’t do nuts? No Problem You can still have THIS raw Carrot Cake! The flavor is sweet, smooth happiness in your mouth.
seoTitle: Nut-Free, Raw, Vegan Carrot Cake | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Can’t do nuts? No Problem You can still have THIS raw Carrot Cake from Sunwarrior! The flavor is sweet, smooth happiness in your mouth.
ingredients:
s:753:"
  • 6 Medjool dates, pitted
  • 8 dried apricots, unsulphured
  • ¼ cup unsweetened applesauce
  • ¼ cup maple syrup
  • 1 ½ teaspoons vanilla extract
  • 2 cups old-fashioned oats
  • ½ cup unsweetened shredded coconut, ground fine
  • 1 teaspoon cinnamon
  • ½ teaspoon ginger powder
  • ½ teaspoon nutmeg
  • Pinch ground cardamom
  • 2 cups shredded carrots
";
directions: In a food processor fitted with the S-blade, process the dates, apricots, applesauce, maple syrup and vanilla extract until well-combined. Add oats, ground coconut, spices and shredded carrots. Continue to process until ingredients are homogenized and the mixture sticks together easily. Press batter into small silicone cupcake molds or use your hands to make balls or individual servings. Place in refrigerator to firm up before serving. May be finished with a vanilla cashew frosting if desired.

articleBodyHTML:
If you want to be a ball of energy, you can eat a ball of energy. These black tahini balls are just the ticket!

These rock star energy balls are high in protein, taste incredible and delicious. Black sesame is common in many Asian desserts. It’s super nutty and packs so many nutritional benefits. There are always new products being featured in organic health markets, and I stumbled across black sesame seed butter. I fell in love and had to create a healthy dessert with them. The result was a success, and these have been a fan favorite with family and friends.

Black sesame butter or better known as black tahini paste is high in healthy fats and amino acids. A small amount of tahini can go a long way. Its flavors are robust, so you don’t need much. While tahini may be high in calories, it contains an abundance of protein and benefits your skin, heart, hormones and energy levels. Many people who are on a plant-based diet tend to feel lethargic or suffer from anemia. Tahini is a great source of plant-based protein that can help with these symptoms and help boost energy levels.

If you can’t find black sesame tahini, you can always use the regular version. Make sure you look for un-hulled and raw version. Un-hulled sesame is the raw and unprocessed version of the seed where the bran is still attached. By keeping the bran on the kernel, more nutrients are present.

When compared with other nut butters, sesame butter is rated high due to its amazing properties. It’s not as highly processed and refined as its counterpart, peanut butter.

These power balls also include raw cashews and chia seeds which are both an amazing source of protein and energy. These power balls can be made in a larger batch, placed in the freezer and stored for up to two months in an airtight container. These are the perfect on the go snack.
articleSummaryHTML: If you want to be a ball of energy, you can eat a ball of energy. These black tahini balls are just the ticket!
seoTitle: Black Tahini Energy Balls | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: If you want to be a ball of energy, you can eat a ball of energy. These black tahini balls are just the ticket! Check out Sunwarrior's recipe today.
ingredients:
s:332:"
  • 1/2 cup black tahini
  • 6 Medjool dates
  • 1/2 cup walnuts
  • 1/2 cup cashews
  • 1/3 cup chia seeds 
  • 2 tablespoons black sesame seeds
";
directions:
1.) Place walnuts and cashews in your food processor. Pulse until broken up

2.) Add pitted dates and black tahini. Blend until well combined

3.) Place chia seeds and sesame seeds in a small bowl

4.) Remove mixture from food processor, roll into balls and roll in chia mix

5.) Store in an airtight container in the fridge

articleBodyHTML:
If it’s not all Greek to you, then it should be because this Greek white bean dip is one of the best flavors you’ll experience this year!

Am I the only one who eats chips and dip as a hobby? I just can’t resist a crunchy snack paired with infinite options to dip it in! My favorite is hummus and pita chips. However, in an attempt to make something slightly out of the box, I used cannellini beans to make a creamy and flavorful dip! Cannellini beans definitely have a more subtle flavor and can hold nicely to bolder flavors such as Kalamata olives and roasted red peppers. By keeping your mix-ins chunky, you are adding additional texture while also bulking up the dip. The best part about this is that it’s totally customizable! Try other mix-ins such as pine nuts, basil, and sundried tomatoes. Just remember to keep it simple and of course, flavorful!

This dip comes together in about 5 minutes, which makes it the perfect last minute entertaining food and also makes it the perfect make-ahead-and-store-in-the-fridge for a quick snack fix later. If you have time, try to create a variety of dippers such as homemade pita chips, sliced cucumbers, and bell peppers to ensure there’s something for everyone!
articleSummaryHTML: If it’s not all Greek to you, then it should be because this Greek white bean dip is one of the best flavors you’ll experience this year!
seoTitle: Greek White Bean Dip | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: If it’s not all Greek to you, then it should be because Sunwarrior's Greek white bean dip is one of the best flavors you’ll experience this year!
ingredients:
s:532:"
  • 1 can cannellini beans, drained and rinsed
  • 2 small cloves garlic, rough chopped
  • Juice of 1 lemon (or more to taste)
  • ½ teaspoon dried oregano
  • 1 roasted red pepper, diced
  • 8–10 Kalamata olives, diced
  • 2 tablespoons fresh parsley
  • Salt and pepper to taste
";
directions:
Place cannellini beans, garlic, lemon juice, and oregano in a food processor and process until smooth. Add salt and pepper to taste.

Remove cannellini bean mixture from the food processor and dump into a bowl. Stir in the diced red peppers, Kalamata olives, and parsley and mix until all incorporated. It is best to chill the dip for at least 1 hour, but it can be served warm temperature as well.

Serve with chips or sliced veggies! Store in the fridge for up to 1 week.

articleBodyHTML:
It’s mm-mmm maple glazed plantains for good health and flavor all in one bite. I’ll eat to that!

Plantains are the health fruit choice that few people think about. But they should because this fruit is rich in vitamin A, vitamin C, vitamin B6, potassium, magnesium, and iron! These vitamins and minerals boost brain health, digestive health, and your immune system  all while lowering your blood pressure and fortifying your body with great antioxidants.

The sweet glaze of maple syrup on these plantains makes for fruit hearty dessert. It is refreshing and satisfying, and the best part is that it only takes a few minutes to make! So get your sauté pan out when you get that sweet craving because this dessert is aimed to please in all the best ways. Serves 2.
articleSummaryHTML: It’s mm-mmm maple glazed plantains for good health and flavor all in one bite. I’ll eat to that!
seoTitle: Learn How to Make Maple Glazed Plantains | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: It’s mm-mmm maple glazed plantains for good health and flavor all in one bite. I’ll eat to that! Learn how to make maple glazed plantains right here!
ingredients:
s:310:"
  • 1 large plantain, soft and ripe
  • 1 tablespoon coconut oil
  • 1 tablespoon maple syrup
  • 1 tablespoon coconut palm sugar
  • Handful of raspberries
";
directions: Peel and cut plantain on the diagonal. Heat sauté pan on medium heat with the coconut oil. Coat plantain with maple syrup and sprinkle with palm sugar. Place plantain in heated pan and cook until browned on each side. About 3 minutes per side. When the second side is almost browned, throw in a handful of raspberries and warm up. Serve with coconut ice cream and enjoy!

articleBodyHTML:
Sweet snacking by the handful, this buckwheat and berry granola has all the health benefits a good snack should!

Granola! Comforting, filling, treat-like, versatile, and truly so easy to make, it really is a smart whole-foods staple to have on hand. With today’s current popular trend to go grain-free, granola may have taken a back seat in your diet, but it might be time to reconsider. The resurgence of Ancient Grains means numerous easy-to-find superfood quality varieties that are delicious, mineral dense, and full of phytonutrients and vitamins as well as being very affordable.

Gluten-free folks can find great options by using teff, amaranth, quinoa, and the almighty buckwheat groats featured in this recipe. With all eight essential amino acids, these pseudo grains/seeds are rich in protein, fiber, manganese, magnesium, and lignans, and they’re alkaline.
articleSummaryHTML: Sweet snacking by the handful, this buckwheat and berry granola has all the health benefits a good snack should!
seoTitle: Buckwheat and Berry Granola | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Sunwarrior's buckwheat and berry granola has all the health benefits a good snack should! Learn how to make this granola and it's perfect for breakfast.
ingredients:
s:1264:"
  • 1 cup raw buckwheat groats soaked 30 minutes or overnight, drain well
  • 2 cups old-fashioned rolled oats of your choice
  • ½ cup sunflower
  • ½ cup pumpkin seeds
  • ½ cup pecans
  • ½ cup coconut flakes
  • ¼ cup flax seed, ground
  • ¼ cup coconut flour or almond meal
  • 1 generous tablespoon cinnamon
  • 1 teaspoon ground ginger
  • ½ teaspoon fine gray sea salt
  • 1/3–½ cup organic agave, coconut syrup or maple syrup, or to taste
  • ¼ cup hazelnut oil or coconut oil, melted
  • 1–2 teaspoons real vanilla extract, as desired
  • ½ cup currants
  • ½ cup goji berries
  • ¼ cup each raw cacao nibs
  • ¼ cup hemp seeds 
";
directions:
1. Preheat oven to 300F and line a large baking sheet with parchment paper

2. In a large bowl, mix together the dry ingredients

3. Once the mix is well combined, add the syrup, oil, and vanilla. Stir well.

4. Spread granola onto baking sheet in a uniform layer. Bake at 300F for 20 minutes then remove from the oven, turn and toss granola, and bake for another 15–20 minutes. (The dried fruits can be added now, or you can wait until the final 5–10 minutes of baking to add them.)

5. Once done, stir in the raw cacao nibs and hemp seeds. Cool completely on the pan. Can be stored in a glass container for 3–4 weeks. The granola can be stored in the freezer as well in a safe container, ideally not plastic.

In my kitchen, I most often enjoy granola on top of my always thick creamy smoothies – now commonly known as smoothie bowls.

articleBodyHTML:
Spice up your Cinco de Mayo with a vegan smoky, spicy chili mole! While not technically a Mexican dish, it’s still an ole’ to your mole!

It’s a perfect make-ahead food for weekday meals, parties, weekends away, tailgate parties, potlucks and freezer fare. What am I talking about? Why chili, of course, and this version is a keeper. I trust you’ll add it to your go-to recipes, since it’s just a little different from many chili recipes out there due to the additional richness of the cacao. The smokiness from the chipotle and paprika are perfect in replacing that meat flavor, making this vegan version certain to win over sworn-carnivores. My suggestion – don’t even mention it’s meatless. They won’t miss it and just may ask you for the recipe.
articleSummaryHTML: Spice up your Cinco de Mayo with a vegan smoky, spicy chili mole! While not technically a Mexican dish, it’s still an ole’ to your mole!
seoTitle: How to Make the Best Smokey, Spicy Chili Mole | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Spice up your Cinco de Mayo with a vegan smoky, spicy chili mole! While not technically a Mexican dish, it’s still an ole’ to your mole!
ingredients:
s:1395:"

 

  • 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil
  • 2 onions, chopped
  • 4 garlic cloves, minced
  • 1 inch ginger root, grated
  • 2 tablespoons chili powder
  • 1 tablespoon cumin powder
  • 2 teaspoons oregano
  • 1 teaspoon smoked paprika
  • 1 teaspoon chipotle chili powder
  • 2 tablespoons cacao powder
  • ½ teaspoon cinnamon
  • ½ teaspoon sea salt
  • Freshly ground black pepper and salt to taste
  • 1 heaping tablespoon organic tomato paste
  • 1 500 g package organic tofu, cubed or crumbled
  • 1 large or 2 small bell peppers, chopped
  • 2 28 oz. cans fire roasted tomatoes, no salt added
  • 2½ cups cooked kidney beans or 2 14 oz. cans
  • 1 bottle organic, dark beer of your choice (Choose gluten-free if desired)
  • 1 cup chopped cilantro, for serving
";
directions:
1. In a large pot, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add onions and cook a few minutes before adding garlic, ginger, chili powder, cumin, oregano, paprika, chipotle, cacao, cinnamon, black pepper and sea salt. Using a wooden spoon, stir well to meld flavors together, add the tomato paste and cook approximately 5 minutes.
  2. Now add the tofu cubes and peppers with a splash of additional oil if needed. Sauté for 3–5 minutes to brown tofu and caramelize peppers.
  3. Stir in the tomatoes, beans, and beer, breaking up the tomatoes as you stir. Bring to a boil, reduce heat to low, cover loosely allowing steam to escape, and cook for 2 hours to infuse flavors and create a thick sauce.
  4. Taste and season with extra salt or spices as needed
  5. Ladle into bowls, and garnish with chopped cilantro.
  6. This chili serves great with soft, grilled warm corn or flour tortillas, organic tortilla chips, guacamole, and salsa or Pico gala. It will keep properly refrigerated for 4–5 days and freezes wonderfully. Like most stews, the flavor intensifies as time passes.

articleBodyHTML:
Come to the vegan side; we have comfort food. You can still have the happiness that comes with mac and cheese; it just tastes better.

If you were a mac and cheese lover like me, then you will absolutely love this gluten-free and dairy-free version. Of course, nothing tastes like the real thing, but this version will surely hit the spot. It is nice to be able to eat something that is creamy without any dairy. It’s also great to be able to mimic the color of cheese with whole foods such as butternut squash. The blend of tahini, miso, squash and nutritional yeast gives this mac its cheesy consistency. If you are grain free, then choose to make this mac with lentil or chickpea pasta, that way it’s not only gluten-free but high in fiber and protein!
articleSummaryHTML: Come to the vegan side; we have comfort food. You can still have the happiness that comes with mac and cheese; it just tastes better.
seoTitle: How to Easy Vegan Mac and Cheese | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Come to the vegan side. You can still have the happiness that comes with Sunwarrior's easy to make mac and cheese; it just tastes better.
ingredients:
s:1139:"
  • 1 bag of gluten free pasta (red lentil or Tinkyada brown rice)
  • 1 ¼ cups water
  • 1 cup plain almond or rice milk
  • 1 softened small or 2 cups butternut squash cut into cubes (can be steamed or roasted)
  • ¾ cup nutritional yeast
  • 3 tablespoons arrowroot powder
  • 1 tablespoon lemon juice
  • 1 teaspoon salt (or more to taste)
  • ½ teaspoon garlic powder
  • 1 teaspoon onion powder
  • ½ teaspoon dry mustard
  • ½ teaspoon paprika
  • ½ teaspoon turmeric
  • Pinch of cayenne pepper
  • 2 tablespoons tahini
  • 1 teaspoon mellow white miso (or additional salt)
  • Black pepper to taste
";
directions:
1. Preheat oven to 350 F. Put the pasta on to boil, according to package directions. While it’s cooking, blend all remaining ingredients together in a blender.

2. When the pasta is al dente, drain it, reserving about 1⁄2 cup of the cooking water, and return the pasta to the pan.

3. Add the sauce mixture and cook, stirring, until mixture boils and thickens. Add a little of the pasta water if more moistness is needed.

4. If the sauce is not as flavorful as you’d like, add a little more mustard and onion powder.

5. Place the pasta and the “cheese sauce” together in a large baking dish and top with brown rice breadcrumbs and bake in the oven for 10–20 (if you like the crispy baked kind).

articleTitle: Zoodle Pasta Pomodoro with Hemp Parmesan…A Twist on the Traditional
articleBodyHTML:
Get a taste of the Old World! This zoodle pasta Pomodoro with hemp parmesan puts a new twist on the traditional flavors of Italy!

This recipe is a twist from the traditional pasta favored by most Italian food lovers. Instead of the glutinous noodles traditionally used in pasta dishes, this recipe uses two types of noodles: zucchini and shirataki, also known as konjac or miracle noodles. If you have not tried shirataki noodles, you are definitely missing out. These translucent noodles have zero calories, are high in fiber and very filling. They are made from glucomannan, a type of fiber that comes from the root of the konjac plant. Since they are high in fiber, they digest slowly, and you feel fuller longer.

In addition, zucchini has a boost of nutrient value and is a healthier alternative to noodles. They contain potassium, folate, magnesium, and have a good source of vitamin A and C. They are low in calories with a high water content, which make them an excellent choice if you want to shed a few pounds and ditch the starchy carbs. So give this recipe a whirl. It’s pretty quick and easy to make.
articleSummaryHTML: Get a taste of the Old World! This zoodle pasta Pomodoro with hemp parmesan puts a new twist on the traditional flavors of Italy!
seoTitle: Zoodle Pasta Pomodoro with Hemp Parmesan | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Get a taste of the Old World! Sunwarrior's zoodle pasta Pomodoro with hemp parmesan puts a new twist on the traditional flavors of Italy!
recipeName: Zoodle Pasta Pomodoro with Hemp Parmesan…A Twist on the Traditional
ingredients:
s:901:"

Pasta

  • 2 ripe large vine tomatoes, chopped
  • ½ a sweet or yellow onion, chopped
  • 1 garlic clove, minced
  • 1 zucchini
  • 1 cup Konjac (miracle) noodles (either angel hair or fettuccini)
  • 1 teaspoon oregano (more if you like oregano)
  • 2 basil leaves (optional)
  • 1 teaspoon Himalayan salt
  • 2 tablespoons olive oil

Hemp Parmesan

  • ¼ cup of hemp seeds
  • ¼ cup of nutritional yeast
  • Salt and pepper to taste
";
directions:
1. Mince garlic and chop onions and tomatoes.
  2. In a pan, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add the minced garlic and chopped onions and sauté until tender but not brown.
  3. Add the chopped tomatoes, oregano, and salt; reduce heat and simmer for at least 20 minutes or until tomatoes have softened.
  4. While tomatoes are simmering, prepare the noodles using a spiralizer. Spiralizer the zucchini so that they come out looking like spaghetti.
  5. Remove the Konjac noodles from the package, place in a colander and rinse under cold water for 10 to 15 seconds. Boil a small pot of water. When the water boils, place the Konjac noodles in the water for only 2 minutes. Remove the noodles and drain the water. Place Konjac noodles in a non-greased pan on medium heat until dry.
  6. Place ingredients for the hemp parmesan in a coffee grinder or food processor and process until you have a fine powder. If do not have either of these, just sprinkle both hemp seeds and nutritional yeast on noodles.
  7. Assemble the zucchini noodles and Konjac on a plate, add the Pomodoro (tomatoes) and top with hemp parmesan. Eat and enjoy!

articleBodyHTML:
For a refreshing light meal or addition to your meal, this sweet kale salad is the reason salads are always in style!

Kale is totally fabulous and totally nutritious! However, kale isn’t something you can just eat raw and enjoy, at least I can’t. Brussels sprouts were a pleasant surprise to me in this salad. It blends in with kale; so picky eaters won’t even notice they are there. For a long time, I always roasted Brussels sprouts, and only a select few in my house liked it. I never thought eating them raw would be good. Surprise! They are delicious raw!

To make this salad even easier, just buy the broccoli slaw found by the packaged salads. The broccoli is already cut into matchsticks, and it has added veggies, red cabbage, and carrots. Make sure it’s organic.

This salad is dense with nutrients. Kale is the main ingredient and is packed with vitamin K, C, and A. Brussels sprouts and broccoli also bring a lot of vitamin K and C as well as folate. Dried cranberries are antioxidant and anti-inflammatory. And the roasted pumpkin seed adds a delicious crunch to the salad as well as manganese and zinc.
articleSummaryHTML: For a refreshing light meal or addition to your meal, this sweet kale salad is the reason salads are always in style!
seoTitle: Learn How to Make Sweet Kale Vegetable Salad Recipe
seoDescription: For a refreshing light meal or addition to your meal, this sweet kale salad is the reason salads are always in style! Learn how to make it with Sunwarrior.
ingredients:
s:1036:"

Salad Ingredients:

  • 4 cups shredded and chopped curly kale
  • 2 cups thinly sliced Brussels sprouts
  • 1 cup broccoli matchsticks
  • ½ cup dried cranberries (or any other tart fruit like green or gala apple)
  • ¼ cup roasted and salted pepitas or pumpkin seeds
  • optional: chopped cabbage and matchstick carrots

Dressing Ingredients:

  • ¼ cup vegan mayonnaise
  • 1 ½ tablespoons almond milk
  • 1 ½ tablespoons white balsamic
  • 1 tablespoon agave or honey (for our vegetarian friends)
  • 2 teaspoons poppy seeds
  • pinch ancient sea salt
";
directions: Mix all salad ingredients together and toss well. Set aside. Add all dressing ingredients except poppy seeds into a food processor. Mix until well blended. Add poppy seeds and pulse a few times. Pour dressing over top of the salad and mix well. Serve.

articleBodyHTML:
If you think brownies can’t fit into your healthy diet, you are wrong. These banana flour brownies are the answer!

Brownies may not be the traditional health food, but you can switch out unhealthy ingredients and replace them with whole foods. A little treat here and there is great, not only for your body, but also for your brain. Allowing yourself to have a healthy treat once or twice a week can help reduce sugar cravings.

The quest for healthy brownies is always on my radar. Countless hours have been spent in the kitchen trying to formulate a delicious and healthy recipe that is gluten free, nutritious, and tasty! I stumbled across banana flour at my local health food store and was intrigued to try it. The result was excellent, and these brownies were a knockout. After a few hit and misses, I developed a delicious and chocolate filled brownie that will leave you wanting seconds. The ingredients in these brownies are pure and simple. This recipe uses chocolate which contains antioxidants which can help your body stave off diseases and help to clear out free radicals in the body. If you have an allergy to chocolate, you can always swap it out for carob powder.

Banana flour is made of green bananas which have a high starch content so you can cut back on the amount of flour in a given recipe. When blended with other ingredients, the flour has a very neutral taste. Banana flour is unlike any other flour as it boasts a high potassium content and rich in minerals and vitamins. Unlike the delicious yellow ripe banana’s we have all grown to love, green bananas are lower in sugar. Green bananas also have resistance starch. What that means is that it passes through your intestine unchanged. It is converted into an insoluble fiber which can help constipation. Overall green bananas are amazing for controlling blood sugar and managing weight.
articleSummaryHTML: If you think brownies can’t fit into your healthy diet, you are wrong. These banana flour brownies are the answer!
seoTitle: How to Make the Best Banana Flour Brownies | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: If you think brownies can’t fit into your healthy diet, you are wrong. Sunwarrior wants you to learn how to make the best banana flour brownies.
ingredients:
s:293:"
  • 1 cup unsweetened applesauce
  • ¼ cup green banana flour
  • 1/3 cup melted vegan chocolate
  • ¼ cup cocoa powder
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
  • ½ teaspoon salt
  • ½ teaspoon baking soda
";
directions:
1.) Preheat oven to 350 degrees

2.) Bring a pot of water to a boil. Place chocolate in a heatproof bowl. Gently stir chocolate until melted. Remove from heat

3.) Mix applesauce, melted chocolate, cocoa powder, vanilla extract, salt, baking soda and banana

4.) Pour batter into a 6 x 6 pan, lined with parchment paper

5.) Bake for 18–20 minutes

articleTitle: High Protein Chocolate and Peanut Butter Cheesecake
articleBodyHTML:
Go to heaven, but skip the awful dying part with this high protein chocolate and peanut butter cheesecake!

This cake is a showstopper! It’s one of these dishes that can convert anyone to veganism unless they don’t believe it’s vegan because it’s so good! It is also very high in protein, gluten-free, and refined sugar-free, so really, it’s just heaven on a plate.

There are four layers to it, so it takes a bit of time to prepare, but most of this time is soaking the ingredients and then waiting for the cake to set, and trust me, it’s so worth the wait!
articleSummaryHTML: Go to heaven, but skip the awful dying part with this high protein chocolate and peanut butter cheesecake!
seoTitle: High Protein Chocolate & Peanut Butter Cheesecake
seoDescription: Go to heaven but skip the awful dying part with this high protein chocolate and peanut butter cheesecake from Sunwarrior. It's easy to make but delicious.
recipeName: High Protein Chocolate and Peanut Butter Cheesecake
ingredients:
s:1667:"

For the Base

  • 150g gluten free oat flour
  • 3 tablespoons peanut butter
  • 1 ½ tablespoons maple syrup
  • 1 ½ tablespoons coconut oil (melted)
  • 1 scoop Sunwarrior Classic Chocolate Protein
  • a pinch of salt

For the Cheese

  • 400g cashews, soaked for 4–6 hours
  • 2 tablespoons coconut oil
  • 2 x 160ml tin of coconut cream (just the thick top layer)

For the Chocolate Layer

  • 2/3 of the “cheese”
  • 2 scoops Sunwarrior Classic Chocolate Protein
  • 2 tablespoons cacao powder
  • 4 tablespoons maple syrup
  • 2 tablespoons lime juice
  • 2 tablespoons coconut oil (melted)

For the Peanut Butter Layer

  • 1/3 of the “cheese”
  • 3 tablespoons peanut butter
  • 4 tablespoons maple syrup
  • 150 ml almond milk
  • a pinch of salt

For the Caramel

  • 250g dates, soaked for 2 hours
  • 2 tablespoons peanut butter
  • 200 ml water
  • a pinch of salt

For the Topping

  • 50g dark chocolate
  • 1 tablespoon coconut oil
  • a handful of peanuts
  • a pinch of salt
";
directions:
To make the base, put all the base ingredients in a food processor or a high-speed blender and mix until loose dough forms. Lay the bottom of an 8-inch round cake tin with baking parchment and firmly press the dough into the bottom. Set aside (no need to chill).

To make the “cheese,” melt the coconut oil and the top layer of the coconut cream and pour into the food processor or high-speed blender. Add soaked and drained cashews and blend until smooth and creamy “cheese” forms. This will take a good few minutes.

To make the chocolate layer, put 2/3 of the “cheese” in the food processor or high-speed blender and add all the other chocolate layer ingredients. Blend for a few minutes until smooth. The mass should be quite thick and creamy. Put the mass on the top of the base and put in the fridge while preparing the other layers.

To make the peanut butter layer, put 1/3 of the “cheese” in the food processor or high-speed blender and add all the other peanut butter layer ingredients. Blend for a few minutes until smooth, thick, and creamy. Take the tin out of the fridge and put the peanut butter layer on the top of the chocolate layer. Put back in the fridge while making the caramel.

To make the caramel, put the soaked and drained dates together with all the other caramel ingredients into the food processor or high-speed blender and blend until smooth caramel forms. This, again, is going to take a few minutes. Put the caramel on the top of the peanut butter layer and put the cake in the freezer for at least 4 hours or overnight.

To make the topping sprinkle a handful of peanuts on the top of the cake. Melt the chocolate together with the coconut oil and pour over the top. Sprinkle with some sea salt. Leave the cake in the fridge for at least 3 hours to defrost. From this point, you can store it in the fridge, and there is no need to freeze it again unless you want to save it for later.

articleBodyHTML:
Finally! A sauce with sass! This vegan cauliflower white sauce is thick, creamy, delicious, and did we mention vegan?!

A delicious, healthy white sauce is so hard to find. I’ve tried for a while to find a good recipe that will make a delicious white sauce without sacrificing taste and texture. I’ve found some recipes that are good, but the taste is off, or the texture is weird.

I recently stumbled upon this delicious cauliflower white sauce that is divine! Each one of my kids was shocked when I told them it was made from cauliflower. I kept it a secret throughout dinner to see if anyone would notice. Not one of the kids said anything. One child did say it is super creamy. Yes! This is just what I was looking for.

Because this recipe is mostly cauliflower, this recipe has a lot of vitamin C. Cauliflower also is an anti-inflammatory that helps fight cancer and other diseases. It is chock full of phytonutrients as well.

You can use this sauce over whole wheat pasta or even on a pizza with veggies. This white sauce is begging to be used in anything you want!
articleSummaryHTML: Finally! A sauce with sass! This vegan cauliflower white sauce is thick, creamy, delicious, and did we mention vegan?!
seoTitle: How to Make Delicious Vegan Cauliflower White Sauce
seoDescription: Finally! A sauce with sass! Sunwarrior's vegan cauliflower white sauce is thick, creamy, delicious, and did we mention vegan?! Learn how to make it here!
ingredients:
s:479:"
  • 8 large cloves garlic, minced
  • 2 tablespoons olive oil
  • 5–6 cups cauliflower florets
  • 6–7 cups vegetable broth
  • 1 teaspoon salt (or to taste)
  • ½ teaspoon pepper (or to taste)
  • ½ cup soy, cashew, or rice milk (or to taste)
";
directions:
1. Bring vegetable broth to a boil. Add all cauliflower and cook until tender about 8 mins. While cauliflower is cooking, sauté the garlic in olive oil until fragrant.
  2. Once cauliflower is tender, remove from broth with a slotted spoon and add to blender. Then add 1 cup vegetable broth (what the cauliflower was cooked in), sautéed garlic, salt, pepper, and milk. Puree until smooth.
  3. Can also add additional nut milk or olive oil to smooth out the sauce, if desired.

Best used the same day.

articleBodyHTML:
Healthy, delicious, and easy to make, this bean salad is the clear winner. Welcome to dinner!

This mixed bean salad is healthy, delicious, and super easy to make. We’re talking 10 super-easy, and it stays fresh in the fridge for 4–5 days. The best part about this salad is that the longer it marinates, the better it tastes. By using fresh ingredients, this makes a great main meal, salad or salsa for any occasion. One of my favorite things about this salad is that it doesn’t contain any oil. Squeeze some fresh limes and sprinkle with Himalayan salt and pepper, and that’s it.

This salad is packed with many nutrients and vitamins starting with the black beans.

Black beans are actually legumes, and they are rich in protein and fiber. You can use organic canned black beans, or you can soak your beans a day ahead and heat them the next day.

Depending on where you live, you can use organic canned corn, or you can buy fresh corn and shave off the niblets. This recipe calls for a lot of chopping and dicing so make sure that knife is sharp. This recipe calls for chopped cilantro, parsley, and pepper. To give this recipe a kick of healthy fats, it uses creamy and ripe avocado. Avocados are one of the world's most incredible and nutrient dense foods. Avocados contain more potassium than bananas. They are also loaded with fiber which can help regulate appetite and maintain a healthy digestive tract. Most people are concerned with avocado’s high-fat content and weight gain. Although avocados are high in fat, by eating and incorporating avocados into your daily meals it will keep you more satiated which will, therefore, reduce your desire to overeat later on.

(NOTE: If you're struggling to find ways to add avocados and healthy fats to your diet, check out our 25 best ways to add avocado. 

You can always add any additional beans, legumes, and vegetables to this salad. Make this your masterpiece and color your plate with vegetables
articleSummaryHTML: Healthy, delicious, and easy to make, this bean salad is the clear winner. Welcome to dinner!
seoTitle: Best Vegan Bean Salad Recipe | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Healthy, delicious, and easy to make, this vegan bean salad is the best recipe you will find online from Sunwarrior. Welcome to dinner!
ingredients:
s:466:"
  • 1 can organic black beans
  • 1 can organic sweet corn
  • 1 red pepper, cubed
  • 1 cup parsley, chopped
  • 1 cup cilantro, chopped
  • 1 avocado, diced into chunks
  • ½ cup lime juice
  • Himalayan salt and pepper
";
directions:
1.) Chop red pepper, cilantro, and parsley. Add to a large bowl

2.) Add beans, corn, and avocado. Add lime juice, salt, and pepper. Serve

articleBodyHTML:
Before those summer nights hit too hard, enjoy the cooler spring evenings with this delicious green lentil soup!

What I love about lentils is that they don’t need to be soaked overnight. So if you’re in a pinch and want a pot of lentil soup for dinner, cook them right into your broth! Lentils are also one of the easiest legumes to digest, and they don’t leave your belly bloated.

If you cook them up separately, then you can use lentils in a variety of recipes all week long from salads and burgers to dips.

However, soup is a delicious and hearty way to enjoy them. This soup has a flare of Indian spices that are warming and satisfying. Complete your soup with a bowl of brown basmati rice and steamed greens!

(NOTE: If you love spicing up your food, check out our article on a couple amazing spices you can add to any dish. Find it here.)
articleSummaryHTML: Before those summer nights hit too hard, enjoy the cooler spring evenings with this delicious green lentil soup!
seoTitle: How to Make Chunky Green Lentil Soup | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Before those summer nights hit too hard, enjoy the cooler spring evenings with this delicious green lentil soup from Sunwarrior Health Hub.
ingredients:
s:860:"
  • 2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil
  • 1 ½ cups diced yellow onion
  • Pinch of sea salt
  • 2 carrots, peeled and diced
  • 1 ½ cups celery, peeled and diced
  • 1 tablespoon garlic
  • 1 teaspoon ground cumin
  • 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon
  • 1/8 teaspoon ground allspice
  • 2 cups green lentils, rinsed well
  • 8 cups water or vegetable stock
  • 2 bay leaves
  • ½ cup fresh lemon juice
  • ¼ teaspoon maple syrup
";
directions:
1. In a large sauté pan, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add the onions and pinch of salt and cook until golden brown. Add the carrots, celery, and garlic, and sauté for about 30 seconds.

2. Add the cumin, cinnamon, allspice, lentils, and pinch of salt

3. Add the liquid and bay leaves. Reduce the heat, cover and simmer until the vegetables are softened and the lentils have cooked through (about 30 minutes).

4. Add lemon juice and maple syrup, and serve.

articleBodyHTML:
Breakfast, snack, divine dessert, or pre or post workout meal: no matter how you parfait, it will always be the perfect time!

Cashews are loved, yet often feared. These coveted nuts deserve a place in your pantry and whipping them into a silky alternative to dairy is a perfect way to convince you. Especially when layered into a cool, sweet, and creamy parfait with a touch of crunch. Having these prepped in your fridge and ready for a grab-and-go meal makes living healthy easy. Actually, making these for a dessert parfait is just perfect too. A drizzle of Limoncello or Cointreau elevates the snack to gourmet dessert. If you abstain from alcohol that’s ok – stick with orange or rose water for an intriguing flavor infusion.
articleSummaryHTML: Breakfast, snack, divine dessert, or pre or post workout meal: no matter how you parfait, it will always be the perfect time!
seoTitle: Cashew Cream & Berry Chia Parfait | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Breakfast, snack, divine dessert, or pre or post workout meal: no matter how you parfait, it will always be the perfect time!
ingredients:
s:1377:"

The Layers

  • 2–3 cups blueberries, fresh or frozen
  • Approximately 1 cup fresh berries
  • 1 banana, sliced
  • Approximately 1 cup chia pudding (recipe below)
  • 1–1½ cups cashew cream (recipe below)

Toppings

Crushed nuts, granola, toasted coconut, dried berries, cacao nibs, zest, etc.

Chia Pudding

  • 4 tablespoons chia seeds
  • 1 cup dairy-free milk
  • Generous pinch cinnamon, cardamom, nutmeg or ginger powder
  • 1 teaspoon sweetener of your choice (agave, honey, maple syrup)

Cashew Crème

  • 1½ cups raw organic cashews soaked 4–8 hours, drained (No time? See Teri’s Tip below!)
  • Approximately ¾ cup organic coconut, cashew or almond milk (more if needed)
  • 4–6 tablespoons raw local honey, real maple syrup or raw agave, to taste    
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
  • 1 teaspoon freshly squeezed organic lemon juice (reserve zest)
  • For optional protein, add 1 scoop of raw vegan Sunwarrior Warrior Blend Vanilla
";
directions:
Chia Pudding

For best results, mix the ingredients the night before and let it set in the refrigerator. The next morning it’s ready to use in your parfaits. If you forgot to do this, then just let stand 15 minutes in the morning.

Cashew Crème

Place the soaked cashews, coconut milk, honey (or other sweetener), vanilla, and lemon juice into a powerful blender. Process or blend using off and on power and scraping down sides as needed until well combined and creamy.

Taste and adjust sweetness and thickness if needed then transfer to a glass bowl and refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before using.

Parfait

Layer approximately ¼ cup blueberries in the bottom of small mason jars, top with a few spoonful’s cashew crème, fresh berries, chia pudding, banana slices, another spoonful of cashew crème, then the crunchy topping of your choice. Garnish as desired, seal and refrigerate for up to three days.

TERI’S TIME SAVER TIP: Mix equal parts of raw cashew butter and your favorite non-dairy milk with honey or maple syrup, to taste. Add more cashew butter or coconut milk for desired consistency. Use as directed above creating a layered berry parfait.

Cashews are rich in copper, magnesium, tryptophan and selenium. With a lower fat content than most other nuts, approximately 75% of their fat is unsaturated fatty acids. Approx 75% of this unsaturated fatty acid content is oleic acid and promotes good cardiovascular health. Studies of diabetic patients show that monounsaturated fat, when added to a low-fat diet, can help to reduce high triglyceride levels.

articleBodyHTML:
You know you need more yoga, but motivation isn’t always easy. This is why we’re giving you the best reward for yoga ever: the chai green smoothie!

While we’re all (I’m sure) well aware of the tremendous benefits of yoga, some of us (definitely me) struggle to commit to spending regular time in down dog. (Shavasana, on the other hand, the one where you lay on your back with your eyes closed, I’ve nailed.)

Yoga can be uncomfortable, it’s sometimes awkward, and it’s deceptively really really hard! Which is why I often skip it, even though I know my body and mind really really want it. But I’m determined for that to change! I’m determined to do yoga more than once a month. And buying the perfect yoga mat aside, I believe I’ve found my solution: this post-yoga chai green smoothie.

This chia green smoothie, completely creamy and flavorful with chai spices (the real ones! Right from a chai tea bag!), juicy dates, Sunwarrior plant-protein and spinach or kale is seriously so good that if I tell myself I only get it as a reward for completing a yoga class, there's a very good chance I'll force myself (I mean lovingly encourage myself) through the chair poses and down dogs for it!

Really, this smoothie is that good.

I hope it also gives you a leg up in your yoga-going-adventures (and in your tree pose).

Chai cheers!

(Serves 1 sweaty yogi)
articleSummaryHTML: You know you need more yoga, but motivation isn’t always easy. This is why we’re giving you the best reward for yoga ever: the chai green smoothie!
seoTitle: Yoga-Motivator Chai Green Smoothie | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: You know you need more yoga, but motivation isn’t always easy. This is why we’re giving you the best reward for yoga ever: the chai green smoothie!
ingredients:
s:653:"
  • ½ frozen banana
  • 1 large handful of kale or spinach
  • 1 scoop Warrior Blend Sunwarrior vanilla protein
  • 1–2 pitted Medjool dates
  • 1 pinch sea salt
  • The contents of 1 chai tea bag
  • ⅔ cups almond milk (or more if you like your smoothies more liquidy)
  • ½–1 tablespoon almond butter
";
directions:
1.) BLEND!

2.) Enjoy!

articleBodyHTML:
Substantially filling while also being substantially slimming, this bean and quinoa power salad has all the right stuff!

Various green leaves by themselves do not make a very substantial meal. Within a few hours of eating a basic veggie salad, you’re hungry again, but if you take up another notch by adding some power foods like beans and quinoa, it’s called a Power Salad! It becomes very filling and leaves you not wanting more until the next meal.

This salad is very quick especially if you already have cooked quinoa on hand. It's basically popping open a few cans and mixing them together. One of the most important ingredients is the hummus. Hummus is very delicious and is basically just garbanzo beans pureed. If you like spicy, get a spicy red pepper flavor. You won’t be sorry!

Garbanzo and great northern beans are an excellent source of protein. They also pack folate, manganese, and fiber. Quinoa also has a lot of protein and has similar nutritional value as the beans with zinc added in.
articleSummaryHTML: Substantially filling while also being substantially slimming, this bean and quinoa power salad has all the right stuff!
seoTitle: How to Make Bean and Quinoa Power Salad | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Substantially filling while also being substantially slimming, Sunwarrior's bean and quinoa power salad has all the right stuff! Check out this recipe!
ingredients:
s:641:"
  • 1 15.5 oz. can Great Northern Beans, drained and rinsed
  • 1 15.5 oz. garbanzo beans (chickpeas), drained and rinsed
  • 1 ½ cups cooked quinoa
  • 1 roasted red pepper, chopped
  • 1 roasted yellow or orange pepper, chopped
  • 1 cucumber, cubed
  • 1 lime
  • 2–3 slices red onion (optional)
  • 1 container grape or cherry tomatoes OR 3 to 4 chopped Roma tomatoes
  • 2 large heads of Romaine lettuce or desired greens mixture
  • ½ cup hummus
  • Light balsamic vinaigrette, if desired
  • Sea salt to taste
";
directions:
1. Add both cans of beans, peppers, and quinoa to a bowl. Combine well. Season with sea salt and lime. Set aside.
  2. Take an extra-large bowl and add all lettuce, tomatoes, cucumber, and onions, if using. Combine well. Then add all the bean mixture to lettuce mixture and mix well.
  3. When serving, dish out the salad and add a dollop of hummus on top and drizzle dressing on, if desired.

articleBodyHTML:
Throw another pizza on the BBQ! That’s right. Pizza! On the grill! Grilled pizza is perfect for those hot summer nights that are coming soon.

Grilled pizza is a fun way to make dinner. Who wants to heat up the house when it's already hot outside? Let the heat stay outside. Fire up your grill and enjoy a delicious comfort food!

Pizza is so versatile. Basically, you can add any ingredients that your heart desires. Empty out your fridge and use up all your leftovers. Peppers, mushrooms, artichokes, squash, BBQ sauce, and Alfredo.

When cooking a pizza on a grill, it can be tricky. But don’t be intimidated. Warm the grill up well before cooking anything. Once the dough is rolled out very evenly, cook one side until it is a light golden brown. This can happen very quickly if you aren’t paying attention. My pizza has gone from almost done to burned in just a matter of moments on several occasions.

This particular pizza recipe is favorite when we have a plethora of tomatoes during harvest season. Fresh basil is delicious, but you can use dried in a pinch. Tomatoes are high in fiber and a good source of vitamin A, C, B2, folate, and chromium. Not only does basil add exquisite flavor, but it is also loaded with vitamins A and K. The whole wheat crust adds essential fiber and has been shown to reduce the risk of diabetes and heart disease. It also is high B vitamins, and vitamin E.

Time to get grilling!
articleSummaryHTML: Throw another pizza on the BBQ! That’s right. Pizza! On the grill! Grilled pizza is perfect for those hot summer nights that are coming soon.
seoTitle: Vegan Pizza: Get Grilled! | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Throw another pizza on the BBQ! That’s right. Pizza! On the grill! Grilled pizza is perfect for those hot summer nights that are coming soon.
ingredients:
s:713:"

Pizza Dough

  • 2 1/4 teaspoons (one 1/4 ounce package) active dry yeast
  • 1 cup warm water
  • 2 teaspoons agave or favorite sweetener
  • 2 1/4 cups whole wheat flour, plus more for dusting
  • 3/4 teaspoons salt
  • 1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil

Pizza

  • 3 tablespoons olive oil
  • 1 ⅓ cup vegan mozzarella
  • 2 Roma tomatoes, sliced thinly
  • ¼ cup grated vegan parmesan
  • 1 large clove of garlic, minced
  • 4–6 fresh basil leaves
  • ½ teaspoon salt
  • Extra oil for brushing on dough
";
directions:
1. To make dough: Dissolve yeast and agave in a small bowl. Let sit for 5 minutes.
  2. Add 2 cups flour and salt into a large bowl and mix well. Add yeast mixture and stir until the dough comes together and is smooth. You may not need all or any of the flour.
  3. Let dough rest for 10 mins.
  4. Warm up the grill to medium heat.
  5. Once dough as rested. Divide the dough into two equal parts. Roll each piece out evenly. Brush the dough with the extra oil. You don’t want the dough to stick to the grill.
  6. Once the grill is fully warmed, lay one piece of dough down on the grill. Let the dough cook about 5 mins or so. It depends on how hot your grill is. You want it to be light brown. Once it is light brown, I like to flip it and cook the other side briefly, 1 to 2 mins. Remove from grill.
  7. Rub olive oil over the side you cooked the longest. Top the crust with cheese, then tomatoes. Then parmesan. Then sprinkle the garlic and basil all over the pizza.
  8. Put the pizza on the grill and cook until the cheese is melted and the dough is light brown on the bottom about 5 mins.
  9. Repeat all steps with the other piece of dough.

articleBodyHTML:
Whether a full meal or a side dish, this quinoa shitake edamame pilaf will be the star of dinner!

Shitake mushrooms are known to be extremely beneficial to the immune system. They contain antiviral and antitumor agents. They are rich in Vitamin D and are a good source of minerals. When they are cooked and added to a recipe, their unique flavor enhances a dish to make it earthy, savory, and grounding. If you can’t find fresh versions of it, you can always use dried. They add a lot of flavor to any broth or any dish.
articleSummaryHTML: Whether a full meal or a side dish, this quinoa shitake edamame pilaf will be the star of dinner!
seoTitle: Quinoa Shitake Edamame Pilaf | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Whether a full meal or a side dish, this quinoa shitake edamame pilaf from Sunwarrior will be the star of dinner! Try it today and see just how easy it is.
ingredients:
s:848:"

 

  • 1 ½ cups water
  • 1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil
  • 1 small yellow onion, diced
  • ½ cup chopped carrot
  • 2 cloves garlic, minced
  • ½ teaspoon salt
  • 1 cup shiitake mushroom caps, sliced
  • 1 sprig fresh or ¼ teaspoon dried rosemary leaves
  • 1 cup red quinoa
  • ½ cup soaked arame (sea vegetable)
  • ½ cup cooked shelled edamame beans (steamed for 3 minutes)
  • Parsley or rosemary sprigs for garnish
";
directions:
1. Rinse and drain quinoa. Add to pot and dry toast for 1–2 minutes on medium heat until the water has evaporated and the quinoa smells nutty.

2. Add the water and rosemary and bring to a boil and then simmer for 12–15 minutes.

3. In a separate pan, heat olive oil on a low to medium heat.

4. Add onion and sauté until golden.

5. Add carrots, garlic, and salt and sauté for about 30 seconds.

6. Add shiitake mushrooms and sauté until mushrooms are just tender.

7. Remove cooked quinoa and place into a large bowl. Add in steamed edamame, arame, and sautéed vegetables, stir once or twice to mix together.

8. Serve hot. May be served as an entrée or a side grain dish. Garnish with rosemary or parsley sprigs.

This pilaf can be served warm or cold which makes it incredibly diverse to enjoy during the week. If you want to make into a full meal, you can pair it with even more protein such as organic tofu and tempeh. It also tastes great on top of a bed of raw or steamed greens.

articleBodyHTML:
This strawberry banana bread is moist and luscious! And if you’re looking for an amazing healthy snack, this is the place where you’re search is over.

Looking for something delicious to bake without having to drag out the mixer or spend more than 10 minutes prep time? This recipe is for you! Minimal ingredients, and if you’re not crazy about strawberries, then use whatever else you like. Vegan chocolate chips, peaches, or blueberries are great options. You will have this batter put together before the oven even heats up. Great for breakfast, a snack, or even as a dessert with a small scoop of ice cream! This recipe makes one large loaf, or 3 mini loaves. I like to make them in mini bread tins and give to friends and family. Have fun cooking!
articleSummaryHTML: This strawberry banana bread is moist and luscious! And if you’re looking for an amazing healthy snack, this is the place where you’re search is over.
seoTitle: How to Make Vegan Strawberry Banana Bread | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: This strawberry banana bread is moist and luscious! And if you’re looking for an amazing healthy snack, this is the place where you’re search is over.
ingredients:
s:294:"
  • 3 mashed bananas
  • 1 cup vegan mayo (bought or made)
  • ⅓ cup coconut sugar
  • ¼ agave nectar
  • 2 cups whole wheat flour
  • 2 teaspoons baking soda
  • 1 teaspoons allspice
  • 1 cup strawberries, chopped
";
directions:
Mix mayo and banana’s into a large bowl.

Stir in agave.

Sift sugar, flour, allspice, and baking soda into the mixture and stir until incorporated.

Add strawberries and gently combine.

Bake at 350 for 45 minutes if you are baking a large loaf. Bake for 35 minutes if you are doing mini loaves.

articleBodyHTML:
Savor the flavor of creamy, chocolate-y mousse where every bite is so mm-mazing, you won’t even know it’s good for you!

Chocolate is divine. Delicious. Decadent. Healthy. Really nothing better. I’m sure there are some who would disagree but overall, most people like chocolate. Chocolate has a tremendous antioxidant potential if there is a high cocoa content. When paired with coconut cream, this dessert becomes the king of healthy desserts!

Coconut cream does have fat but it’s a healthy fat, not like its non-vegan cousin. Coconut cream belongs to the medium chain fatty acids. They are smaller in size than long-chain fatty acids, so they burn quicker and our bodies won’t store it in fat tissues for reserve.

Cocoa has wonderful health benefits. Besides being an antioxidant, it can also help lower LDL cholesterol and high blood pressure. It can also be an antidepressant because it contains phenethylamine.

A recipe with only four ingredients with no cooking required will be a go-to when you need something quick and delicious. You can add a splash of Vitamin Mineral Rush to add some extra health benefits to your dessert!
articleSummaryHTML: Savor the flavor of creamy, chocolate-y mousse where every bite is so mm-mazing, you won’t even know it’s good for you!
seoTitle: Vegan Chocolate Mousse | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Savor the flavor of creamy, chocolate-y mousse where every bite is so mm-mazing, you won’t even know it’s good for you!
ingredients:
s:333:"
  • 2 13.7 oz. coconut cream
  • 1 13.7 oz. coconut milk
  • 3 tablespoons agave nectar
  • 4 to 5 tablespoons unsweetened cocoa powder
";
directions:
Place all cans of coconut cream and milk in the fridge overnight. Without shaking the cans, open and scoop out the cream and milk and place in a bowl. Reserve any coconut water for another use. Add the sweetener and mix until thick and creamy.

If desired, reserve about 1/3 cup of coconut cream to top the mousse.

Stir the cocoa powder into the remaining thickened cream. Spoon into serving dishes and refrigerate until set. Top with reserved coconut cream and serve.

articleBodyHTML:
These vegan peanut butter ganache cookies are packed with all the good stuff that make them so scrumptious you’ll want more than one!

If that was not enough, they are dipped in a ganache taking your taste buds to a whole new level of happiness! Recipe makes approximately 24 cookies.
articleSummaryHTML: These vegan peanut butter ganache cookies are packed with all the good stuff that make them so scrumptious you’ll want more than one!
seoTitle: Vegan Peanut Butter Ganache Cookies | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: These vegan peanut butter ganache cookies are packed with all the good stuff that make them so scrumptious you’ll want more than one!
ingredients:
s:540:"
  • 1 cup (4 oz) vegan butter, softened
  • 3 cups oats
  • 1 cup peanut butter
  • 1 teaspoon cardamom
  • ½ cup sugar
  • 1 teaspoon cinnamon
  • ½ cup coconut sugar
  • ½ teaspoon nutmeg
  • 2 tablespoons coconut oil
  • ½ teaspoon salt
  • 1 tablespoon cornstarch + 2 tablespoons water (mixture)
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla
  • 1 ½ teaspoons baking soda
  • Raw chocolate nibs or nuts (handful)
";
directions:
1. Preheat oven to 350. In a large bowl, mix butter, sugars, and peanut butter until creamy with a hand mixer. Add in coconut oil, baking soda and cornstarch mixture. Combine all together.

2. Using a wooden spoon, stir in remaining ingredients, oats, spices, vanilla, nibs, and nuts until well incorporated.

3. Spoon out heaping tablespoons of cookie dough onto cookie sheet leaving a little space in between each cookie. Once all in place, gently flatten the tops with your fingers. These cookies will spread a little, but not too much.

4. Bake for approximately 17–20 minutes. Let cool slightly before removing onto a cooling rack. These cookies can crumble easily if you move them before cooling.

5. Make your favorite vegan ganache and dip these cookies and then chill in fridge to harden ganache (about 30 minutes). So worth your while to take this step. It takes your cookies to another level. Enjoy!

articleBodyHTML:
It’s childhood in a glass with this peanut butter &jelly smoothie. Yep . . . a glass full of health and happiness with a sprinkle of innocence.

A peanut butter and jelly sandwich was a staple in my household growing up. I used to be all about the bread when I was a kid, but know as an adult, my stomach can’t take the gluten. Even gluten-free bread makes me feel terrible and inflamed. I wanted to recreate my favorite childhood sandwich but healthier. After many trial and errors, you will be pleasantly surprised how close it tastes like the sandwich without the bread.
articleSummaryHTML: It’s childhood in a glass with this peanut butter &jelly smoothie. Yep . . . a glass full of health and happiness with a sprinkle of innocence.
seoTitle: Peanut Butter & Jelly Smoothie
seoDescription: It’s childhood in a glass with this peanut butter &jelly smoothie. Yep . . . a glass full of health and happiness with a sprinkle of innocence.
ingredients:
s:662:"
  • 1 frozen banana
  • ½ cup frozen strawberries
  • ½ cup fresh strawberries
  • 2 tablespoons of peanut butter powder
  • 1 scoop in Sunwarrior Vanilla Classic Plus
  • ½–1 cup water
  • Ice
  • Drizzle peanut butter on top of smoothie for garnish
  • Slice strawberries for garnish on top
";
directions:
Blend all ingredients in a blender until smooth. You can add more ice for an ice cream texture. Pour into a fancy glass and drizzle with peanut butter and sliced strawberries. If your peanut butter is thick, scoop a tablespoon or two in a pan and heat up; it should be easier to drizzle when warm. Then add sliced strawberries on top and enjoy!

Benefits of a Peanut Butter and Strawberry Smoothie

Peanut butter has protein and healthy fat, meaning this smoothie will keep you satiated longer. The peanuts also have vitamin E that protects your body from free radical damage. The strawberries are high in vitamin C and have tons of antioxidants to correct free radicals as well.

Fun Fact

Did you know that food historians do not know exactly when the peanut butter and jelly sandwich was first prepared? There have been no advertisements or mentions of peanut butter and jelly before the 1940s. Peanut butter wasn't invented until 1890, and it became a hit at the 1904 World's Fair in St. Louis. The first reference of peanut butter paired with jelly on bread to be published in the United States was by Julia Davis Chandler in 1901 in the Boston Cooking-School Magazine of Culinary Science and Domestic Economics.

Spread the love real thick

articleBodyHTML:
Cue the music “If you like Pina Coladas and getting caught in the rain…” and if you’re not into the whole rain thing, you can still have an awesome Pina Colada smoothie

Treat yourself to an island paradise with this tropical smoothie. There is something about the summertime that makes you want a fun, fruity drink with an umbrella next to the water. The first one that comes to my mind is a Pina Colada. This creamy smoothie will make you think you are indulging in a decadent drink minus the rum. Once this sweet drink hits your lips, it will feel like an instant beach vacation. Feel free to indulge anytime you need a break from reality.

ingredients:
s:581:"
  • 1 frozen banana
  • 1–2 cups frozen pineapple chunks
  • A couple chunks of fresh coconut
  • ½–1 cup coconut milk or water
  • 1 scoop of Sunwarrior Vanilla Classic Plus
  • Handful of ice
  • Pineapple for garnish
  • Little umbrella for fun
";
directions:
Blend all ingredients in a blender until smooth. You can add more ice for an ice cream texture. Pour into a fancy glass and garnish with pineapple. Envision you are on a beach vacay to complete to the taste.

Benefits of Pineapple

Pineapples are a delicious tropical fruit not only for their taste but for their health benefits, too. It includes respiratory health, digestion improvement, weight loss help, bone strengthening, oral health improvement, eye health boost, skin improvement, inflammation reduction, and heart health improvement. Pineapples are a great source of vitamins and minerals that include thiamin, riboflavin, Vitamin C and B-6, folate, magnesium, and potassium.

Fun Fact

Pineapples were first brought to Europe and Spain following Christopher Columbus’s return there in 1493. Historically, the most significant grower of pineapples was Hawaii, but now they are cultivated in Brazil, Philippines, Costa Rica, and Thailand. Pineapples are actually native to Paraguay and Brazil.

Be a pineapple: stand tall, wear a crown, and be sweet on the inside

articleBodyHTML:
As summer is upon us, we’re all searching for a heartier salad which is healthy and nutritious. This couscous salad with its Middle Eastern flare means the search is over.

Salads are best when they are bursting with different textures, crunches, and freshness. This salad is vibrant and without a trace of guilt in it! This pretty salad is super easy to make, delicious to eat, and gorgeous to look at. This salad is filled with herbs, vegetables, and spices. We use a delicious tarragon dressing for extra flavor. You can always omit the tarragon for any herb of choice such as basil or parsley. With this salad, you can add any additional fruits, vegetables, or spices.

So what exactly is pearl couscous? Pearl couscous is also called Israeli couscous. It is made out of semolina or wheat and typically doesn’t have much flavor. Before you boil the couscous, you can slightly toast the couscous in a pan to give a beautiful nuttiness to the grain. It is similar to small balls of pasta. Since this ingredient is so versatile, it will work well with any dish. When you cook it with a delicious vegetable stock and herbs, it adds a great flavor profile to it. Although not a gluten-free grain, it is low on the glycemic index making it healthy and rich in fiber. Couscous is also rich in vitamins and minerals such as calcium, protein, and selenium. Couscous at times may be difficult to find. You can always check your local Middle Eastern supermarket or Middle Eastern section in your grocery store.

This couscous salad is perfect as a dinner or lunch the following day. Toss it in an airtight container or a mason jar and voila! The longer the herbs and dressing soak into the couscous, the tastier it gets. You can add some chopped nuts, seeds, or lettuce greens to add different flavors and textures.
articleSummaryHTML: As summer is upon us, we’re all searching for a heartier salad which is healthy and nutritious. This couscous salad with its Middle Eastern flare means the search is over.
seoTitle: Couscous Vegan Plant Based Salad | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: As summer is upon us, we’re all searching for a heartier salad which is healthy and nutritious. This couscous salad with its Middle Eastern flare means the search is over.
ingredients:
s:862:"
  • Couscous:
  • 1 package couscous
  • 2 cups vegetable stock
  • 1 scallion, chopped
  • 1/3 cup cranberries
  • 1 tomato, seeded and cubed
  • 1 cup chopped flat leaf parsley
  • 1/2 cup chopped red onions
  • 1 cup lentils

Tarragon dressing:

  • 1 shallot, minced
  • 1 bundle tarragon, chopped
  • 1/4 cup lemon juice
  • 1 tablespoon Dijon mustard
  • 2 tablespoons olive oil
";
directions:
1.) Preheat a pan over medium heat with 1 tablespoon of olive oil. Add couscous and toast for 2 minutes. Remove from heat and add 2 cups of vegetable broth. Cook according to the package.

2.) Add chopped scallions, dried cranberries, tomatoes, parsley, red onion, and lentils

3.) In a small bowl add all dressing ingredients. Drizzle on couscous and serve.

4.) Leftovers can be stored in an airtight container in the fridge.

articleBodyHTML:
Fire up the grill and get your saucy on! BBQ that is! Because nothing says summer’s here like the king of sauces: the BBQ sauce!

Sometimes sweet and brown, sometimes red and hot (and often something in between), barbecue sauce is thick with American history and culture.

Visit Memphis or North Carolina, and your sauce would likely be tomato based; in contrast, head down to South Carolina for a mustard-heavy sauce. In Alabama, BBQ often features a unique mayo-and-vinegar mix.

The most popular type of modern barbecue sauce is probably the Kansas City style, dominated by ketchup. Usually served on pork, beef, and chicken, barbecue is usually thought of as a carnivore’s condiment.

If you’re looking for something new, try my Best Homemade BBQ sauce on for size. Slather it on your favorite veggie burger or use it as a dipping sauce for crudités. You can even make BBQ chips by brushing the sauce onto potato slices (2mm or so thick) and dehydrating until crisp.
articleSummaryHTML: Fire up the grill and get your saucy on! BBQ that is! Because nothing says summer’s here like the king of sauces: the BBQ sauce!
seoTitle: Best Homemade BBQ Sauce | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Fire up the grill and get your saucy on! BBQ that is! Because nothing says summer’s here like the king of sauces: the BBQ sauce!
ingredients:
s:701:"
  • ¾ cup sun-dried tomatoes, with just enough water to cover
  • (about 1–2 cups)
  • 2 teaspoons onion powder
  • ¼ teaspoon cayenne pepper
  • ½ teaspoon chipotle pepper powder
  • 2 tablespoons chopped onion
  • 2 tablespoons Rapadura (dehydrated cane juice sweetener)
  • 1 tablespoon honey (or agave syrup)
  • 1 tablespoon yacon syrup or coconut nectar
  • 1 tablespoon prepared organic mustard
  • 2 tablespoons tamari
  • ½ tablespoon fresh ginger root, chopped
  • 1 clove garlic
  • 1/8 teaspoon pepper
  • 1 teaspoon apple cider vinegar
";
directions: Blend all ingredients on high until smooth, adding more water if necessary. Will keep in a glass jar in the refrigerator for five days.

articleTitle: Mattern’s Miracle Mixer with Apple Cider Vinegar
articleBodyHTML:

Leading a life to include intense training sessions or even casual encounters with public surfaces such as restrooms or shopping carts can leave your immune system pretty shaken up. Luckily, there are steps we can take to mitigate the risks by boosting our immunity via whole plant food. The following recipe is a tonic I take every morning to insure my own immunity, to promote probiotic gut health. and to bolster my body’s anti-inflammatory response.
