Snow cones were always synonymous with fairs, carnivals, and fun. These classic carnival treats are something I still crave as an adult. In retrospect, those snow cones were loaded with food colorings and sugar.

Working for a healthier treat that gives the same happy refreshing feelings, these frozen treats are great for the little ones or adults

These snow cones are ridiculously easy to make and come together in less than two minutes.  Forget the beautiful pictures on the internet of lavish desserts that are so visually appealing (and also very time consuming). It’s summer, you want something refreshing and fast!

You can choose an assortment of fruits to use. We used a watermelon juice as the “syrup” alongside some wild blueberries and sour cherries. Watermelon is it’s loaded with vitamins and minerals and keeps you hydrated in the hot weather.

Forget the sugar filled syrups. All you need is your favorite juice to top your snow cone. If watermelon isn’t your favorite, you can use pineapple, orange, pear, or apple.
articleSummaryHTML: Before summer’s gone, indulge in the best summer has to offer: snow cones! Fruity and refreshing and so, so good!
seoTitle: Fruitastic Snow Cones! | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Before summer’s gone, indulge in the best summer has to offer: snow cones! Fruity and refreshing and so, so good!
ingredients:
s:213:"
  • 1/2 cup fresh juice of choice
  • 1 cup ice
  • 1 cup fresh fruit (blueberries, strawberries, pineapple, mango)
";
directions:
1. You don’t need a snow cone maker. Just place your ice cubes in a high-speed blender and pulse until ice is a snowy powder! Top with fruit juice and fruit of your choice.
  2. Enjoy!

Alternatively, you can make coconut snow. Simply place a can of coconut milk in a container in the freezer. Remove from freezer and place into food processor. This magical coconut snow will melt into a creamy and rich mixture.

articleBodyHTML:
Summer just got real with this watermelon soup that is cool, refreshing, and filled with sweetness that feels a little sinful. Use the big spoon.

When you visit the grocery store, you typically notice two types of watermelon: seeded and seedless. But did you know there are over 1200 varieties grown throughout the world? That’s a lotta melon! The selections are nearly endless: seeded or seedless, three-pound mini melons up to record-breaking 250-pounders, red, yellow, pink, orange. With any of these options, you also get some pretty great benefits—watermelons are about 92% water (think hydration!), contain the antioxidant lycopene (which may boost your sun-screening power), and they’re cholesterol-free, fat-free, and sodium-free. No matter which type you’re eating, one thing is common to all of them: their sweet, thirst-quenching meat is perfect for summertime and early fall enjoyment. My chilled soup combines the melon with sweet wine, grapes, raisins and a mint topper—summertime 2.0!

This recipe calls for seedless, ruby red watermelon—but feel free to experiment! Just note that different cultivars will alter the taste. I don’t recommend changing up the seedless part, though; it’s best to avoid the bitterness that results after seeds are pureed by the blender. (If you must buy seeded melon, my recommendation would be to remove those kernels before whipping up your soup.)

To amp up the natural sweetness of the melon, we’re using a couple of sweeteners: sweet wine and coconut nectar. If you choose not to use wine, try substituting kombucha instead or white grape juice. You may also choose to substitute agave nectar or something similar for the coconut nectar if you want, but don’t stray too far—use of maple syrup, honey, or a similar sweetener would change the flavor of the dish significantly and is not recommended.

Remember to add your mint last, so it doesn’t infuse too long and overshadow the delicate watermelon flavor in the soup.

One last tip: Watermelon Soup is best consumed the same day it’s made.
articleSummaryHTML: Summer just got real with this watermelon soup that is cool, refreshing, and filled with sweetness that feels a little sinful. Use the big spoon.
seoTitle: Cooling Off with Watermelon Soup | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Summer just got real with this watermelon soup that is cool, refreshing, and filled with sweetness that feels a little sinful. Use the big spoon.
ingredients:
s:527:"

 

  • 8 cups seedless watermelon, chopped
  • 1/4 cup sweet white wine (or white grape juice for those avoiding the alcohol)
  • 2 tablespoons coconut nectar
  • Pinch unrefined sea salt
  • 1 cup green seedless grapes
  • 1 cup golden raisins
  • 2 tablespoons  fresh mint, chopped
";
directions: Combine the watermelon, wine, coconut nectar and salt in a blender and puree until very smooth. Transfer to a bowl and stir in the raisins and grapes. Chill for at least 2 hours. Serve cold, garnished with mint.

articleBodyHTML:
For a bite of true bliss, these vegan caramel peanut butter bites make the perfect dessert!

These indulgent slices make a great snack or an after-dinner treat. They look and taste extremely naughty but all the ingredients are healthy and natural, so you don’t have to worry if you eat one, or five too many! They are super quick and easy to make, and you can store them in the freezer for as long as you like without worrying that they might go off (that is if you can resist eating them all at once). (makes 12–14 slices)
articleSummaryHTML: For a bite of true bliss, these vegan caramel peanut butter bites make the perfect dessert!
seoTitle: Vegan Caramel Peanut Butter Bites | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: For a bite of true bliss, these vegan caramel peanut butter bites make the perfect dessert! Check out our recipe for vegan caramel peanut butter bites.
ingredients:
s:506:"

For the Base

  • 1 3/4 cups rolled oats
  • 3 tablespoons maple syrup
  • 3 tablespoons peanut butter
  • 2 tablespoons coconut oil

For the Caramel

  • 1 1/2 cup soft dates
  • 1/3 cup water
  • 2 tablespoons peanut butter + 3 extra tablespoons.

For the Chocolate

  • 4 oz. dark chocolate
  • 3 tablespoons coconut oil
";
directions:
To make the base, blend the oats in a food processor or high-speed blender until flour forms. Add maple syrup, peanut butter, and melted coconut oil, and blend everything until dough forms. It should have a wet and easy to from consistency.

Lay a square baking tray with greaseproof paper and press the dough firmly into the bottom and then set aside.

To make the caramel, put the dates, water, and 2 tablespoons peanut butter into a food processor and blend until smooth caramel forms. This might take a good few minutes. When ready, spread the caramel evenly on top of the base. Then spread a thin layer of the remaining peanut butter on the top of the caramel and put the tray in the freezer for at least 30 min.

To make the chocolate layer, melt the coconut oil on low heat, then add chopped chocolate and stir until smooth, but be careful not to burn it. Set aside for 5 min to cool down slightly. Take the tray out of the freezer and pour the chocolate on top of the peanut butter layer. Put back in the freezer for another 30 min.

Take out of the freezer and cut into 12–14 square slices. Store in the freezer.

articleBodyHTML: Dessert just got real with this vegan blueberry fireweed cheesecake. Fragrant and filled with flavor, this vegan “cheesecake” will hit all those dessert happy places!
articleSummaryHTML: Dessert just got real with this vegan blueberry fireweed cheesecake. Fragrant and filled with flavor, this vegan “cheesecake” will hit all those dessert happy places!
seoTitle: Vegan Blueberry Fireweed Cheesecake! | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Dessert just got real with this vegan blueberry fireweed cheesecake. Fragrant and filled with flavor, this vegan “cheesecake” will hit all those happy places!
ingredients:
s:972:"

Crust

  • ¾ cup of oatmeal flour
  • ½ cup of coconut flour
  • 1 teaspoon baking powder
  • ½ teaspoon pink salt
  • 2 tablespoons olive oil or coconut oil
  • About 6–8 tablespoons water

Filling

  • 1 pint of blueberries, fresh
  • 1 ½ cup of fireweed blossoms (save a few for decoration on the top afterward!)
  • ½ cup agave (or liquid sweetener of your choice)
  • 1 tablespoon lemon juice
  • 1 ½ package of soft tofu (about 20 oz. total)
  • ½ teaspoon cinnamon
";
directions:
Crust

Mix dry ingredients together then add the oil and water; do this one tablespoon at a time, mixing until you get a crumbly consistency, then add 4 tablespoons more water. Press into a pie pan (9 or 10-inch diameter is fine), bake at 300 degrees uncovered for 15 minutes, or until golden brown. Take out and let cool while you are making the filling.

Filling

Blend tofu, cinnamon, lemon juice, and honey together until completely mixed. Transfer to a bowl, and use a spatula to mix the blueberries and blossoms in.

Pour this on top of the already baked crust.

Place back in the oven at 350 degrees for 25–30 minutes.  It should be golden brown on top, with the blueberries bursting open!

Place some extra blossoms on top when it comes out of the oven, and ENJOY!

articleBodyHTML:
There is nothing like the flavors and color of a Moroccan dish! A healthy, amazingly tasty dish your taste buds will thank you for, dinner has never been better!

This is a take on a traditional Moroccan tagine. However, this one is loaded with pure plant-based ingredients that are full of protein and fiber. The rice is replaced with quinoa, but brown basmati rice can easily be used. The dried fruit complements the savory accents of the Moroccan spices in this tagine. You don’t actually need a tagine to cook it in, although it would add to the experience.

What so wonderful about this dish is that it is fully loaded and colorful. It also yields quite a bit so you can enjoy it over several days or invite lots of people over to enjoy it with you. Feel free to change up the vegetables depending on the season.
articleSummaryHTML: There is nothing like the flavors and color of a Moroccan dish! A healthy, amazingly tasty dish your taste buds will thank you for, dinner has never been better!
seoTitle: Savory Vegetable Tagine | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: There is nothing like the flavors and color of a Moroccan dish! A healthy amazingly tasty dish your taste buds will thank you for dinner has never been better.
ingredients:
s:1726:"

Roasted Squash & Beans

  • 1 cup dry white lima beans, soaked overnight
  • 2 butternut squash, peeled and cubed into 1/2 inch cubes
  • 1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
  • 1 teaspoon sea salt
  • 1 tablespoon grapeseed oil

Braised Greens

  • 1 bunch collards or kale, washed and chopped
  • 2 cloves garlic, peeled and crushed
  • 3 tablespoons grapeseed oil
  • 1 cup quinoa, rinsed and dry toasted

Veggies

  • 2 red onions, sliced
  • 3 tablespoons grapeseed oil
  • 1 onion, diced into small cubes
  • 3 carrots, peeled and diced into small cubes
  • 4 parsnips, peeled and diced into small cubes
  • 2 tablespoons lemon zest
  • 1/4 teaspoon ground cumin
  • 1/4 teaspoon turmeric
  • 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
  • 4 cups vegetable stock, water, or bean cooking water
  • 2 cans diced organic tomatoes
  • 1/4 cup dried prunes or raisins, rehydrated
  • 1/2 cup dried apricots, rehydrated
  • Sea salt to taste
";
directions:
1. Preheat oven to 400F.

2. Combine beans and water to cover in a small stockpot. Bring the beans to a boil, reduce the heat, then cover and simmer until beans are tender (approximately 1 hour).

Check the beans occasionally for readiness and to make sure they are covered with cooking liquid.

3. Rinse quinoa and dry toast in a saucepan until the water has been absorbed. Pour 2 cups of water with sea salt in the pot. Bring to a boil and simmer for 15 minutes.

4. Toss butternut squash with 1 tablespoon oil, cinnamon, and sea salt. Roast in the oven for 35 minutes or until just tender.

5. Caramelize red onion in a pan with 1 tablespoon oil.

6. In a small stock pot, heat 3 tablespoons of oil and garlic for 5–7 minutes and add collards. Reduce heat and cover. Braise for 15–20 minutes, adding oil as needed.

7. In a medium stockpot, heat 2 tablespoons of oil. Add onion, carrot, parsnip and sauté until tender

8. Add lemon, cumin, turmeric, and cinnamon, toss to coat.

9. Add vegetable stock, tomatoes and dried fruit. Simmer for 30 minutes. Salt and adjust seasonings to taste.

10. Fold in the roasted squash and beans. Simmer for 5 minutes.

11. Serve over quinoa and braised collards.

articleBodyHTML:
Sass up your salads with quinoa! Tired of the typical barbecue side dishes? Shake it up with an amazing quinoa salad.

Barbeque season is in full force for a little while longer. It's a great time to interact with our friends and family and eat food! I truthfully get tired of the same old green and macaroni salads. I want something delicious and healthy and not boring! Too much to ask? No. This delicious quinoa salad is filling and delectable and actually tastes even better if you refrigerate it beforehand. The flavors mix well and are so scrumptious!

Quinoa is high in protein and is one of the few grains that has all nine essential amino acids. It also is chock full of protein and so good for you heart. Black beans also have a lot of protein and fiber. They also are loaded with antioxidants that help protect you against cancer.

So why don’t you quit taking that boring lettuce and macaroni salad to get-togethers and take something worth eating!
articleSummaryHTML: Sass up your salads with quinoa! Tired of the typical barbecue side dishes? Shake it up with an amazing quinoa salad.
seoTitle: How to Make the Best Zesty Quinoa Salad | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Sass up your salads with quinoa! Tired of the typical barbecue side dishes? Shake it up with an amazing quinoa salad.
ingredients:
s:426:"
  • 2 cups quinoa
  • 4 cups vegetable broth
  • 1 can shoepeg corn, drained
  • 1 can black beans, drained
  • 1 red pepper, chopped finely
  • ½ red onion, chopped finely
  • ½ bunch cilantro, chopped finely
  • ½ cup vegan cheese
  • 1 cup craisins
  • 2 limes
  • 1 tablespoon lime olive oil or plain olive oil
";
directions:
1. Add quinoa and the broth to a rice cooker and cook until done. Allow quinoa to cool.
  2. Once cool, add remainder of ingredients and mix well. Taste and add more lime juice, if desired. Refrigerate for a few hours before serving if possible.

articleBodyHTML:
Give your grill some love with these cilantro lime tofu kebabs! There’s no better way to celebrate in season foods!

One second summer is here, the next it’s gone in a flash. Summer vegetables should be celebrated and loved just as much as everything else that goes on to the grill! Depending on where you live, different vegetables will be in season and fresh. Currently, fresh zucchini and corn are everywhere. When grilling these vegetables, we are simply cooking the exterior to give a beautiful smoky flavor while the nutrients stay mostly intact inside. Marinating the tofu overnight will ensure that we really soak up the flavors of the herbs, spices, oils, and citrus you are trying to absorb. The next day, all you need is to fire up the grill, and you got yourself a wicked meal!

Feel free to customize your kebabs by adding mushrooms, onions or peppers!
articleSummaryHTML: Give your grill some love with these cilantro lime tofu kebabs! There’s no better way to celebrate in season foods!
seoTitle: Cilantro Lime Tofu Kebabs | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Give your grill some love with these cilantro lime tofu kebabs! There’s no better way to celebrate in season foods!
ingredients:
s:514:"
  • 1 package extra firm tofu
  • 1 cup chopped zucchini 
  • 10 grape tomatoes
  • 1/4 cup lime juice
  • 1 tablespoon avocado oil
  • 1/4 cup fresh cilantro
  • 1 clove garlic
  • 1 teaspoon cayenne powder 
  • Himalayan salt and pepper
";
directions:
1.) Remove tofu from package and drain water. Place tofu in a Ziplock bag with cilantro, avocado oil, garlic, cayenne, salt, and pepper. Shake well and place in fridge for 12–24 hours to marinate

2.) Preheat grill. Remove tofu from package. Dice into cubes and place on skewers along with mixed vegetables. Grill for 5 minutes on each side. Remove from heat and serve.

There are so many great marinades for these kebabs. This recipe uses a cilantro lime marinade. You can also play around with different marinades such as:

Japanese Marinade

  • 1/4 cup tamari
  • 3/4 mirin

Greek

  • 1/3 cup olive oil
  • 1/4 cup lemon juice
  • 2 garlic cloves
  • 1 tablespoon oregano 

Middle Eastern

  • 1 tablespoon cardamom
  • 1 tablespoon cumin
  • 2 crushed garlic cloves
  • Salt, pinch
  • 1/3 cup olive oil
  • 1/2 cup lemon juice

articleBodyHTML:
Breakfast: when it’s the most important meal of the day, it should taste spectacular. So, we’ve given you spectacular with this mango berry coconut parfait.

Many people are intimidated by the idea of coming up with recipes, but the truth is, it’s pretty easy. Once you begin to trust your instincts, all you have to do is open your mind (and mouth!) up to the concept of flavor combining. One place to begin is with seasonal produce. Edible plants that come to maturity at the same time often taste good together (think tomatoes and basil). The same rule of thumb applies to crops that grow in the same region, such as tropical fruits.

Blending the meat from a young coconut with its own water will yield a luscious light pudding or a thick cream, depending on the ratio you use. For the thicker result, use less of the water. And don’t let fear of opening a young coconut keep you away from this delight—there are lots of YouTube videos that will show you the technique, or you can order season one of my television show Fork in the Road with Sheree Clark: I show you how in one of the 13 episodes.
articleSummaryHTML: Breakfast: when it’s the most important meal of the day, it should taste spectacular. So, we’ve given you spectacular with this mango berry coconut parfait.
seoTitle: Mango Berry Coconut Parfait | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Breakfast: when it’s the most important meal of the day, it should taste spectacular. So, we’ve given you spectacular with this mango berry coconut parfait.
ingredients:
s:490:"
  • 1 capful Vitamin Mineral Rush
  • 1–2 young coconuts
  • 2 mangoes, cubed
  • ½ pint blueberries
  • ½ pint blackberries
  • 2 teaspoons chia seeds
  • 3 tablespoons  granola
";
directions:
Open young coconuts and pour one cup of the coconut water and Vitamin Mineral Rushinto blender. Scoop out coconut meat and add to blender and puree until smooth, adding more coconut water if needed for blending. Stir in chia seeds and set aside.

Combine berries and mango and arrange into serving bowls or glasses. Pour coconut mixture on top. Garnish with granola.

articleBodyHTML:
You know when it’s almost bedtime, but you’re still hungry? What you need is a smoothie to help Mr. Sandman do his job so you can sleep!

Since finding myself hungry at bedtime happens to me on a regular basis, I uphold the philosophy that as long as you’re not bingeing on a boat-load of food before bed; eating something to keep from going to sleep on a rumbling tummy isn’t going to do you harm. It’s all about making sure you’re pre-sleep-snacking the right way because the truth is certain foods might fill you up, but then they also jazz you up so much you won’t be able to ever fall asleep!

However, there are special foods (like the ones in this smoothie) that can both fill you up and wind you down, acting as a yummy little lullaby.

Bananas are high in tryptophan: the sleepiness-inducing hormone that raises melatonin & serotonin levels, which promotes stable sleep. Cherries are one of the few natural plant sources of melatonin – a serious sleep-inducing hormone. Kale is high in magnesium which can help you sleep awesome-er. Rolled Oats are packed with magnesium and calcium, which are two minerals, that when taken together, have been proven to help stimulate deeper, less interrupted sleep! And Sunwarrior Plant-Protein Powder – keeps your blood sugar stable.

And here’s how to make it:
articleSummaryHTML: You know when it’s almost bedtime, but you’re still hungry? What you need is a smoothie to help Mr. Sandman do his job so you can sleep!
seoTitle: Go to Sleep Smoothie | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: You know when it’s almost bedtime, but you’re still hungry? What you need is a smoothie to help Mr. Sandman do his job so you can sleep!
ingredients:
s:587:"
  • 1 frozen banana
  • 1 cup frozen cherries
  • 1 handful (or cup) of kale
  • 2 tablespoons chocolate Sunwarrior Warrior Blend
  • 2 tablespoon chia seeds
  • 1 tablespoon almond butter
  • 1/2 cup almond milk (or more. Use as much as you need to get your desired texture!)

TOPPINGS (optional - if you want to make this a smoothie bowl instead of just a smoothie):

  • chia seeds
  • rolled oats
  • nutmeg
";
directions: Blend and Sip Yourself to Sleep :-)

articleBodyHTML:
For creamy flavor satisfaction, this is the smoothie for you. Bursting with the awesomeness of banana and chocolate and infused with a shot of cinnamon, smoothies have never been better!

Looking for an option for a healthy chocolate smoothie? You have come to the right place. This banana chocolate smoothie is so creamy and light that you forget how healthy it is for you. Did I mention it is packed with healthy fats, vitamins, and minerals too! You can definitely indulge without the guilt.
articleSummaryHTML: For creamy flavor satisfaction, this is the smoothie for you. Bursting with the awesomeness of banana and chocolate and infused with a shot of cinnamon, smoothies have never been better!
seoTitle: Creamy Banana Chocolate Smoothie | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: For creamy flavor satisfaction, this is the smoothie for you. This smoothie is bursting with the awesomeness of banana and chocolate and cinnamon.
ingredients:
s:323:"
  • 2 frozen bananas
  • ½ avocado
  • 2 teaspoons raw cacao powder
  • ¾ cup coconut milk
  • ¼ teaspoon cinnamon
  • ½ scoop chocolate Classic Plus protein
";
directions:
In a blender, combine all ingredients and blend until smooth and creamy. Approximately 30 seconds. If you prefer a thinner smoothie, add coconut milk a couple tablespoons at a time until you reach desired thickness.

Feel free to also add in a pinch of cayenne pepper if you want to kick this up!

articleTitle: Peanut Butter Banana Oatmeal Breakfast Bars
articleBodyHTML:
Never skip breakfast again! These peanut butter banana oatmeal breakfast bars are the perfect on-the-go meal for health and simplicity!

On-the-go breakfasts can be so satisfying. They allow you to snooze your alarm for an extra 15 minutes, you don’t have to worry about dishes, and you still get morning fuel! That’s why I love these peanut butter banana oat bars. I can prep them on Sunday and have breakfast for the entire week (plus extra for snacking if I’m hungry). They are made with whole ingredients to ensure that you are feeding your body some good nutrients in the morning and they have a great macro profile. 1 bar is 180 calories, 6 grams of fat, 28 carbs, and around 5 grams of protein! Talk about a win-win! Not to mention, these are totally customizable. Add in some chocolate chips if you have a sweet tooth, some walnuts for crunch, or even a scoop of protein powder if you want extra protein. The options are endless!
articleSummaryHTML: Never skip breakfast again! These peanut butter banana oatmeal breakfast bars are the perfect on-the-go meal for health and simplicity!
seoTitle: Peanut Butter Banana Oatmeal Breakfast Bars | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Never skip breakfast again! These peanut butter banana oatmeal breakfast bars are the perfect on-the-go meal for health and simplicity!
recipeName: Peanut Butter Banana Oatmeal Breakfast Bars
ingredients:
s:770:"
  • 3 bananas
  • ¼ cup maple or agave syrup
  • ¼ cup smooth peanut butter
  • ½ cup unsweetened almond milk
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
  • 1 tablespoon chia seeds
  • ½ cup desiccated unsweetened coconut
  • 1 ½ cups rolled oats
  • 1 teaspoon cinnamon
  • ½ teaspoon baking powder
  • 1 scoop Sunwarrior mocha illumin8 (optional)
";
directions:
1. Preheat your oven to 350 degrees
  2. In a medium sized bowl, mash your bananas until resembling baby food
  3. Mix in your syrup, peanut butter, almond milk, and vanilla until smooth
  4. Finally, mix in the chia, coconut, oats, cinnamon, and baking powder
  5. Mix all ingredients well
  6. Spray a 9x9 baking pan spray with non-stick cooking spray, then dump the banana oat mixture into the pan
  7. Bake for 20–22 minutes until just firm to the touch
  8. Let cool completely before cutting
  9. Store in the fridge in an air tight container until ready to eat!

articleTitle: Cozy Squash, Apple, and Fennel Soup
articleBodyHTML:
We're coming into soup season! And this cozy squash, apple, and fennel soup is everything that makes autumn awesome!

It’s difficult to mess up a soup recipe unless you throw some strong flavors in like olives or things that just don’t taste good when simmered like cucumbers or eggplant. But other than that, soup is easy-peasy.

You most likely already have some veggies in your kitchen (like carrots, celery, broccoli, kale, chard, squash, mushrooms) that can be chopped up and tossed into a pot of warm water. Once it has come to a boil and simmered, you can leave it chunky, or you can blend up for a smooth puree. Either way, you’ve got a nice warm meal all in one pot. It is the cheapest and quickest way to make a meal for a large group or for multiple personal servings over and over.

Lastly, don’t get caught up with ingredients or quantities. Just get creative and have fun with new items (like squash instead of white potatoes) and try planning with different amounts, add a tablespoon instead of a teaspoon if it’s an herb that you really like!

Also, soups freeze really well. So, toss out those cans of Campbell’s and turn your pot on!
articleSummaryHTML: We're coming into soup season! And this cozy squash, apple, and fennel soup is everything that makes autumn awesome!
seoTitle: Cozy Squash, Apple, and Fennel Soup | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: We're coming into soup season! And this cozy squash, apple, and fennel soup is everything that makes autumn awesome!
recipeName: Cozy Squash, Apple, and Fennel Soup
ingredients:
s:958:"
  • 2 cups vegetable broth or herbed water (thyme, bay leaf, basil, & cracked peppercorns: use a sachet if peppercorns are not cracked)
  • 2 cups water
  • 1 large butternut squash, peeled and cubed
  • 2 apples, peeled, cored, and chopped
  • 2 stalks celery chopped
  • 1 small onion, thinly sliced
  • 1 cup chopped fennel (or 1 medium fennel)
  • 1 bay leaf
  • 1⁄4 teaspoon dried thyme leaves
  • 1⁄8 teaspoon ground nutmeg
  • 6 peppercorns
  • 1⁄2 teaspoon ginger
  • 1⁄2 teaspoon cinnamon
  • 1 tablespoon olive oil
";
directions:
1. Preheat oven to 350F. Place squash on baking sheet and bake for 30 minutes. Remove from oven and move around and add fennel slices to the tray and bake for another 15–20 minutes, remove from oven to cool.

2. In a large pot, sauté onions, celery, and apples in olive oil until just tender. Combine with broth or herbed water.

3. Bring to a boil. Add ginger and cinnamon. Reduce heat and simmer, covered, 20 minutes.

4. Combine squash and fennel with the apple broth and continue to simmer for another 10 minutes.

5. Strain soup, reserving liquid. Remove bay leaf from the apple-vegetable mixture in strainer.

6. In blender or food processor, puree mixture; add reserved liquid and blend well. Reheat soup, if necessary, ladle soup into soup bowls and serve.

Delicious Knowledge by Marni

Fennel is a unique ingredient. When it is roasted with squash and paired with apple, it gives this soup a natural sweetness along with a distinct flavor. Fennel is also excellent for digestion, especially when it is combined with other warming herbs like ginger and cinnamon.

articleTitle: Carrot & Quinoa Muffins: Breakfast is Served!
articleBodyHTML:
When you need a quick, on-the-go, healthy breakfast or snack ideas, we got you covered with carrot & quinoa muffins.

We used carrots in the recipe but you can also add bananas, sweet potato, or mixed berries. You can make this recipe your own. Quinoa is normally associated with lunch or dinner to make delicious and healthy salads, but it makes a great breakfast muffin!

We have grown to love this grain as it boosts so many health benefits, but did you know that you can also buy quinoa flour? Yep, that right, your favorite grain can now be made into healthy and nutty treats. Muffins are normally made with refined white sugar, eggs, and white flour. This recipe switches out these traditional ingredients for healthier ones.

Quinoa flour is one of the best flours on the market. Quinoa flour makes recipes light and delicious. Quinoa is an incredible source of protein and is a complete source of amino acids. Quinoa flour is a great to use not only in muffins but pancakes and waffles. Imagine the possibilities! Quinoa flour is also high in fiber which can help regulate your digestive system. This grain has been around for centuries but only in the past few years we have really grown to love this grain. The best part about this grain is that it’s gluten free. Quinoa is also low in calories and has a low glycemic index rating so it won’t spike your glucose levels and cause a crash later on during the day.

These perfect little muffins make a great brunch or breakfast idea anytime! Enjoy this aromatic muffin recipe!
articleSummaryHTML: When you need a quick, on-the-go, healthy breakfast or snack ideas, we got you covered with carrot & quinoa muffins.
seoTitle: Carrot & Quinoa Muffins: Breakfast is Served! | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: When you need a quick, on-the-go, healthy breakfast or snack ideas, we got you covered with the best carrot & quinoa muffins.
recipeName: Carrot & Quinoa Muffins: Breakfast is Served!
ingredients:
s:488:"
  • 1 ½ cups quinoa flour
  • 2 teaspoons baking powder
  • ½ cup raw coconut sugar 
  • ½ cup maple syrup 
  • 1 cup shredded carrots
  • 1/3 cup olive oil
  • 1 teaspoon cinnamon
  • ½ teaspoon nutmeg
  • 1/8 teaspoon salt
  • 2 tablespoons crushed walnuts
  • 1 tablespoon dried cranberries
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
  • 1 zest of orange
";
directions:
Preheat oven to 375 

Whisk together quinoa flour, baking powder, coconut sugar, nutmeg, cinnamon, and salt

In another bowl, shred carrots and pat dry with a paper towel

Add all remaining ingredients together except for walnuts. Make sure to mix well until well combined. Add walnuts on top of muffins and bake for 20 minutes

Remove from oven and let cool

articleBodyHTML:
Get your baker hat on and fill your house with the smell of cookie goodness! Cashew, coconut, chocolate cookies are everything tasty and awesome!

As a gluten-free baker, I incorporate almond butter into many recipes. It’s a reliable flour alternative, and it helps bind all the ingredients together. While almond butter will always be my go-to choice (mostly because I’m obsessed with the taste), I decided to experiment with cashew butter for my new cookie recipe. Cashew butter is creamy, buttery, and extremely smooth. I usually shy away from peanut butter because it is often processed, double the amount of sugar, and loaded with calories and fats. It’s really a no-brainer to use cashew butter when straying from almond. The beauty of this recipe is that as long as you create the cashew butter base, you can add any ingredient into the batter to form your perfect cookie. For me, that means adding coconut and dark vegan chocolate chips! Here is the recipe for my vegan and gluten-free Cashew Coconut Chocolate Cookies!
articleSummaryHTML: Get your baker hat on and fill your house with the smell of cookie goodness! Cashew, coconut, chocolate cookies are everything tasty and awesome!
seoTitle: Cashew Coconut Chocolate Cookies (Gluten-Free and Vegan)
seoDescription: Get your baker hat on and fill your house with the smell of cookie goodness! Cashew, coconut, chocolate cookies are everything tasty and awesome!
ingredients:
s:758:"
  • 1 jar of creamy cashew butter (16 oz.). *Note: use a brand that says ‘no sugar added’ on the label
  • 2 flax eggs (regular eggs are also fine and will create a slightly firmer cookie, but use flax to be completely vegan)
  • ½ cup of organic maple syrup
  • 1 tablespoon finely shredded organic coconut powder
  • 1 teaspoon organic vanilla extract
  • ½ teaspoon pink Himalayan sea salt
  • ½ teaspoon baking soda
  • ½ cup of 69% cacao vegan Enjoy Life dark chocolate chips
";
directions:
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees.

Combine the cashew butter, flax eggs, maple syrup, coconut powder, vanilla extract, sea salt, and baking soda in a large bowl and mix until smooth; a sticky batter will form.

Add the chocolate chips and gently fold in.

Scoop out ¾ of a tablespoon onto parchment paper per cookie (you should have 8–10 cookies lined on the sheet) and form small circles.

Bake for 15–20 minutes (depending on your oven so check at the 15-minute mark; the cookies should be slightly golden and remember, they harden more once they sit so don’t overcook)

Let the cookies sit for 15 minutes and then store in the refrigerator, so they keep their shape and texture.

articleBodyHTML:
When you spiralize your zucchini into noodles, you get zoodles! And these zoodles taste amazing in stir fry! Dinner is served!

Zoodles is the new thing. At least, it’s new to me. I love it! Zoodles are zucchini cut into noodles. They are a fantastic substitute for regular noodles especially if you need to lower your carb intake. I personally love zoodles and can tell a small difference from regular noodles but not that big of a difference. My kids didn’t really know it was zoodles that I made. All they knew was that it was different.

Zucchini is a win-win vegetable. It’s low in calories and high in antioxidants. Zucchini is loaded with vitamin C and B6. It’s also good for your heart. Carrots are high in vitamin A and is also a high source of antioxidants. Carrots have beta carotene, lutein, and zeaxanthin that boost your eye health. Broccoli is high in Vitamin K, C, and A. It also is high in antioxidants.
articleSummaryHTML: When you spiralize your zucchini into noodles, you get zoodles! And these zoodles taste amazing in stir fry! Dinner is served!
seoTitle: Spiralize Stir Fry with Zoodles! | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: When you spiralize your zucchini into noodles, you get zoodles! And these zoodles taste amazing in stir fry! Dinner is served!
ingredients:
s:854:"

Sauce

  • ⅓ cup soy sauce
  • 1 tablespoon vegetable broth
  • 1 tablespoon maple syrup
  • 2 cloves garlic, minced
  • 1 teaspoon minced ginger
  • 1 tablespoon cornstarch

For Stir-Fry

  • 2 teaspoons oil
  • 1 red bell pepper, sliced thin
  • 1 onion, sliced thin
  • 1 cup matchstick carrots
  • 2 cups broccoli florets
  • 2 cups cabbage
  • 2 medium zucchini, spiralized
";
directions:
1. Whisk all ingredients together for the sauce and set aside.
  2. Add oil to hot skillet or wok. Add red pepper, onion, carrots, broccoli, and cabbage. Cook until crisp tender about 2 to 3 minutes. Set aside.
  3. Add sauce to the same pan and cook until bubbly about 2 mins. Add zoodles (zucchini spiralized) and cook about 2 minutes or until desired tenderness. Add remaining vegetable and toss. Serve immediately.

articleBodyHTML:
Bye-bye, basic popsicles! Frozen treats will never be boring again with these blackberry rose water mint popsicles!

Blackberry Rose Water Mint Popsicles are an unexpected spin on your classic ice pop. Refreshing and full of natural goodies, you won’t feel guilty if you sneak more than one. Mix it up by using basil or rosemary instead of mint, or try orange blossom water as a stand-in for the rose.

In this recipe, rose water is the special guest. Why, you ask? There are many proponents of rose water who will tell you:

  • It hydrates skin from the inside
  • It’s a relaxer, helping to relieve stress and improve the mood (like chocolate, but with fewer calories!)
  • It’s a natural reliever of bloating, upset stomach, and constipation
  • It reduces fluid retention and inflammation

When buying rose water, be sure to purchase the pure form rather than a synthetic rose oil and water blend, which likely also contains preservatives. Pure rose water is simply the steam distillation of rose petals. You can also make your own rose water at home. Look up the process online—it’s fairly simple and requires little more than a large pot, some ice and a couple of quarts of fresh rose petals

Making these frozen treats couldn’t be easier: just five delicious ingredients, blended and frozen.
articleSummaryHTML: Bye-bye, basic popsicles! You’ll never be boring again blackberry rose water mint popsicles!
seoTitle: Blackberry Rose Water Mint Popsicles | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Bye-bye, basic popsicles! You’ll never be boring again blackberry rose water mint popsicles! Try them for your perfect summer treat.
ingredients:
s:356:"

Yield: 6 servings

  • 1 cup blackberries
  • 2 cups raspberries
  • 2 tablespoons coconut nectar
  • 1 teaspoon rose water
  • 2 tablespoons chopped mint leaves
";
directions: Puree ingredients in a blender and spoon into popsicle molds. Freeze 5–6 hours or follow manufacturer’s instructions if using a commercial unit.

articleTitle: One Pot Meals: New Age Minestrone
articleBodyHTML:
Achievement unlocked with this one-pot wonder of health, taste, and tummy happiness!

It’s so great to cozy up to a warm bowl of goodness during the longer and colder days that are coming. The best part is that one-pot meals are easier than preparing your average dinner at home (which usually involves more than one recipe to get a balanced meal).

For your one-pot meal to cover the entire basis of your meal, you are going to need a few things:

Vegetables: onions, carrots, and celery provide a great base for a soup or stew, to give your water some flavor. Then you can add in vegetables that are in season such as squash, sweet potatoes, rutabaga, turnips, parsnips, Brussels sprouts, fennel, broccoli, cauliflower, and kale (you can really get crazy here!)

Legumes: Preferably cooked from scratch. Choose from chickpeas, black beans, white beans, lentils, yellow split peas, kidney beans, mung beans, and black-eyed peas.

Herbs and spices – Make sure you have some basics on hand from cumin, parsley, sage, oregano, garlic, ginger, rosemary, thyme, basil, marjoram, and turmeric.

Whole Grains- Using barley, oats, quinoa, brown rice, and millet can add a dose of complex carbohydrate, texture, and substance to your pot.

There you have it – a well-rounded one-pot meal! These meals make for a convenient and easy way to approach dinnertime in the fall and winter months. You can make a batch of it early in the week or on the weekend and take portions out, as you need them throughout the week. You can even warm some up and put it in a stainless-steel thermos for you or your kids on the go! You can freeze portions in glass containers and store them for a snowy day when you don’t feel like cooking or going anywhere.
Benefit from cooking some of your own meals at home: you get to be creative, you know what goes in it, and you know it’s going to be delicious!
articleSummaryHTML: Achievement unlocked with this one-pot wonder of health, taste, and tummy happiness!
seoTitle: One Pot Meals: New Age Minestrone | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Achievement unlocked with this one-pot wonder of health, taste, and tummy happiness! New age minestrone.
recipeName: One Pot Meals: New Age Minestrone
ingredients:
s:1118:"
  • 1 Spanish onion, cut into small chunks
  • 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil
  • 1–2 cloves of garlic, minced
  • 1 ½ teaspoon sea salt
  • 1 tablespoon dried oregano
  • 4–6 cups filtered water or stock
  • 1 bay leaf
  • 1 butternut squash, peeled and cut into medium pieces (or roast half squash in oven on 350F for 45 minutes) – then peel flesh away from skin and place in pot
  • 1 sweet potato cut into small chunks
  • 3 ribs celery cut into small chunks
  • 1 large zucchini (or two small), cut into small chunks
  • 1 bunch of chard, cut into bite-sized pieces
  • 1 cup soaked and cooked kidney beans (optional)
  • ½ cup cooked elbow brown rice noodles (optional)
";
directions:
1. In a larger pot, sweat onion in oil with salt until soft.
  2. Add oregano and sweat a few more minutes
  3. Add water and bay leaf
  4. Add vegetables in order given (squash, sweet potatoes, celery, zucchini)
  5. Turn up the heat until water bubbles, then lower and simmer covered for 40–45 minutes.
  6. Stir vegetables until squash falls apart.
  7. Add in chopped chard.
  8. Cover and simmer for 10 minutes.
  9. Stir a few more times and serve.

*** For a smoother texture, simmer squash separately until soft (in 1–2 cups of water), and puree in food processor. Add squash to the soup for the last 10 minutes of cooking.

articleTitle: 3 Different Protein Bars in a Jiffy
articleBodyHTML:
Protein: You gotta have it! So, get your protein in the fastest, easiest, and tastiest of ways with these three protein bar recipes!

Where do you get your protein? This is one of the most standard questions every vegetarian or vegan person gets asked. We all know that plants provide what we need, but sometimes you just need it in a hurry! Here are some quick protein bar recipes that you can carry with you during hikes, travel, work, workout sessions, and pretty much anywhere!
articleSummaryHTML: Protein: You gotta have it! So, get your protein in the fastest, easiest, and tastiest of ways with these three protein bar recipes!
seoTitle: 3 Different Protein Bars in a Jiffy | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Protein: You gotta have it! So, get your protein in the fastest, easiest, and tastiest of ways with these three protein bar recipes!
ingredients:
s:1568:"

Peanut Butter Swirl

  • 2 tablespoons peanut butter
  • 3–4 Dates
  • ¾ cup oat flour
  • ½ teaspoon Himalayan sea salt
  • 1 tablespoon Sunwarrior Classic natural protein

Coconut Cashew Crunch

  • ¾ cup cashews, soaked and dried
  • ¾ cup shredded coconut
  • 1 tablespoon coconut butter
  • 1 teaspoon Himalayan sea salt
  • 1 tablespoon coconut nectar
  • 1 tablespoon Sunwarrior Classic natural protein

Almond Joy

  • 3 tablespoons almonds, sliced
  • 1 tablespoon coconut, shredded
  • 2 tablespoons almond butter
  • 1 tablespoon goji berries
  • 1 teaspoon Himalayan sea salt
  • 2–3 Medjool dates
  • 1 tablespoon Sunwarrior Classic natural protein
";
directions:
Peanut Butter Swirl

  1. Using a food processor, pulse all ingredients until smooth. You can also do a quick pulse to give it a bit chunky feeling
  2. Spread the ingredients in a glass tray and refrigerate for longer use.
  3. Cut them into small squares and take it everywhere you go!

Coconut Cashew Crunch

  1. Using a food processor, pulse all ingredients until smooth. You can also do a quick pulse to give it a bit chunky feeling
  2. Spread the ingredients in a glass tray and refrigerate for longer use.
  3. Cut them into small squares and take it everywhere you go!

Almond Joy

  1. Using a food processor, process the almond butter, dates and sea salt until smooth and creamy
  2. Then simply add the remaining ingredients and give it a quick pulse.
  3. Transfer the ingredients to a glass tray and spread it out evenly and refrigerate for longer storage.
  4. All of these bars are packed with essential nutrients, superfood qualities, essential fat and of course protein!

Feel free to top with whatever toppings that make you happy or leave them with no toppings at all--whatever you like best!

Enjoy!

articleBodyHTML:
Sometimes a home-made cookie filled with chocolate chunks is the only thing that you want. We’re here to make it a healthier choice with these chocolate chunk coconut cookies!

Let’s face it – sometimes we need (want) a cookie! A really big, yummy, chocolatey cookie! It’s beyond wanting one. We truly need it. Having an easy to make, whole-foods focused version means we can even have two without remorse. These cookies score on all health food checkpoints being a nutrient dense quality carb, protein-rich, high fiber, dairy/corn/soy/gluten free, low sugar, no added oil, absolutely fabulous tasting power cookie. Like many great recipes, doubling the batch is a great idea. You can keep half of the batter in the freezer for up to a month meaning another batch is just a bake away when the cookie jar is empty. And trust me, it just may empty sooner than you like.
articleSummaryHTML: Sometimes a home-made cookie filled with chocolate chunks is the only thing that you want. We’re here to make it a healthier choice with these chocolate chunk coconut cookies!
seoTitle: Chocolate Chunk Coconut Cookies | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Home-made cookie filled with chocolate chunks is the only thing that you want. We’re here to make it a healthier choice with chocolate chunk coconut cookies!
ingredients:
s:1024:"
  • ¼ cup chia seeds or flax meal mixed with ½ cup non-dairy milk
  • 3 over-ripe bananas, mashed, approximately 1.5 cups
  • 1/3 cup Sunbutter or organic peanut butter
  • 1 teaspoon real vanilla extract
  • 1 cup organic old-fashioned oatmeal (gluten free)
  • 1½ cups almond meal, plus more if needed
  • 2 scoops Sunwarrior Warrior Blend protein chocolate
  • ½ teaspoon baking soda, alum free
  • 1½ teaspoon organic cinnamon
  • ½ cup organic toasted coconut shavings or flakes
  • ½ cup dairy free chocolate, roughly chopped
  • ¼ teaspoon sea salt
";
directions:
1. Pre-heat the oven to 350F, and cover a large baking sheet or two small sheets with parchment paper.
  2. Measure all of the wet ingredients in a large bowl including the sugar and flax or chia blend. Mix well and set aside.
  3. Next, combine the remaining dry ingredients together and add to the wet mixture to create a thick, sticky batter. Take a little taste; it’s so good you can eat as is yet refrain for they are super yummy baked. Adjust the texture with additional coconut meal if needed. If you prefer a sweeter cookie add more cinnamon or a touch more sugar to taste.
  4. Using a large soup spoon or two-inch ice cream scoop drop the batter onto your prepared sheet leaving 2 inches between each cookie. Shape into even rounds and bake in the preheated oven approximately 25-30 minutes or until the cookies are evenly browned. If you prefer a crunchier cookie, let them bake a little longer then cool on a rack before storing in a covered glass container in a cool location up to a week.

TERI’S TIPS:

  • The cookies freeze well for up to 1 month, 2 months maximum for best results
  • Keep frozen ripe banana chunks in your freezer, so you always have some on hand
  • Not a fan of bananas? Sub with date or prune (dried plums) jam made by soaking the dried fruits in boiling water 2 hours or more then pureeing into a jam-like paste.
  • Like it sweet? Add 2–3 tablespoons organic coconut sugar, yet taste the mixture first. You may discover it isn’t needed. Especially if using the dates and protein powder

articleBodyHTML:
Autumn is where sweater weather and soup weather unite to bring us cozy happiness, and we’re bringing all the happiness with this coconut squash soup!

This is the perfect fall soup! It is warming, spiced to perfection, and delicious. This makes a delicious addition to any meal. Combine with a large salad for lunch or start your dinner meal off with this tasty soup. It stores in the fridge for up to one week, and you can keep it in the freezer for up to 3 months.
articleSummaryHTML: Autumn is where sweater weather and soup weather unite to bring us cozy happiness, and we’re bringing all the happiness with this coconut squash soup!
seoTitle: How to Make Coconut Squash Soup | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Autumn is where sweater weather and soup weather unite to bring us cozy happiness, and we’re bringing all the happiness with this coconut squash soup!
ingredients:
s:646:"
  • 1 large butternut squash, peeled and cubed
  • 1 tablespoon coconut oil
  • 1 white onion, chopped
  • 2 carrots, chopped
  • 2 cloves garlic, crushed
  • 1⁄2 teaspoon grated fresh ginger
  • 4 cups water
  • 1 cup coconut milk
  • ½ teaspoon turmeric
  • 1⁄2 teaspoon cinnamon
  • 1 teaspoon sea salt
";
directions:
1. Preheat oven to 350F. Place squash on baking sheet and bake for 30 minutes.

2. In a large pot, sauté onions, carrots, garlic, and ginger in coconut oil until just tender. Combine with water and coconut milk

3. Bring to a boil. Add turmeric and cinnamon, sea salt. Reduce heat and simmer, covered, 20 minutes.

4. Combine squash with broth and continue to simmer for another 10 minutes.

6. In blender or food processor, puree mixture; add more liquid if needed. Reheat soup, if necessary, ladle soup into soup bowls and serve.

Top with coconut flakes and dried herbs.

articleBodyHTML:
The best thing since sliced bread! No really! Since many people have celiac disease or going gluten-free for digestive reasons, we bring you sweet potato toast!

Someone came up with a better way to enjoy our toast, and, boy, is it delicious! Sweet potato toast has been all the rage these days. There are so many ways to make it; the possibilities are endless! This is a classic sweet potato toast recipe that I enjoy a few times a week.
articleSummaryHTML: The best thing since sliced bread! No really! Since many people have celiac disease or going gluten-free for digestive reasons, we bring you sweet potato toast!
seoTitle: Tomato Basil Sweet Potato Toast | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: The best thing since sliced bread! No really! Since many people have celiac disease or going gluten-free for digestive reasons, we bring you sweet potato toast!
ingredients:
s:327:"
  • 1 sweet potato sliced
  • Basil leaves
  • 1 large tomato
  • 1 small avocado
  • Himalayan sea salt to taste
  • Black pepper to taste 
";
directions:
Take the sweet potato and slice it up thin. Slice how many “toast” pieces you want to have. I can eat 2–3 for a snack. Put the sweet potato slice in the toaster twice for best results. You can do three times depending on your toaster temperature. I put mine on medium, so I don’t burn it. While your sweet potato is toasting, slice tomatoes and avocado. Wash basil and get it ready to layer on top of sweet potato. When sweet potato is done, put on a plate and top with avocado first. Smash avocado on the toast with a fork. Then add basil slices, so they stick to the avocado. Then add tomato slices on top of basil. Crack some Himalayan sea salt and pepper on top to taste. Enjoy the flavors as they melt in your mouth!

Benefits of Sweet Potato

There are so many more health benefits to the sweet potato than people realize. Their rich orange color indicates that they are high in carotenoids like beta-carotene and other carotenoids, which is the precursor to vitamin A in your body. Carotenoids help strengthen our eyesight and boost our immunity to disease; they are powerful antioxidants that help ward off cancer and protect against the effects of aging. They are high in Vitamin D which is great for strong bones. They also help regulate blood sugars.

Happy snacking!

articleTitle: Superfood List – Be Your Best; Eat the Best
articleBodyHTML:
Good health combines a healthy diet, active lifestyle, and clocking enough hours of sleep. These superfoods help you with all of that to help make you your best!

While you may have already balanced out your healthy lifestyle, there are some superfoods that will boost your immunity, your endurance level and improve your sleep pattern. While for some of us, these may look like three different segments; according to scientists, all of these are intertwined and work hand-in-hand.

What you eat affects your mind, body, and sleep pattern. Your sleep pattern affects your mood, your diet, and so on. These superfoods can take you to the next level.

Walnuts

These brain-shaped nuts are packed with antioxidants, selenium, vitamin E, and are a great source of serotonin. They are also rich in protein, fiber, healthy omega 3s, and biotin. A handful of these can replenish your body, boost immunity, and leave your skin clean and glowing.

Kale

Healthy kale is found everywhere: smoothies, salads, dehydrated chips, or even kale candy. It’s impossible to miss this green. But it does do great justice for the fame it has obtained. It’s rich in vitamin C, vitamin K, vitamin B6, calcium, manganese, small amounts of protein, and loads of fiber.

Coconut Oil

There’s a set of people who promote coconut oil to be amazing, whereas others shun it in the name of fat. Coconut oil is a medium-chain fatty acid that’s not similar to saturated fats or other small-chained fats. It is absorbed by the body in a different way and is not treated as a hydrogenated fat.

Coconut oil is packed with antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory properties that can ward off any viral or bacterial infection. They are great to lubricate your joints and skin, are a great source of brain food, and, above all, keep you looking young and fresh.

Blueberries

These tiny pieces of joy are packed with powerful antioxidants that help to get rid of the free radicals in your body. They are also rich in anti-aging and anti-inflammatory properties and are a great way to add more fruit to your diet with some amazing benefits like fiber, protein, zinc, folate, calcium, manganese, and iron.

Water

Yes! This is not food, but technically, it is higher than food. One of the key ingredients to survival is water. This amazing liquid not only hydrates your body, but it is also the main way to regulate blood flow, aid organ functions, eliminate toxins, boost your activity level, and, of course, keep you alive!

Want to have it all at the same time? Here is my quick Superfood recipe:
articleSummaryHTML: Good health combines a healthy diet, active lifestyle, and clocking enough hours of sleep. These superfoods help you with all of that to help make you your best!
seoTitle: Superfood List – Be Your Best; Eat the Best | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Good health combines a healthy diet, active lifestyle, & clocking enough hours of sleep. These superfoods help you with all of that to help make you your best!
ingredients:
s:306:"
  • ¾ cup blueberries
  • 1 cup water or coconut water
  • ¾ cup kale leaves
  • 1 tablespoon coconut oil
  • 2 tablespoon walnuts, soaked
";
directions: Using a high-speed blender, blend all ingredients until smooth and creamy.

articleBodyHTML:
Do you ever open the fridge in hopes of finding something sweet, delicious, and ready to fill that sweet tooth? Chia pudding is the answer!

Most people opt for that tub of ice cream or perhaps left-over dessert but what if you opened your fridge to a dish that could be breakfast, lunch, or dessert? This dish is so versatile, taking on the flavors of whatever you top or blend it with. This magical dish is chia seed pudding! Chia seed puddings take only 1 minute to make and an hour or so to set. This is one dessert that you won’t feel guilty polishing off every last morsel.

Chia seeds are magical black seeds from the earth that delivers a massive amount of nutrients without harboring calories. Chia seeds are packed with fiber, and when placed into a liquid, they become gel-like. This will expand in your stomach, creating a long-lasting satiated feeling. Many plant-based products are low in protein, but chia seeds come out on top with a huge amount of digestible protein. Chia seeds are very easy to incorporate into your diet, they can be placed in water, made into pudding, or sprinkled onto food.

The standard version of the recipe is made with chia seeds, almond milk, maple syrup, and vanilla powder. To add an intense berry flavor, you can puree fruits with your nut milk and then add the chia seeds. Peanut butter, jelly, and banana are the all-time classics. This beautiful marriage between these three ingredients makes a tantalizing and delicious chia seed pudding that will keep your energized all the way to lunch. Peanuts are packed with fiber, protein, and healthy fats which can curb hunger later on during the day. You can also add cocoa powder to your nut milk and create a chocolate chia pudding and top it with nuts. Whichever way you like your chia pudding, it will be delicious.

When that sweet tooth comes knocking, opt for this scrumptious pudding.
articleSummaryHTML: Do you ever open the fridge in hopes of finding something sweet, delicious, and ready to fill that sweet tooth? Chia pudding is the answer!
seoTitle: Vanilla Chia Pudding | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Do you ever open the fridge in hopes of finding something sweet, delicious, and ready to fill that sweet tooth? Chia pudding is the answer!
ingredients:
s:297:"
  • 2 cups nondairy milk of choice
  • ½ cup chia seeds
  • ½ teaspoon vanilla extract or a vanilla bean, scraped
  • 1 tablespoon liquid sweetener of choice
";
directions:
1. Add ingredients to a bowl and mix well. Add sweetener, and rest in fridge overnight
  2. Serve with desired toppings and enjoy!

articleTitle: Broccoli Raisin Salad: Not Your Grandma’s Side Dish
articleBodyHTML:
Breathe some happiness into your dinner with a side dish that sings: Broccoli Raisin Salad! Trust us; it’s nothing like the stuff grandma brought to family parties.

Nothing beats the satisfying crunch of a bite of broccoli. For this salad, you can take extra pleasure in the fact that we’re removing the “uglies” from the traditional broccoli-and-raisin salad: no mayo, sugar, or bacon. For sweetness, we’re relying on the natural sugars in the raisins—including the water used to soak them—and adding just a dab of maple syrup.

Another unconventional twist in this recipe is the added zing of mustard and lemon juice, which act as more flavorful replacements for the vinegar. Feel free to experiment and add more mustard if you want to bump up the tanginess!

Did you know nutrients are condensed when a food is dried or dehydrated? Once grapes transform into raisins, their nutrients become concentrated, so even a handful of raisins is chock full of B vitamins, iron, and potassium. Additionally, snacking or including raisins in a salad like this one is a great way to sneak good carbohydrates for energy into the body.

Unlike other broccoli and raisin salad mixes, which may contain dairy or meat, this one is vegan. For a decorative sprinkle and extra crunch, hold the sunflower seeds until the end for a topping instead of blending with the rest. Want to ramp up the nutrition even more? Sprout the sunflower seeds for a day before adding them to the salad.
articleSummaryHTML: Breathe some happiness into your dinner with a side dish that sings: Broccoli Raisin Salad! Trust us; it’s nothing like the stuff grandma brought to family parties.
seoTitle: How to Make the Best Broccoli Raisin Salad | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Breathe some happiness into your dinner with a side dish that sings: Broccoli Raisin Salad! It’s nothing like the stuff grandma brought to family parties.
recipeName: Broccoli Raisin Salad: Not Your Grandma’s Side Dish
ingredients:
s:678:"

Salad

  • 3 cups broccoli florets, in bite-sized pieces
  • ½ cup sweet yellow onion, chopped
  • ½ cup raisins, soaked (retain soak water)
  • ½ cup raw sunflower seeds, sprouted if desired

Dressing

  • ½ cup raw cashews, soaked 2+ hours
  • 3 tablespoons lemon juice
  • 2 tablespoons olive oil
  • ¼ cup raisin soak water (drained from raisins, below)
  • 1 clove garlic
  • 2 tablespoons maple syrup or coconut nectar
  • 1 tablespoon   prepared Dijon mustard
  • Dash unrefined salt
";
directions:
1. Puree dressing ingredients in a blender until smooth and creamy.
  2. In a large bowl, combine salad ingredients and toss to mix. Add the dressing and toss to coat.

articleBodyHTML:
Breakfast so good, you’ll want it for every meal! This peach-blueberry compote French toast is the reason you will want to get up in the morning!

This French toast is lightly infused with peach and slowly cooked on the griddle until lightly toasted. Peach blueberry compote is an excellent topping to bring this dish together with bright, happy flavors. Enjoy!
articleSummaryHTML: Breakfast so good, you’ll want it for every meal! This peach-blueberry compote French toast is the reason you will want to get up in the morning!
seoTitle: Peach Blueberry Compote French Toast | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Breakfast so good, you’ll want it for every meal! This peach-blueberry compote French toast is the reason you will want to get up in the morning!
ingredients:
s:1092:"

Toast

  • 8 slices of gluten-free bread, or your choice of bread
  • 1 ½ cup almond coconut milk, unsweetened
  • ½ cup oats
  • ½ cup soy peach yogurt
  • 1 ½ tablespoons coconut oil
  • 2 tablespoons cornstarch
  • 2 tablespoons coconut sugar
  • 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon
  • ½ teaspoon ground nutmeg
  • Pinch of ground cloves

Peach Blueberry Compote

  • 1 peach, diced
  • ⅔ cup blueberries
  • 1 tablespoon liquid sweetener of your choice (maple syrup or agave)
  • Sprinkle of cinnamon
  • About ¼ cup water
";
directions:
1. Place the bread in a large glass dish. In a medium bowl combine dairy-free milk, oats, yogurt, cornstarch, sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves. Whisk together. Set aside to allow the oats to absorb some of the liquid while you prepare the compote.

2. In a small pot, combine compote ingredients. Bring to a boil, reduce heat to low and let simmer about 15 minutes until sauce starts to thicken. Remove from heat, cover, and allow to cool slightly. The sauce will thicken more during the cooling process.

3. Pour French toast mixture over bread. Allow bread to soak up liquid 2–3 minutes per side.

4. Heat large griddle to approximately 325 degrees. Add coconut oil. When oil is warmed gently place bread on griddle. Make sure you get some of the soaked oats on each piece. Cook until lightly toasted, then flip and cook until lightly toasted on other side. About 3–5 minutes per side.

5. Plate and add desired amount of compote.

articleBodyHTML:
Simple to make with simple ingredients make this creamy and delicious pea pesto pasta a quick and healthy dinner. Being short on time doesn’t mean being short on health.

This dinner doesn’t require too much preparation, and you only need simple ingredients to make it. The pea pesto gives this dish a wonderful fresh touch, and the addition of cashew nuts makes the whole thing extra creamy. You’ll taste a hint of “cheesy” flavors because of the yeast flakes, so nobody will know that it’s 100% plant-based. If you are not that keen on kale, you can swap it for spinach, or just skip it completely, and it will still taste amazing!
articleSummaryHTML: Simple to make with simple ingredients make this creamy and delicious pea pesto pasta a quick and healthy dinner. Being short on time doesn’t mean being short on health.
seoTitle: The Best Vegan Pea Pesto Pasta | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Simple to make and simple ingredients make this creamy and delicious pea pesto pasta a quick and healthy dinner. Being short on time doesn’t mean being short on health.
ingredients:
s:742:"

 

  • 16 oz. your favorite pasta
  • 16 oz. frozen peas
  • 1 leek, sliced
  • ½ chopped green chili
  • 5 cloves garlic, finely chopped
  • 1 cup cashews (no need to soak)
  • 4 tablespoons olive oil
  • 2/3 cup almond milk
  • 3 tablespoons yeast flakes
  • 2 handfuls fresh curly kale, chopped
  • 1 handful fresh basil leaves
  • salt and pepper 
";
directions:
1. Cook the pasta according to the instructions on the packaging.
  2. While the pasta is cooking, heat 2 tablespoons olive oil in a pan and add sliced leek. Cook for 3 minutes stirring occasionally. Add garlic and chili and cook for 3 more minutes. Then add frozen peas and kale, season with salt and pepper and cook for 5 min stirring occasionally. Remove from heat.
  3. Take out half of the vegetable mix from the pan and put it in a food processor or high-speed blender. Add almond milk, 2 tablespoons olive oil, cashews, basil leaves, and yeast flakes, and blend until smooth and creamy pesto forms. You might need to add more almond milk if the consistency is not wet enough. Try and season to taste.
  4. When the pasta is cooked, mix it with the pesto and the remaining vegetables and serve drizzled with olive oil and decorated with basil leaves.

articleTitle: Pumpkin Protein Chocolate-Chip Cookies (Flour-Free and Vegan)
articleBodyHTML:
These pumpkin protein chocolate chip cookies will put the great in your great pumpkin festivities this month. Welcome your taste buds to October!

While I’m sad to see summer go, the flavors of fall can be really exciting. Pumpkin-flavored foods have become quite the trend, but they can also be dangerous. Many companies tout their “limited edition” pumpkin treats, but they don’t tell you about the skyrocketing amounts of sugar, the hidden calories, the heavy flour, and all that butter you need to power-wash out of your body.

Pumpkin is low in calories, packed with fiber, and loaded with Vitamin A, so why dilute a food with so many benefits by pairing it with unhealthy ingredients? According to the National Cancer Institute, pumpkin has even been found to potentially help prevent cancer thanks to its powerful antioxidant beta-carotene (also found in sweet potatoes and carrots). This food is also packed with Vitamin C, which, of course, helps maintain a healthy immune system. So how do you enjoy the benefits of this fall favorite without adding unhealthy ingredients? Here is a delicious, fluffy pumpkin-chocolate chip cookie recipe that will satisfy any cookie craving. I even added some Sunwarrior protein to the mix! Make sure you chill these first before eating so that you can really taste the pumpkin flavor.
articleSummaryHTML: These pumpkin protein chocolate chip cookies will put the great in your great pumpkin festivities this month. Welcome your taste buds to October!
seoTitle: Pumpkin Protein Chocolate-Chip Cookies (Flour-Free & Vegan)
seoDescription: These pumpkin protein chocolate chip cookies will put the great in your great pumpkin festivities this month. Welcome your taste buds to October!
recipeName: Pumpkin Protein Chocolate-Chip Cookies (Flour-Free and Vegan)
ingredients:
s:1042:"
  • ½ cup of organic pumpkin (+ 1 additional tablespoon)
  • 1 cup of almond butter (make sure there is no sugar added)
  • ¼ cup of organic maple syrup
  • 1 flax egg (or regular egg, but use flax to make this vegan)
  • 1 scoop of Sunwarrior Protein (chocolate or natural)
  • 1 teaspoon of baking soda
  • 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract
  • ¼ teaspoon of pink Himalayan sea salt
  • 1 ½–2 teaspoons of pumpkin pie spice (depending on preference - always can add more, but start with 1 ½ )
  • ¼ cup of Enjoy Life Vegan Chocolate Chips 
";
directions:
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees.
  2. Combine all ingredients in a large bowl and stir until smooth.
  3. Add in the vegan chocolate chips and lightly stir. (The batter will be a little runny, and that is okay; these cookies are meant to have more of a fluffy cake-like consistency)
  4. Using a tablespoon, scoop out batter and put on parchment paper, 6 at a time (recipe makes about 12–16 depending on size of your scoop)
  5. Bake each batch for 14 minutes
  6. Remove cookies to a plate and store in refrigerator so they can firm up
  7. Let sit for 20 minutes in the refrigerator so the flavors can settle.
  8. Enjoy!

articleTitle: Vegan Black Bean and Butternut Squash Chili
articleBodyHTML: Cozy up this autumn with this vegan black bean and butternut squash chili. Filled with bold flavors and strong nutrients, dinner just got mm-mazing!
articleSummaryHTML: Cozy up this autumn with this vegan black bean and butternut squash chili. Filled with bold flavors and strong nutrients, dinner just got mm-mazing!
seoTitle: Vegan Black Bean and Butternut Squash Chili | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Cozy up this autumn with this vegan black bean and butternut squash chili. Filled with bold flavors and strong nutrients, dinner just got mm-mazing!
recipeName: Vegan Black Bean Chili with Butternut Squash
ingredients:
s:631:"
  • 32oz low sodium, vegetable broth
  • 1 can black beans, drained and rinsed
  • ½ cup red split lentils
  • 8oz butternut squash, diced
  • White mushrooms, chopped
  • 1 red onion, chopped
  • 1 jar salsa (Trader Joe’s Garlic Chipotle recommended, or you could make your own salsa)
  • Spinach, chopped (optional)
  • Avocado for garnish (optional)
";
directions:
Combine vegetable broth, red onion,and lentils in a medium-sized pot and bring to boil. Then reduce to simmer for 5–10 minutes. Add rinsed black beans, butternut squash, mushrooms, and salsa. The Garlic Chipotle Salsa from Trader Joes adds great flavor! No additional seasonings are needed since the salsa really flavors the whole soup.

Spinach and other vegetables are great additions too! If adding spinach, wait and add it later before the soup is almost done. Let soup simmer for 30–60 minutes. This soup is great served with a small portion of diced avocado on top for garnish. It adds a nice creamy texture and a shot of healthy nutrients including fiber, vitamin A, and potassium.

articleBodyHTML:
If you’re on a low-carb diet and need a little energy, these sweet treat mocha protein fat bombs are exactly what you need!

You’re going to love these decadent, rich protein packed balls. They can be made with a variety of different nuts and coatings. You can vary the nuts and seeds with this recipe. You can also coat them with cacao, carob, or coconut. If either of these two is not your thing, you can keep them nude and enjoy them just the same.

So, when that sweet tooth hits, give this recipe a go, and let us know what you think.
articleSummaryHTML: If you’re on a low-carb diet and need a little energy, these sweet treat mocha protein fat bombs are exactly what you need!
seoTitle: Mocha Protein Fat Bombs | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: If you’re on a low-carb diet and need a little energy, these sweet treat mocha protein fat bombs are exactly what you need!
ingredients:
s:893:"
  • 1 cup raw hazelnuts
  • 1/3 cup raw walnuts
  • 1/3 cup raw pecans
  • 1 tablespoon coconut butter
  • ½ scoop of Mocha Warrior Blend Protein
  • 1 teaspoon raw cocoa powder
  • 2 tablespoons extra virgin coconut oil
  • 6 to 8 drops vanilla Lakanto Monkfruit liquid sweetener
  • 1 teaspoons Lakanto Monkfruit golden sweetener
  • 1–2 teaspoons  non-alcoholic vanilla extract
  • ½ cup shredded coconut
  • ½ raw cacao powder
";
directions:
1. Soak all nuts the night before (8 hours) to remove enzyme inhibitors for better digestion. Rinse well. Place in a dehydrator for 10 to 12 hours. This helps them get their crunch back (If you do not have a dehydrator, skip this step and use nuts as is).
  2. Place hazelnuts, walnuts, and pecans in a food processor, process until the nuts turn into a flour-like consistency. Add the remainder of the ingredients and process all the ingredients until it starts to stick together.
  3. Remove from the food processor and place the ingredients in a bowl. Knead slightly making sure that all the dough sticks together. Shape into one large ball.
  4. Place raw cacao powder or coconut in a small Ziplock bag and set aside.
  5. Roll the fat bomb dough into 1-inch size balls. Roll larger if you want them a bigger size.
  6. Place a few at a time into the Ziplock bag with cacao or coconut and toss to coat.
  7. Once all the fat bombs are coated with either cacao or coconut, place them in an airtight container and put them in the freezer for at least an hour.  The longer you keep them in the freezer, the better they taste.
  8. Enjoy your treat!!

articleBodyHTML:
Suffering from carb phobia? It’s time to return to quality ancient grains in your meal line-up, and the place to start is with this fall superfood salad.

It was a good idea to pass on the over consumed, refined non-organic or GMO grains dominating breakfast, lunch, dinner, and even snacks. But there are an abundance of ancient grains readily available in most grocers that are truly good for you. These nutritional powerhouses are abundant in vitamins, minerals, and trace minerals along with most being a fabulous source of protein, healthy fats, and fiber.

My motto remains “Choose real food, as close to Mother Nature as possible aiming for a wide variety of seasonal, local foods.” And, of course, eat consciously and with gratitude and enjoy!
articleSummaryHTML: Suffering from carb phobia? It’s time to return to quality ancient grains in your meal line-up, and the place to start is with this fall superfood salad.
seoTitle: Shades of Fall Superfood Salad | Sunwarrior
seoDescription: Suffering from carb phobia? It’s time to return to quality ancient grains in your meal line-up, and the place to start is with this fall superfood salad.
ingredients:
s:1027:"
  • 1–1 ½ cups cooked farro or your favorite Ancient Grains
  • 1 medium bulb fennel, slivered
  • 2 cups sturdy leafy greens: romaine, watercress, and baby kale
  • 1 cup red cabbage, slivered or grated
  • 2 large carrots, grated
  • ½ cup pepitas/pumpkin seeds
  • 2 large organic oranges, sectioned, plus zest and any juices
  • ¼–1/3 cup quality olive oil, to taste
  • 4 tablespoons white balsamic vinegar
  • 1 small shallot, minced
  • Sea salt and black pepper, to taste
  • GARNISH:
  • Fresh spicy micro greens or sprouts, if desired
  • Slivered organic apricots or mulberries
";
directions:
Toss all the ingredients in a salad bowl and mix well. Taste and adjust vinaigrette and seasonings if needed.

Serve in regular bowls or plates or fora spectacular presentation spoon the salad into the leaf bowls from a whole cabbage or radicchio head or the oblong boats from Nappa cabbage.

Great add-ins options are sun-dried olives or capers and a few tablespoons mulberries, currants, apricots, or dried figs.

articleBodyHTML:
Pumpkin! Not just for pie anymore! Here is pumpkin for breakfast with these quick, easy pumpkin coconut overnight oats!

Overnight oats are one of the most perfect ways to start the day. You can make them the night before. So, when you wake up early, not knowing your left from your right, or you wake up rushed, barely able to brush all your teeth, you have to do practically zero work to enjoy a healthy, delicious breakfast. They’re also portable, which is sweet if you want to take them on your morning commute (and make everyone on the bus, train or traffic jam jealous)! And of course, they’re really filling! Their talent is keeping you going all morning long. The thing is: I’m only talking about overnight oats on their own. But now add some pumpkin, which on its own is mother nature’s gift to earth, and you’ve just got a full home-run. If you don’t believe me, make this recipe!
articleSummaryHTML: Pumpkin! Not just for pie anymore! Here is pumpkin for breakfast with these quick, easy pumpkin coconut overnight oats!
seoTitle: Pumpkin Coconut Overnight Oats | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Pumpkin! Not just for pie anymore! Here is pumpkin for breakfast with these quick, easy pumpkin coconut overnight oats!
ingredients:
s:733:"
  • ⅓ cup oats
  • 1 tablespoon chia seeds
  • 1 teaspoon pumpkin pie spice
  • 2 tablespoons coconut flakes
  • 1 teaspoon vanilla
  • 1 teaspoon maple syrup
  • ½ cup almond milk
  • ¼ cup pumpkin puree

Additional & Optional Toppings

  • granola
  • almond milk
  • coconut sugar
  • fresh or dried fruit
";
directions:
One by one, add all ingredients to a jar. This can be a ball jar, an old nut butter jar or Tupperware. (Old pickle jars are not recommended.)

Mix well, making sure to get all the way to the bottom of the jar.

Secure the lid and pop into the fridge, letting it rest while YOU rest. (Ideally, let it sit overnight. In a pinch, 20–30 minutes is all it really needs.)

In the morning, remove the lid, give it a few nice big stirs and add your desired toppings.

Take it with you to work, school, errands, the gym, your commute, or to your kitchen table and ENJOY!

articleBodyHTML: Soup’s on! As the weather cools down outside, warm up inside with this vegan vegetable soup. It’s filling and bursting with all the flavors of the perfect comfort food!
articleSummaryHTML: Soup’s on! As the weather cools down outside warm up inside with this vegan vegetable soup. It’s filling and bursting with all the flavors of fall!
seoTitle: Vegan Vegetable Soup | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Soup’s on! As the weather cools down outside warm up inside with this vegan vegetable soup. It’s filling and bursting with all the flavors of fall!
ingredients:
s:1143:"
  • 1 tablespoon olive oil
  • 1 small onion, diced
  • 2 cloves garlic, minced
  • 1 tablespoon fresh grated ginger
  • ½ cup red bell pepper, diced
  • ½ cup sliced snow peas
  • 1 can garbanzo beans
  • 1 cup diced butternut squash
  • 1 tablespoon curry powder
  • 1 scoop Sunwarrior Warrior Blend Protein, Natural
  • 1 can coconut milk
  • 1 cup veggie stock
  • Sea salt and pepper to taste

Garnish:

  • ¼ cup Pepitas, toasted
  • Fresh lime wedge
  • Cilantro, chopped
  • Jalapeno, sliced
";
directions:
1. Heat olive oil over medium heat in a large saucepan.
  2. Cook the onion and garlic for 2 minutes and then add butternut squash. Cook until soft
  3. and add the bell pepper, snow peas, ginger and curry powder. Stir to combine and cook
  4. for 2 more minutes.
  5. Add the protein, coconut milk, stock, salt, and pepper, stir well. Cook for 5–8 minutes until
  6. heated through.
  7. Can be served with brown rice or quinoa and top with garnish.

articleBodyHTML:
Your family called; they’re starving! Good thing we’ve got you covered with this delicious, fast, easy Pad Thai recipe. Dinner’s served!

This nutritious Pad Thai makes a super quick and easy dinner that tastes amazing and is 100% plant-based. It doesn’t require any fancy ingredients and all you need to do is just throw it all in a pan and do a little bit of stirring and boom, it’s ready!
articleSummaryHTML: Your family called; they’re starving! Good thing we’ve got you covered with this delicious, fast, easy Pad Thai recipe. Dinner’s served!
seoTitle: Vegan, Plant-Based Pad Thai | Sunwarrior Health Hub
seoDescription: Your family called; they’re starving! Good thing we’ve got you covered with this delicious, fast, easy Pad Thai recipe. Dinner’s served!
ingredients:
s:876:"
  • 8 oz. pack medium rice noodles
  • 4–6 tender stem broccoli
  • 4 oz. sugar snap peas
  • 1 red chili
  • 1 red pepper
  • 2 medium carrots
  • 1 leek
  • 1 handful bean sprouts
  • 2 heaped tablespoons peanut butter
  • 3 tablespoons soy sauce
  • 1 teaspoon ginger powder
  • 3 tablespoons sesame oil
  • 2 tablespoons maple syrup
  • 1 lime, cut in 4
  • a handful of peanuts (optional)
  • salt 
";
directions:
Soften the noodles by placing them in a large bowl and pour a kettle of boiling water until all noodles are covered. Leave for 5–10 min until they are soft.

In the meantime, prepare your vegetables: wash and cut the broccoli stems along in 23 pieces depending on their size; wash the snap peas; chop the chili; cut the pepper into long slices; peel the carrots and cut them into 3 inch long sticks; chop the leek.

In a large pan heat 3 tablespoons sesame oil, then add soy sauce, peanut butter, ginger powder, and maple syrup and mix thoroughly.
